('65', 0, 5, 6, 120) You have come to the wrong man.
('65', 0, 5, 7, 152) Do you know that I rarely attend the meetings of the Parliamentary Board 1?
('65', 0, 5, 8, 228) In Their selection of individual candidates I have absolutely no part.
('65', 0, 5, 9, 299) I have been involved in solving the problem of Malaviyaji’s party.
('65', 0, 5, 10, 366) 2 You have rightly written exhaustively to Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.
('65', 0, 5, 11, 434) Let him consider the question.
('65', 0, 5, 12, 465) This matter of selection is absolutely beyond me.

('65', 3, 0, 1, 4117) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 3, 1, 2, 4157) 5. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('65', 3, 2, 3, 4183) WARDHAGANJ, September 17, 1934
('65', 3, 3, 4, 4214) The rumour that I had contemplated severing all physical connection with the Congress was true.
('65', 3, 3, 5, 4310) However, for considerations urged by many friends who had come to Wardha during the meetings of the Working Committee and the Parliamentary Board last week, I agreed with them that it might be safer for me to leave the Congress, if at all, after the forthcoming session.
('65', 3, 3, 6, 4581) There was an intermediate course suggested by Pandit Govind Vallabh Pant and Mr. Rafi Ahmed Kidwai of remaining in the Congress without participating in the active administration of the organization but both Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad strongly disapproved of that course.
('65', 3, 3, 7, 4879) Sardar Vallabhbhai had agreed with me that the time had arrived for me to retire from the Congress but many others would not endorse that view.
('65', 3, 3, 8, 5023) After due consideration of all the pros and cons 1 have adopted the safe and prudent course of postponing the final step, at least till after the meeting of the Congress session in October.
('65', 3, 3, 9, 5213) one tempting idea behind the insistence on postponement was that it would enable me to test the accuracy of my impression that a very large body of Congress intelligentsia were tired of my method and views, and the programme based upon them, that I was a hindrance rather than a help to the natural growth of the Congress, that instead of remaining the most democratic and representative institution in the country, the Congress had degenerated into an organization dominated by my one personality and that in it there was no free play of reason.
('65', 3, 3, 10, 5760) If I am to test the truth or otherwise of my impression, naturally I must put before the public the reason on which my impression was based and my own proposals based thereon.
('65', 3, 3, 11, 5936) Congressmen might vote on them and thus clearly register their opinion.
('65', 3, 3, 12, 6008) I must try to do this as briefly as I can.
('65', 3, 3, 13, 6051) It has appeared to me that there is a growing and vital difference of outlook between many Congressmen and myself.
('65', 3, 3, 14, 6166) I seem to be going in a direction just opposite of what many of the most intellectual Congressmen would gladly and enthusiastically
('65', 4, 0, 1, 6298) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 5
('65', 4, 1, 2, 6347) take, if they were not hampered by their unexampled loyalty to me.
('65', 4, 1, 3, 6414) No leader can expect greater loyalty and devotion than I have received from intellectually minded Congressmen even when they have protested and signified their disapproval of the policies It have laid before the Congress.
('65', 4, 1, 4, 6636) For me any more to draw upon this loyalty and devotion is to put undue strain upon them.
('65', 4, 1, 5, 6725) Their loyalty cannot blind my eyes to what appears to me to be fundamental differences between the Congress intelligentsia and me.
('65', 4, 1, 6, 6856) Let me state them.
('65', 4, 1, 7, 6875) I put the spinning wheel and khadi in the forefront.
('65', 4, 1, 8, 6928) Hand spinning by the Congress intelligentsia has all but disappeared.
('65', 4, 1, 9, 6998) The general body of them have no faith in it and yet if I could carry their reason with me, I would substitute the four anna franchise by personal daily hand spinning.
('65', 4, 1, 10, 7166) The khadi clause of the Congress constitution has been almost a dead letter from the beginning and Congressmen have not been wanting who have reminded me that I am responsible for the hypocrisy and evasion about the working of the khadi clause.
('65', 4, 1, 11, 7411) I ought to have realized that it was not passed out of deep conviction, but largely out of personal loyalty to me.
('65', 4, 1, 12, 7526) I must own that there is considerable force in the argument.
('65', 4, 1, 13, 7587) Nevertheless my conviction is growing that if India is to win complete independence in terms of the toiling millions and through unadulterated non violence, the spinning wheel and khadi have to be as natural to the educated few as to the partially unemployed and semi starved millions, who, for not using their hands for the purpose for which nature has endowed man with them, have become almost like beasts of burden.
('65', 4, 1, 14, 8006) The spinning wheel is thus an emblem of human dignity and equality in the truest sense of the term.
('65', 4, 1, 15, 8106) It is the handmaid of agriculture.
('65', 4, 1, 16, 8141) It is the nation’s second lung.
('65', 4, 1, 17, 8173) We are perishing because we are using only one lung.
('65', 4, 1, 18, 8226) Yet only a few Congressmen have a living faith in the Indiawide potency of the wheel.
('65', 4, 1, 19, 8312) The removal of the khadi clause in the constitution would mean a removal of the living link between the Congress and the millions whom it has from its inception sought to represent and yet if it remains it has to be rightly enforced; but it cannot be, if a substantial majority of Congressmen have no living faith in it.
('65', 4, 1, 20, 8633) Take again the Parliamentary Board.
('65', 4, 1, 21, 8669) Though the author of non co operation I am convinced that in the present circumstances of
('65', 5, 0, 1, 8759) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 5, 1, 2, 8799) the country and in the absence of any general scheme of civil resistance, a Parliamentary Party within the Congress is the necessary part of any programme that may be framed by the Congress but there are sharp differences of opinion among us on that point.
('65', 5, 1, 3, 9056) The force with which I urged the programme at the A. I. C. C. meeting in Patna, 1
('65', 5, 2, 4, 9138) I know, oppressed many of our best colleagues but they hesitated to act according to their own conviction.
('65', 5, 2, 5, 9245) Up to a point suppression of one’s views in favour of those of another considered superior in wisdom or experience is virtuous and desirable for healthy growth of an organization.
('65', 5, 2, 6, 9425) It becomes a terrible oppression when one is called upon to repeat the performance from day to day.
('65', 5, 2, 7, 9525) Though I have never wished any such untoward result, I cannot conceal from me or the public the tragic fact that such has been my own experience.
('65', 5, 2, 8, 9671) Many have despaired of resisting me.
('65', 5, 2, 9, 9708) This is a humiliating revelation to me, a born democrat.
('65', 5, 2, 10, 9765) I make that claim if a complete identification with the poorest of mankind, an intense longing to live no better than they and a corresponding conscious effort to approach that level to the best of one’s ability can entitle one to make it.
('65', 5, 2, 11, 10005) I have welcomed the formation of the Socialist Group.
('65', 5, 2, 12, 10059) 2 Many of them are respected and self sacrificing co workers.
('65', 5, 2, 13, 10121) With all this, I have fundamental differences with them on the programme published in their authorized pamphlets.
('65', 5, 2, 14, 10235) But I would not by reason of the moral pressure I may be able to exert suppress the spread of ideas propounded in their literature.
('65', 5, 2, 15, 10367) I may not interfere with the free ex pression of those ideas however distasteful some of them may be to me.
('65', 5, 2, 16, 10475) If they gain ascendancy in the Congress, as they well may, I cannot remain in the Congress.
('65', 5, 2, 17, 10567) For me to be in active opposition should be unthinkable.
('65', 5, 2, 18, 10624) Though I have identified myself with many organizations during a long period of public service I have never accepted that position.
('65', 5, 2, 19, 10756) Then there is the policy advocated by some in regard to the States which is wholly different from what I have advised.
('65', 5, 2, 20, 10875) I have given many an anxious hour to the question but I have not been able to alter my view.
('65', 5, 3, 21, 10968) 1 Vide “Speech at A.I.C.C. Meeting, Patna II”, 19 5 1934. 2 The Congress Socialist Party was formed at Patna in May 1934.
('65', 6, 0, 1, 11090) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 7
('65', 6, 1, 2, 11139) Even on untouchability my method of approach is perhaps different from that of many if not most Congressmen.
('65', 6, 1, 3, 11248) For me, it is a deeply religious and moral issue.
('65', 6, 1, 4, 11298) Many think that it was a profound error for me to have disturbed the course of the civil resistance struggle by taking up the question in the manner and at the time I did.
('65', 6, 1, 5, 11470) I feel that I would have been untrue to myself, if I had taken any other course.
('65', 6, 1, 6, 11551) Last of all take non violence.
('65', 6, 1, 7, 11582) After 14 years of trial it still remains a policy with the majority of Congressmen whereas it is a fundamental creed with me.
('65', 6, 1, 8, 11708) That Congressmen do not still regard non violence as a creed is no fault of theirs.
('65', 6, 1, 9, 11792) It is undoubtedly my faulty presentation and still more faulty execution that are responsible for this failure.
('65', 6, 1, 10, 11904) I have no consciousness of faulty presentation or execution.
('65', 6, 1, 11, 11965) But it is the only possible inference from the fact that it has not yet become an integral part of the lives of Congressmen.
('65', 6, 1, 12, 12090) And if there is uncertainty about non violence there must be still more about civil resistance.
('65', 6, 1, 13, 12186) In spite of my 27 years of study and practice of the doctrine, I cannot claim to know all about it.
('65', 6, 1, 14, 12286) The field of research is necessarily limited as occasions for civil resistance in a man’s life must not be frequent.
('65', 6, 1, 15, 12403) It can only come after voluntary obedience to authority, whether of parents, teachers or other elders, religious or secular.
('65', 6, 1, 16, 12528) There need be no wonder that as the only expert, however imperfect among us, I should have come to the conclusion that it should for some time to come be limited only to me.
('65', 6, 1, 17, 12702) This was necessary in order to minimize errors and mischief proceeding from them as also to explore its hidden possibilities.
('65', 6, 1, 18, 12828) But again for no fault of Congressmen it has been increasingly difficult for me to carry the reason of fellow Congressmen with me in all resolutions 1 recently passed on the subject, while they have generously voted for them.
('65', 6, 1, 19, 13054) Even the memory of the sense of opposition which they experienced at the time of voting without an intelligent belief in these resolutions oppresses me just as much as they were oppressed.
('65', 6, 1, 20, 13243) They and I must be free from this oppression if we are all to grow in pursuit of what we believe to be the common goal.
('65', 6, 1, 21, 13363) Hence it is necessary for all concerned to act freely and boldly according to their convictions.
('65', 6, 1, 22, 13460) I have in my Patna statement 2, recommending the suspension of civil resistance, drawn attention to the failure of civil resistance to achieve two obvious results.
('65', 6, 1, 23, 13624) If we had the full non violent spirit in us
('65', 6, 2, 24, 13668) 1 Vide “Resolution on council entry”, 19 5 1934. 2 Vide “Statement to the press”, 2 4 1934.
('65', 7, 0, 1, 13760) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 7, 1, 2, 13800) it should have been self evident and should not have escaped the notice of the Government that their ordinances were certainly not warranted by any of the ‘misdeeds’ done by or imputed to us.
('65', 7, 1, 3, 13992) They were undoubtedly intended to break our spirits anyhow, but it would be wrong if we contended that civil resisters were above reproach.
('65', 7, 1, 4, 14132) If we were non violent through and through our non violence would have been self evident.
('65', 7, 1, 5, 14222) Nor were we able to show to the terrorists that we had greater faith in our non violence than they in their violence.
('65', 7, 1, 6, 14340) On the contrary many of us made them feel that we had the same spirit of violence in our breasts that they had.
('65', 7, 1, 7, 14452) Only we did not believe in deeds of violence.
('65', 7, 1, 8, 14498) Terrorists rightly argued that if the spirit of violence was common to both, the policy of doing or not doing violence was a matter of opinion.
('65', 7, 1, 9, 14642) I need not repeat what I have said before that the country has made great strides towards non violence indeed and that many have exhibited great courage and self sacrifice.
('65', 7, 1, 10, 14815) All I want to say is that ours has not been unadulterated non violence in thought, word and deed.
('65', 7, 1, 11, 14913) It is now my paramount duty to devise ways and means of showing demonstrably to the Government and the terrorists the efficacy of non violence as a means of achieving the right thing including freedom in every sense of the term.
('65', 7, 2, 12, 15142) For this experiment, to which my life is dedicated, I need complete detachment and absolute freedom of action.
('65', 7, 2, 13, 15253) Satyagraha, of which civil resistance is but a part, is to me the universal law of life.
('65', 7, 2, 14, 15342) ‘Satya’, in truth, is my God.
('65', 7, 2, 15, 15372) I can only search Him through non violence and in no other way and the freedom of my country as of the world is surely included in the search for truth.
('65', 7, 2, 16, 15525) I cannot suspend this search for anything in this world or another.
('65', 7, 2, 17, 15593) I have entered political life in pursuit of this search and if it cannot carry reason as well as heart of the educated Congressmen when I say that this search necessarily includes complete independence, and many other things which may be part of truth, it is plain I should work single handed in implicit faith that what I fail to make clear to my countrymen today shall be clear to them some day of itself or, if God wills it, through some apt word He may put in my mouth or some apt work which He may prompt me to do.
('65', 8, 0, 1, 16113) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 9
('65', 8, 1, 2, 16162) In matters of such tremendous importance a mechanical vote or a grudging assent will be wholly inadequate if not injurious to the cause itself.
('65', 8, 1, 3, 16306) I have referred to the common goal, but I have begun to doubt if all Congressmen understand the same thing by the expression complete independence.
('65', 8, 1, 4, 16454) I want for India complete independence in the full English sense of that English expression.
('65', 8, 1, 5, 16547) For me poorna swaraj has an infinitely larger meaning than complete independence, but even poorna swaraj is not self explained.
('65', 8, 1, 6, 16675) No one word or compound expression will give us a meaning which all can understand.
('65', 8, 1, 7, 16759) Hence on several occasions I have given several definitions of swaraj.
('65', 8, 1, 8, 16830) I hold that they are all true, not at all self contradictory.
('65', 8, 1, 9, 16892) They are all hopelessly incomplete even when put.
('65', 8, 1, 10, 16942) together, but I do not wish to labour this point further.
('65', 8, 1, 11, 17000) My mention of the difficulty, if not impossibility, of giving a complete definition leads me to another serious point of difference between many Congressmen and myself.
('65', 8, 1, 12, 17169) I have always said since 1908 that means and end are convertible terms and that, therefore, where the means are various and even contradictory the end must be different and even contradictory.
('65', 8, 1, 13, 17362) We have always control over the means, never on the end, but may not bother about its content if we all em ploy identical means with identical connotation for them.
('65', 8, 1, 14, 17527) It will be admitted that many Congressmen do not admit this, to me the obvious truth.
('65', 8, 1, 15, 17613) They believe that end justifies means whatever they may be.
('65', 8, 1, 16, 17673) It is the sum total of these differences which has sterilized the existing Congress programme because members who gave their lip assent to it, without believing in it, have naturally failed to reduce it to practice and yet I have no other programme save the Congress programme now before the country.
('65', 8, 1, 17, 17974) Untouchability, Hindu Muslim unity, total prohibition, hand spinning with khadi and cent per cent swadeshi in the sense of the revival of village industries and general reorganization of seven lakhs of villages ought to give all satisfaction that one’s love of one’s country may demand.
('65', 8, 1, 18, 18261) Personally I would like to bury myself in an Indian village, preferably in a Frontier village.
('65', 8, 1, 19, 18356) If the Khudai Khidmatgars are truly non violent they will contribute the largest share to the promotion of non violent spirit and of Hindu Muslim unity, for if they are non violent in thought, word and deed and are lovers of
('65', 9, 0, 1, 18581) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 9, 1, 2, 18622) Hindu Muslim unity, surely through them we should see the accomplishment of the two things we need most in this land.
('65', 9, 1, 3, 18740) The Afghan menace which we dread so much should then be.
('65', 9, 1, 4, 18797) a thing of the past.
('65', 9, 1, 5, 18818) I am, therefore, yearning to test the truth for myself of the claim that they have imbibed the spirit of non violence and are believers in the heart unity of Hindus, Mussalmans and others.
('65', 9, 1, 6, 19007) I should like also personally to deliver the message of the spinning wheel to them.
('65', 9, 1, 7, 19091) In this and various such other ways I would love to serve the Congress in my own humble manner, whether I am in it or outside.
('65', 9, 1, 8, 19218) I have reserved to the last any reference to the growing corruption in our ranks.
('65', 9, 1, 9, 19300) I have already said enough about it in public.
('65', 9, 1, 10, 19347) In spite of all I have said the Congress still remains in my estimation the most powerful and most representative organization in the country.
('65', 9, 1, 11, 19490) It has a history of uninterrupted noble service and self sacrifice.
('65', 9, 1, 12, 19558) From its inception it has weathered storms, as no other institution has done.
('65', 9, 1, 13, 19636) It has commanded a measure of self sacrifice of which any country would be proud.
('65', 9, 1, 14, 19718) It holds today the largest number of devoted men and women of unimpeachable character.
('65', 9, 1, 15, 19805) If I must leave this organization I shall not do so without a wrench and I should do it only when I am convinced that by being outside I would serve it, that is, the country better than by being in it.
('65', 9, 1, 16, 20007) I propose to test the feeling of the Congress on all the points I have touched by placing before the Subjects Committee certain resolutions giving effect to the views enunciated above.
('65', 9, 1, 17, 20192) The first amendment I would propose is to replace the words “legitimate and peaceful” by the words ‘truthful and non violent’.
('65', 9, 1, 18, 20319) I should not have done so but for the purpose of the opposition which was raised against the utterly innocent use by me of the two adjectives in place of “legitimate and peaceful”.
('65', 9, 1, 19, 20500) If Congressmen really believe in the necessity of truthfulness and non violence for the attainment of our goal they should have no hesitation about accepting the unequivocal adjectives.
('65', 9, 1, 20, 20686) The second amendment would be to replace the four anna franchise by the delivery, by every member to a Congress depot, of 2,000 rounds (one round equal to four feet) per month of well twisted even yarn of not less than 15 counts spun by himself or herself.
('65', 9, 1, 21, 20943) On proof of Poverty, with enough cotton for spinning the requisite quantity, the arguments for and against need not be repeated here.
('65', 10, 0, 1, 21077) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 11
('65', 10, 1, 2, 21127) we are to be a truly democratic body representing even the lowest paid labourer, we cannot do it better than by devising a simple labour franchise.
('65', 10, 2, 3, 21275) Hand spinning is by common consent the lowest paid labour and yet the most dignified.
('65', 10, 2, 4, 21361) It is the nearest approach to adult franchise, within the means of almost everyone who is willing to labour for the sake of the country for half an hour daily.
('65', 10, 2, 5, 21521) Is it too much to expect the intelligentsia and propertied classes to recognize the dignity of labour irrespective of the material benefit it brings?
('65', 10, 2, 6, 21671) Is not labour, like learning, its own reward?
('65', 10, 2, 7, 21717) If we are true servants of the masses, we would take pride in spinning for their sakes.
('65', 10, 2, 8, 21805) I recall what the late Maulana Mahomed Ali used to repeat from many a platform.
('65', 10, 2, 9, 21885) As the sword was the symbol, he would say, of brute force and might, the wheel or the takli was the symbol of non violence, service and humility.
('65', 10, 2, 10, 22031) When the wheel was accepted as part of the National Flag it was surely implied that the spinning wheel would hum in every household.
('65', 10, 2, 11, 22164) If Congress men do not believe in the message of the wheel, we must remove it from the National Flag and khaddar from the constitution.
('65', 10, 2, 12, 22300) It is intolerable that there should be unashamed fraud in the observance of the khaddar clause.
('65', 10, 2, 13, 22396) The third amendment I should propose would be that no one shall be entitled to vote to any Congress election whose name has not been on the Congress register continuously for six months without default and who has not been a habitual wearer wholly of khaddar for that period.
('65', 10, 2, 14, 22672) Great difficulty has been experienced in the working of the khaddar clause.
('65', 10, 2, 15, 22748) It can be easily avoided by giving powers, subject to appeal to the President of the Congress, to the chairmen of the respective committees to decide the question as to whether a particular voter is or is not a habitual wearer wholly of khaddar within the meaning of the constitution.
('65', 10, 2, 16, 23033) No one is to be considered such a wearer who at the time of voting is not manifestly wholly clad in khaddar.
('65', 10, 2, 17, 23142) But no rule however carefully and strictly worded can produce satisfactory results if a large number do not voluntarily carry it out.
('65', 10, 2, 18, 23276) Experience has shown that the Congress is an unwieldy organization even with 6,000 delegates.
('65', 10, 2, 19, 23370) In practice the full number has never attended the Congress and when this Congress register nowhere contains a truly representative list the delegation can hardly be claimed to be as reality.
('65', 11, 0, 1, 23562) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 11, 1, 2, 23603) I would, therefore, have an amendment for the purpose of reducing the number to not more than 1,000 delegates, not more than one delegate per every thousand voters.
('65', 11, 1, 3, 23768) To have full number of delegates would mean one million voters, not an overambitious hope in a country having a population of 315 millions.
('65', 11, 1, 4, 23908) The Congress would by this amendment gain in substance what it may lose in the show of numbers.
('65', 11, 1, 5, 24004) The spectacular part of the session would be kept intact by making ample provision for visitors, but the Reception Committees will be spared the wholly unnecessary anxiety of having to provide accommodation for an unwieldy number of delegates.
('65', 11, 1, 6, 24248) Let us recognize the fact that the Congress enjoys prestige, democratic character and influence not by the number of the delegates and visitors it has drawn to its annual functions but by the ever increasing amount of service it has rendered.
('65', 11, 2, 7, 24491) Western democracy is on its trial, if it has not already proved a failure.
('65', 11, 2, 8, 24566) May it not be reserved to India to evolve the true science of democracy by giving a visible demonstration of this fitness?
('65', 11, 2, 9, 24689) Corruption and hypocrisy ought not to be inevitable products of democracy as they undoubtedly are today; nor bulk a true test of democracy.
('65', 11, 2, 10, 24829) True democracy is not inconsistent with a few persons representing the spirit, the hope and the aspirations of those whom they claim to represent.
('65', 11, 2, 11, 24976) I hold that democracy cannot be evolved by forcible methods.
('65', 11, 2, 12, 25037) The spirit of democracy cannot be in posed from without.
('65', 11, 2, 13, 25094) It has to come from within.
('65', 11, 3, 14, 25122) I have mentioned here only the principal amendments I should propose in the constitution.
('65', 11, 3, 15, 25212) there would be other resolutions bringing out clearly the points I have touched upon in the foregoing paras.
('65', 11, 3, 16, 25321) I don’t need to burden this statement with them.
('65', 11, 4, 17, 25370) My fear is that even the amendments I have named will hardly commend themselves to the large number of Congressmen who will attend the Congress.
('65', 11, 4, 18, 25515) Nevertheless if I am to guide the policy of the Congress I hold them and the resolutions in keeping with the spirit of this statement to be essential for the earliest attainment of our goal.
('65', 11, 5, 19, 25706) No voluntary organization can succeed in its purpose without its resolutions and policies being carried out whole heartedly by its members and no leader can give a good account of himself if his lead
('65', 12, 0, 1, 25906) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 13
('65', 12, 1, 2, 25956) is not faithfully, ungrudgingly and intelligently followed and this is true of a leader who has no resource at his disposal but what truth and non violence can supply.
('65', 12, 1, 3, 26124) It follows, therefore, that there is no room for compromise on the essentials of the programme I have endeavoured to adumbrate in these paras.
('65', 12, 1, 4, 26267) Let Congressmen, therefore, examine it dispassionately and on its merits.
('65', 12, 1, 5, 26341) They must eliminate me from their consideration and give effect to the dictates of their reason.
('65', 12, 2, 6, 26438) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 9 1934

('65', 15, 7, 12, 31171) I have your letter.
('65', 15, 7, 13, 31191) In his letter Rajbhoj has used the expression ‘Brahmin’ to mean non Harijan Hindus.
('65', 15, 7, 14, 31275) The Board does not consist exclusively of Brahmins; it has non Brahmins also.
('65', 15, 7, 15, 31353) Nevertheless you should remember that the Board contains only workers and not those who want prominence or cheap credit.
('65', 15, 7, 16, 31474) Strange as it may appear, the largest amount of sacrifice is still to be found among Brahmins, if it is also true that Brahmins are the stumbling block in the way of progress of the campaign against untouchability.
('65', 15, 7, 17, 31689) But no provincial organization is wholly confined to Brahmins.
('65', 15, 7, 18, 31752) As to the second objection, you will be glad to know that there is no Harijan Board which does not contain at least one Harijan, and in several organizations there are many.
('65', 15, 7, 19, 31926) There are hundreds of Harijan Boards affiliated to the Central Board.
('65', 15, 7, 20, 31996) I can claim no merit or credit
('65', 15, 8, 21, 32027) 1 Of the Harijan Sevak Sangh 2 The superscription in this and other letters addressed to Mary Barr is in the Devanagari script.
('65', 16, 0, 1, 32155) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 17
('65', 16, 1, 2, 32205) for this event.
('65', 16, 1, 3, 32221) If I could have helped it, I should certainly have confined all these boards exclusively to non Harijans.
('65', 16, 1, 4, 32327) In the place of the word ‘penitents’ read ‘debtors’.
('65', 16, 1, 5, 32380) 1 Harijans are in the place of creditors.
('65', 16, 1, 6, 32422) Have you ever heard of a board of debtors containing a sprinkling of creditors?
('65', 16, 1, 7, 32502) Debtors alone know how to discharge their obligations.
('65', 16, 1, 8, 32557) Creditors will be the judges as to whether they will give them discharge certificates for the payments they will make.
('65', 16, 1, 9, 32676) But they would not even be bothered about the meetings of the debtors.
('65', 16, 1, 10, 32747) They will have their own meetings, their own advisers and the like.
('65', 16, 1, 11, 32815) And I have invited the Harijans to form their own advisory boards which will become irresistible.
('65', 16, 1, 12, 32913) They will, if they are compact bodies, dictate their own terms.
('65', 16, 1, 13, 32977) If you are closely following the Harijan from week to week you will understand surely the meaning of what I have said.
('65', 16, 1, 14, 33096) Marvellous work has been done in the shape of distribution of funds.
('65', 16, 1, 15, 33165) Harijan Boards are intended to be swiftly moving organizations carrying out their operations without fuss.
('65', 16, 1, 16, 33272) They are not debating societies.
('65', 16, 1, 17, 33305) To alter their character would be to turn them into debating societies frittering away time, energy and substance, whereas I want to save every ounce of these solely for the benefit of Harijans.
('65', 16, 1, 18, 33500) Then and then only will there be no ‘you’ and ‘we’, but only ‘we’.
('65', 16, 1, 19, 33567) You have again returned to your proposal about prayer.
('65', 16, 1, 20, 33622) The proposal does not appear to me to be feasible.

('65', 16, 1, 22, 33792) You may perhaps know that every Friday we have a rendering of “Lead, Kindly Light” in the Ashram and every Thursday we have a very popular Islamic bhajan.
('65', 16, 1, 23, 33947) The Ashram Bhajanavali contains several bhajans from Mussalman sources and you will find also a selection of Christian hymns.
('65', 16, 1, 24, 34073) On certain occasions we have Christian and Mussalman prayers.
('65', 16, 1, 25, 34135) But to make these prayers a daily feature would be entirely mechanical, if not also hypocritical.
('65', 16, 1, 26, 34233) It would be different if we had a large number of Mussalmans and Christians in the different ashrams.
('65', 16, 1, 27, 34335) And if we had an ashram predominantly Mussalman or Christian, there will naturally be generally only Christian or Islamic prayers.
('65', 16, 1, 28, 34466) The point I am trying to make is to show that the ashrams are not theosophical organizations, but they are organizations which have equal regard for all the religions.
('65', 16, 1, 29, 34634) I should expect, therefore, non Hindus in an ashram predominantly Hindu to pay equal respect to the Hindu form of
('65', 16, 2, 30, 34748) 1 Vide “Letter to P. N. Rajbhoj”.

('65', 17, 1, 4, 35005) Ashrams honestly attempt, though they may ever fail, to reach the ideal of equality and growth from within.

('65', 31, 0, 1, 55579) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 31, 1, 2, 55620) 34. LETTER TO VAMAN G. JOSHI September 20, 1934
('65', 31, 2, 3, 55668) DEAR VAMANRAO 1,
('65', 31, 3, 4, 55685) I have your letter.
('65', 31, 3, 5, 55705) Without entering into the argument, I give you my replies to your questions.
('65', 31, 3, 6, 55782) 1. When a man wears clothes made of khadi as a matter of habit, he is a habitual wearer.
('65', 31, 3, 7, 55871) If, therefore, for any just cause he cannot use khadi on some occasions, he does not cease to be a habitual wearer.
('65', 31, 3, 8, 55987) 2. But if a person appears at Congress functions in clothes not made of khadi, he will be presumed not to be a habitual wearer of khadi.
('65', 31, 3, 9, 56124) 3. Habitual wear of clothes made of khadi means all clothes from top to toe made of hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('65', 31, 3, 10, 56240) 4. When it is pointed out to the Chair or when the Chairman of a Congress meeting himself knows that a voter or a candidate is not wearing khadi clothes at that meeting, he is bound to rule that the person is not a habitual wearer in spite of his protestation to the contrary.
('65', 31, 3, 11, 56517) Yours sincerely,
('65', 31, 4, 12, 56534) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('65', 39, 3, 6, 69154) 46. INTERVIEW WITH A HARIJAN WORKER 1
('65', 39, 4, 7, 69192) [Before September 21, 1934]
('65', 39, 5, 8, 69220) [GANDHIJI:] So you wanted to take the citadel by storm?
('65', 39, 6, 9, 69276) [AKARTE:] Yes, rather.
('65', 39, 6, 10, 69299) But the preacher is a believer in the removal of untouchability, and I had told the Secretary that he should hold the kirtan in a temple which was open to the Harijans.
('65', 39, 6, 11, 69468) You did not approach the preacher himself?
('65', 39, 7, 12, 69511) No, Sir.
('65', 39, 8, 13, 69520) The preacher himself had no prejudice against the Harijans, for, you yourself say he went to the Harijan quarters and gave them a kirtan?
('65', 39, 9, 14, 69658) He had no prejudices, but he should not have yielded to the Secretary.
('65', 39, 9, 15, 69729) You know that the temple was not open to the Harijans, and you laid yourself open to the charge that you wanted to go in under cover of the kirtan?
('65', 39, 10, 16, 69877) But, Mahatmaji, he might have come out and held the kirtan outside.
('65', 39, 10, 17, 69945) But he did go to the Harijan quarters.
('65', 39, 10, 18, 69984) Didn’t he?
('65', 39, 11, 19, 69995) But the handbills invited all the Hindus.
('65', 39, 11, 20, 70037) Quite right.
('65', 39, 11, 21, 70050) But the preacher had not issued the leaflets, and, then, “all” means, in our present state of unenlightenment, the so called Hindus, and does not include the Harijans.
('65', 39, 12, 22, 70218) Mahatmaji, the Hindu Sabha Secretary ought to know better.
('65', 39, 13, 23, 70277) 1 Reported by Mahadev Desai, this appeared in Harijan under the title “The Wrong Way”.
('65', 39, 13, 24, 70364) The Hindu Sabha of Morsi, in C. P., had arranged with one of its preachers to hold a kirtan and issued handbills inviting Hindus.
('65', 39, 13, 25, 70494) The kirtan was held in a temple where Akarte, a Harijan worker, and other Harijans were not allowed.
('65', 39, 13, 26, 70595) The preacher also declined to hold the kirtan outside for the benefit of the Harijans but offered to go to the Harijan quarters and give them a special kirtan.
('65', 39, 13, 27, 70755) Akarte later held a protest meeting and passed a resolution condemning the preacher.
('65', 39, 13, 28, 70840) Akarte then sought Gandhiji’s guidance.
('65', 40, 0, 1, 70880) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 41
('65', 40, 1, 2, 70930) Well, well, no legal quibbles.
('65', 40, 1, 3, 70961) There ought not to have been a protest meeting, at all.
('65', 40, 1, 4, 71017) You might have approached the preacher in the first instance, you might have gently asked him to address a meeting of the Hindus for the removal of untouchability or to appeal to the Hindus in the course of his kirtan itself to admit the Harijans to a religious function to which they had every right.
('65', 40, 1, 5, 71319) You might have asked the other Hindus to boycott the function altogether.
('65', 40, 1, 6, 71393) Even now, if you have sufficient energy in you, you may serve on the temple trustees notice asking them to show cause why they prevented Harijans from entering even the precincts of the temple and thus from listening to a religious sermon.
('65', 40, 1, 7, 71633) That would be a good test case; whilst temple entry may be prohibited in law, entry into the precincts may not be.
('65', 40, 1, 8, 71748) But the protest meeting and the other things you did were, perhaps, an exhibition of excessive zeal.
('65', 40, 1, 9, 71849) The method of our work is unadulterated non violence, and non violence alone will succeed.
('65', 40, 1, 10, 71940) Force is sure to fail.
('65', 40, 2, 11, 71963) I am sorry, Mahatmaji; I must confess I was in a temper.
('65', 40, 2, 12, 72020) If you like, I can make a public statement to that effect.
('65', 40, 3, 13, 72079) That is hardly necessary.
('65', 40, 3, 14, 72105) Your restraint in action will be more eloquent than any expression of regret.
('65', 40, 4, 15, 72183) Though cholera is fast disappearing in Malkapur and Morsi, 1 there are other villages where it has spread and might spread.
('65', 40, 4, 16, 72307) What precautionary measures would you suggest?
('65', 40, 4, 17, 72354) Could we take the help of the police in a crisis like this?
('65', 40, 5, 18, 72414) Certainly, police help may be taken, as medical help is taken.
('65', 40, 5, 19, 72477) All drinking water must be boiled (and a grain of potassium permanganate should be added to it.
('65', 40, 5, 20, 72573) They must be asked not to drink any other water.
('65', 40, 6, 21, 72622) But they are ignorant, they don’t listen.
('65', 40, 6, 22, 72664) And how can we expect the poor people to drink boiled water, when they go to the fields.
('65', 40, 7, 23, 72753) Now, that’s not an active worker speaking!
('65', 40, 7, 24, 72796) You must carry on vigorous propaganda, provide them with every facility and not rest until they have listened to you.
('65', 40, 7, 25, 72914) You can provide them with extra fuel to boil the water with, pots in which to carry the boiled water to the fields and potassium permanganate.
('65', 40, 7, 26, 73057) You can have Harijans whom you have inoculated to accompany you and help in the propaganda.
('65', 40, 7, 27, 73149) No pains to be spared.
('65', 40, 8, 28, 73172) 1 The worker had described the cholera epidemic in these villages and the steps he had taken to control it.
('65', 41, 0, 1, 73280) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 41, 1, 2, 73321) I quite see.
('65', 41, 1, 3, 73334) I was tending a Harijan myself yesterday.
('65', 41, 1, 4, 73376) I had a medical man to treat him; he was worse, I had another doctor called and I am glad he will completely recover.
('65', 41, 1, 5, 73494) He got a treatment which the richest in our village might envy.
('65', 41, 1, 6, 73558) That’s vary good.
('65', 41, 1, 7, 73576) Rest assured that your name has gone down in the book of God, who keeps an accurate record of all things good and bad.
('65', 41, 1, 8, 73695) There is no better Accountant on earth.
('65', 41, 2, 9, 73735) Harijan, 21 9 1934
('65', 41, 3, 10, 73754) 47. WHY AGAINST VIOLENCE?
('65', 41, 4, 11, 73780) A correspondent argues:
('65', 41, 5, 12, 73804) Why are you against violence?
('65', 41, 5, 13, 73834) Do you think that every act of violence is an expression of himsa?
('65', 41, 5, 14, 73901) Is it not strange that we should feel a kind of horror, pity and disgust when we see a murder or assassination, and silently witness the slow sucking of blood going on every day in the world?
('65', 41, 5, 15, 74093) If one believes that a successful bloody revolution would ameliorate a good deal of misery in the world, why should he not resort to arms?
('65', 41, 5, 16, 74232) Don’t you realize that the rulers of the world have become so callous that, to understand you or humanity, they must again become children.
('65', 41, 5, 17, 74372) I don’t mean to say they are born bad.
('65', 41, 5, 18, 74411) But their badness is a physical fact and, in spite of themselves, they cannot alter it.
('65', 41, 6, 19, 74499) It is because the rulers, if they are bad, are so, not neces sarily or wholly by reason of birth, but largely because of their environment, that I have hopes of their altering their course.
('65', 41, 6, 20, 74689) It is perfectly true, as the writer says, that the rulers cannot alter their course themselves.
('65', 41, 6, 21, 74785) If they are dominated by their environment, they do not surely deserve to be killed, but should be changed by a change of environment.
('65', 41, 6, 22, 74920) But the environment are we—the people who make the rulers what they are.
('65', 41, 6, 23, 74993) They are thus an exaggerated editon of what we are in the aggregate.
('65', 41, 6, 24, 75062) If my argument is sound, any violence done to the rulers would be violence done to ourselves.
('65', 41, 6, 25, 75156) It would be suicide.
('65', 41, 6, 26, 75177) And since I do not want to commit suicide, nor encourage my neighbours to do so, I become non violent myself and invite my neighbours to do likewise.
('65', 41, 6, 27, 75327) Moreover, violence may destroy one or more bad rulers, but, like Ravana’s heads, others will pop up in their places, for, the root lies elsewhere.
('65', 41, 6, 28, 75474) It lies in us.
('65', 41, 6, 29, 75489) If we will reform ourselves, the rulers will automatically do so.
('65', 41, 6, 30, 75555) The correspondent seems to imagine that a non violent person
('65', 42, 0, 1, 75616) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 43
('65', 42, 1, 2, 75666) has no feelings and that he is a silent witness to the “slow sucking of blood going on every day in the world”.
('65', 42, 1, 3, 75778) Non violence is not a passive force nor so helpless as the correspondent will make it out to be.
('65', 42, 1, 4, 75875) Barring truth, if truth is to be considered apart from non violence, the latter is the activest force in the world.
('65', 42, 1, 5, 75991) It never fails.
('65', 42, 1, 6, 76007) Violence only seemingly succeeds, and nobody has ever claimed uniform success for violence.
('65', 42, 1, 7, 76099) Non violence never promises immediate and tangible results.
('65', 42, 1, 8, 76159) It is not a mango trick.
('65', 42, 1, 9, 76184) Its failures are, therefore, all seeming.
('65', 42, 1, 10, 76226) A believer in violence will kill the murderer and boast of his act.
('65', 42, 1, 11, 76294) But he never killed murder.
('65', 42, 1, 12, 76322) By murdering the murderer, he added to it and probably invited more.
('65', 42, 1, 13, 76391) The law of retaliation is the law of multiplying evil.
('65', 42, 1, 14, 76446) A non violent man will act upon the murderer through his love.
('65', 42, 1, 15, 76509) He cannot, by punishing the murderer, undo the murder already committed.
('65', 42, 1, 16, 76582) But he hopes by gentleness to get the murderer to repent of his deed and change the whole course of his life.
('65', 42, 1, 17, 76692) A non violent man always and automatically turns the searchlight selfward and discovers that the best course of conduct is to do unto others as he would have others to do unto him.
('65', 42, 1, 18, 76873) If he was the murderer, he would not like to be killed for his madness but would like the opportunity of mending himself.
('65', 42, 1, 19, 76995) He knows, too, that he must not destroy what he cannot create.
('65', 42, 1, 20, 77058) God is the sole Judge between man and man.
('65', 42, 2, 21, 77101) Harijan, 21 9 1934
('65', 42, 3, 22, 77120) 48. GOD OR NO GOD
('65', 42, 4, 23, 77138) During my visit to the South I met Harijans and others who pretended not to believe in God.
('65', 42, 4, 24, 77230) At one place where a conference of Harijans was being held, the chairman delivered a harangue on atheism under the very shadow of a temple which Harijans had built for themselves with their own money.
('65', 42, 4, 25, 77431) But out of the bitterness of his heart for the treatment meted out to fellow Harijans, he had begun to doubt the very existence of a benevolent Power that had allowed such cruelty to flourish.
('65', 42, 4, 26, 77624) There was, perhaps, some excuse for this disbelief.
('65', 42, 4, 27, 77676) But here is a specimen of disbelief of another type from another source:
('65', 42, 5, 28, 77749) Don’t you think that a preconceived idea of a God, Truth or Reality
('65', 43, 0, 1, 77817) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 43, 1, 2, 77858) might colour the whole trend of our search and hence be a great impediment and may defeat the very purpose of our life?
('65', 43, 1, 3, 77978) For example, you take certain moral truths as fundamental.
('65', 43, 1, 4, 78037) But we are in search and, as long as we have not found the reality, how can we boast or assert that a certain rule of morality is the truth or it alone.
('65', 43, 1, 5, 78190) is going to help us in our search.
('65', 43, 2, 6, 78225) No search is possible without some workable assumptions.
('65', 43, 2, 7, 78282) If we grant nothing, we find nothing.
('65', 43, 2, 8, 78320) Ever since its commencement, the world, the wise and the foolish included, has proceeded upon the assumption that, if we are, God is and that, if God is not, we are not.
('65', 43, 2, 9, 78490) And since belief in God is co existent with the humankind, existence of God is treated as a fact more definite than the fact that the sun is.
('65', 43, 2, 10, 78632) This living faith has solved the largest number of puzzles of life.
('65', 43, 2, 11, 78700) It has alleviated our misery.
('65', 43, 2, 12, 78730) It sustains us in life, it is our one solace in death.
('65', 43, 2, 13, 78785) The very search for Truth becomes interesting, worth while, because of this belief.
('65', 43, 2, 14, 78869) But search for Truth is search for God.
('65', 43, 2, 15, 78909) Truth is God.
('65', 43, 2, 16, 78923) God is, because Truth is.
('65', 43, 2, 17, 78949) We embark upon the search, because we believe that there is Truth and that It can be found by diligent search and meticulous observance of the wellknown and well tried rules of the search.
('65', 43, 2, 18, 79138) There is no record in history of the failure of such search.
('65', 43, 2, 19, 79199) Even the atheists who have pretended to disbelieve in God have believed in Truth.
('65', 43, 2, 20, 79281) The trick they have performed is that of giving God another, not a new, name.
('65', 43, 2, 21, 79359) His names are Legion.
('65', 43, 2, 22, 79381) Truth is the crown of them all.
('65', 43, 2, 23, 79413) What is true of God is true, though in a less degree, of the ‘assumption of the truth of some fundamental moralities’.
('65', 43, 2, 24, 79532) As a matter of fact, they are implied in the belief in God or Truth.
('65', 43, 2, 25, 79601) Departure from these has landed the truants in endless misery.
('65', 43, 2, 26, 79664) Difficulty of practice should not be confused with disbelief.
('65', 43, 2, 27, 79726) A Himalayan expedition has its prescribed conditions of success.
('65', 43, 2, 28, 79791) Difficulty of fulfilling the conditions does not make the expedition impossible.
('65', 43, 2, 29, 79872) It only adds interest and zest to the search.
('65', 43, 2, 30, 79918) Well, this expedition in search of God or Truth is infinitely more than numberless Himalayan expeditions and, therefore, much more interesting.
('65', 43, 2, 31, 80062) If we have no zest for it, it is because of the weakness of our faith.
('65', 43, 2, 32, 80133) What we see with our physical eyes is more real to us than the only Reality.
('65', 43, 2, 33, 80210) We know that appearances are deceptive.
('65', 43, 2, 34, 80250) And yet we treat trivialities as realities.
('65', 43, 2, 35, 80294) To see the trivialities as such is half the battle won.
('65', 43, 2, 36, 80350) It constitutes more than half the search after Truth or God.
('65', 43, 2, 37, 80411) Unless we disengage ourselves
('65', 44, 0, 1, 80441) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 45
('65', 44, 1, 2, 80491) from trivialities, we have not even the leisure for the great search; Or is it to be reserved for our leisure hours?
('65', 44, 1, 3, 80608) Let Harijan workers know that the campaign against untouchability is a part of the great search, whether we know it or not.
('65', 44, 1, 4, 80732) Untouchability is a big falsehood.
('65', 44, 1, 5, 80767) We have proved it for ourselves, or we should not be devotees of the cause.
('65', 44, 1, 6, 80843) We can transmit the truth to others only by diligence and due observance of the conditions of success which have been often enough set forth in these columns.

('65', 60, 1, 12, 106722) I have acted in this manner all my life.
('65', 60, 1, 13, 106763) I have been content to accept moral responsibility.
('65', 60, 1, 14, 106815) After writing all this, the conclusion to which I come is this, that though Vallabhbhai has understood all this in his mind he has fearlessly done what he thought right.
('65', 60, 1, 15, 106985) Even if, therefore, he harboursa prejudice against Kaka, that cannot be deduced from this incident.
('65', 60, 1, 16, 107085) Hence, if he did anything in the past, that should not be made a reason by Kaka for leaving Gujarat just now and, therefore, not a word should be uttered against Sardar.
('65', 60, 1, 17, 107255) Kaka has held his view all the time and we ought to try to persuade him to change it.
('65', 60, 1, 18, 107341) I did that even while I was in jail and am still trying to persuade Kaka to see the matter in that light.
('65', 60, 1, 19, 107447) And since Vallabhbhai’s name has been connected with Kaka’s desire to leave Gujarat and his good name has suffered, it has become all the more Kaka’s duty not to leave Gujarat.
('65', 60, 1, 20, 107624) Only then can the wings of slander be clipped.
('65', 60, 1, 21, 107671) Otherwise this kabar 2 will keep on flying.
('65', 60, 1, 22, 107715) Does this reasoning appeal to you?

('65', 61, 4, 10, 108389) 69. INTRODUCTION TO “VARNAVYAVASTHA”3
('65', 61, 5, 11, 108427) September 23, 1934 4
('65', 61, 6, 12, 108448) This booklet is a collection of all my writings on varnadharma.
('65', 61, 6, 13, 108512) Its printing was complete some or perhaps many months ago but it remained unpublished in the absence of an introduction.
('65', 61, 6, 14, 108633) I had agreed to write the introduction but could not do so till now on account of my Harijan tour.
('65', 61, 8, 15, 108732) I should have loved to go through all my speeches and writings on varnashrama during the past fifteen years before writing this introduction, but it was physically impossible.
('65', 61, 8, 16, 108908) perhaps it is well that I cannot do so.
('65', 61, 8, 17, 108948) I have never made a fetish of consistency.
('65', 61, 8, 18, 108991) I am a votary of truth and I must say what I feel and think at a given moment on the question, without regard to what I may have said before on it.
('65', 61, 8, 19, 109139) The publisher too wants this.
('65', 61, 8, 20, 109169) 3 It is for the reader to find out how far my present views coincide with those formerly expressed.
('65', 61, 8, 21, 109269) Wherever he finds that what I have said or written before runs contrary to what I am writing now, he should without hesitation reject the former.
('65', 61, 8, 22, 109415) I do not claim omniscience.
('65', 61, 8, 23, 109443) 4 I claim to be a votary of truth and to follow to the best of my ability what seems to be the truth at a given time.
('65', 61, 8, 24, 109561) As my vision gets clearer, my views must grow clearer with daily practice.
('65', 61, 8, 25, 109636) Where I have deliberately altered an opinion, the change should be
('65', 61, 9, 26, 109703) 1 Omissions as in the source 2 ibid.
('65', 61, 9, 27, 109740) 3 This sentence is from Harijanbandhu.
('65', 61, 9, 28, 109779) 4 This and the following sentence are from Harijanbandhu.
('65', 62, 0, 1, 109837) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 63
('65', 62, 1, 2, 109887) obvious, only a careful eye would notice a gradual and imperceptible evolution.
('65', 62, 1, 3, 109967) Varnashramadharma is a compound word known to all our vernaculars, and, though the word dharma (law) is related to both the components, varna and ashrama, the words are rarely used in separation.
('65', 62, 1, 4, 110163) Hinduism is but another and imperfect name for varnashramadharma.
('65', 62, 1, 5, 110229) The word ‘Hindu’ was apparently coined by foreigners and has more geographical than any other content.
('65', 62, 1, 6, 110332) The dharma (religion or law) that Hindus have professed to observe is varnashramadharma.
('65', 62, 1, 7, 110421) To say that the dharma of the Hindus is Aryan does not carry us very far.
('65', 62, 1, 8, 110495) It simply means that the Hindus, or those who lived in the east of the Indus or believed in the Vedic dharma, 1
('65', 62, 2, 9, 110607) called themselves Aryas and others non Aryas.
('65', 62, 2, 10, 110653) To give our dharma this kind of ethnic label is in my opinion misleading.
('65', 62, 2, 11, 110727) It should have a name that declares its predominant characteristic, and everyone will admit that Hinduism is nothing without the law of varna and ashrama.
('65', 62, 2, 12, 110882) It would be impossible to find any smriti of which a large part was not devoted to varnashramadharma.
('65', 62, 2, 13, 110984) This law of varna and ashrama is to be traced to our most ancient scriptures —the Vedas, and so no one who calls himself a Hindu may ignore it.
('65', 62, 2, 14, 111128) It is his duty to study it in all its bearings, and to reject it if it is an excrescence, and to foster it and restore it to its pristine purity, if it represents a universal law.
('65', 62, 2, 15, 111308) So far as the law of ashrama is concerned, it is extinct, alike in profession and observance.
('65', 62, 2, 16, 111402) Hinduism lays down four ashramas or stages—the life of a brahmachari (continent student), the life of a grihastha (householder), the life of a vanaprastha (who has retired) and the life of a sannyasi (renunciator)—through which every Hindu has to pass to fulfil his purpose in life.
('65', 62, 2, 17, 111685) But the first and the third are practically non existent today, the fourth may be said to be observed in name to a small extent.
('65', 62, 2, 18, 111814) The second is professed to be observed by all today, but it is observed in name, not in spirit.
('65', 62, 2, 19, 111910) Grihasthas or householders of a kind we all are, inasmuch as we eat and drink and propagate our kind, like all created beings.
('65', 62, 2, 20, 112037) But in doing so, we fulfil the law of the flesh and not of the spirit.
('65', 62, 2, 21, 112108) Only those married couples who fulfil the law of the spirit can be said to observe the law of grihastha ashrama.
('65', 62, 2, 22, 112221) Those who live the mere animal life do not observe the law The life of householders of today is one of indulgence And as the four stages represent a ladder of growth and
('65', 62, 3, 23, 112391) 1 The words “or believed in the Vedic dharma” are from Harijanbandhu
('65', 63, 0, 1, 112460) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 63, 1, 2, 112501) are interdependent, one cannot leap to the stage of a vanaprastha or a sannyasi, unless he or she fulfilled the law of the first two ashramas— brahmacharya and grihastha.
('65', 63, 1, 3, 112672) The law of the ashrama, therefore, is a dead letter today.
('65', 63, 1, 4, 112731) It can be revived only if the law of varna, with which it is intimately interlinked, is revived.
('65', 63, 1, 5, 112828) That brings us to a consideration of the law of varna.
('65', 63, 1, 6, 112883) Varna ‘can certainly be said to exist, though in a distorted form.
('65', 63, 1, 7, 112950) There are four varnas, but the distortion that passes as varna today is divided into countless castes.
('65', 63, 1, 8, 113053) All the four varnas are divided into numerous castes and sub castes, but Whilst those who belong to the first three are not ashamed to declare that they belong to them, those who belong to the fourth, viz., Shudra, prefer to declare the sub caste as their label rather than their varna, which they regard as a badge of humiliation.
('65', 63, 1, 9, 113385) But labels never reveal a man’s character, nor does the fact that a man clings to a label show that he deserves it.
('65', 63, 1, 10, 113501) A black man will not be red, no matter how repeatedly he calls himself red.
('65', 63, 1, 11, 113577) In the same way, one does not become a Brahmin by calling oneself a Brahmin.
('65', 63, 1, 12, 113654) Not until a man reveals in his life the attributes of a Brahmin can he deserve that name.
('65', 63, 1, 13, 113744) Considered in this light, varna may be said to be extinct.
('65', 63, 1, 14, 113803) If we may, indeed, claim a label, we can call ourselves Shudras, though really we are not entitled to that name either, inasmuch as we do not observe the law of that varna.
('65', 63, 1, 15, 113976) This law is the law of one’s being, which one has to fulfil.
('65', 63, 1, 16, 114037) The fulfilment should be spontaneous and no matter of honour or shame.
('65', 63, 1, 17, 114108) How many are there who are fulfilling the law as law, i.e, spontaneously?
('65', 63, 1, 18, 114182) We fulfil it because we cannot help it we are all serfs, whether we will it or no.
('65', 63, 1, 19, 114265) Let no one contend that varna exists today, because all the functions of the different varnas are being performed by someone or the other and somehow or the other.
('65', 63, 1, 20, 114429) Varna is intimately, if not indissolubly, connected with birth, and the observance of the law of varna means the following on the part of us all the hereditary and traditional calling of our forefathers in a spirit of duty.
('65', 63, 1, 21, 114653) Those who thus fulfil the law of their varna can be counted on one’s fingers’ ends.
('65', 63, 1, 22, 114737) This performance of one’s hereditary function is done as a matter of duty, though it naturally carries with it the earning of one’s livelihood.
('65', 63, 1, 23, 114881) Thus, the function of a Brahmin is to study and to teach the science of Brahman (or spiritual truth).
('65', 63, 1, 24, 114983) He performs the function, as he cannot do otherwise, as it is the law of his being.
('65', 63, 1, 25, 115067) That secures him his livelihood, but he will take it as a gift from God.
('65', 63, 1, 26, 115140) A Kshatriya will
('65', 64, 0, 1, 115157) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 65
('65', 64, 1, 2, 115207) perform the function of protecting the people in the same spirit, accepting for his livelihood whatever the people can afford to give him.
('65', 64, 1, 3, 115346) A Vaishya will pursue wealth producing occupations for the welfare of the community, keeping for himself enough for his own maintenance and rendering the balance to the community in one shape or another.
('65', 64, 1, 4, 115550) A Shudra will perform physical labour in the same spirit of service.
('65', 64, 1, 5, 115619) Varna is determined by birth, but can be retained only by observing its obligations.
('65', 64, 1, 6, 115704) One born of Brahmin parents will be called a Brahmin, but if his life fails to reveal the attributes of a Brahmin when he comes of age, he cannot be called a Brahmin.
('65', 64, 1, 7, 115871) He will have fallen from Brahminhood.
('65', 64, 1, 8, 115909) On the other hand, one who is born not a Brahmin but reveals in his conduct the attributes of a Brahmin will be regarded as a Brahmin, though he will himself disclaim the label.
('65', 64, 1, 9, 116087) Varna thus conceived is no man made institution but the law of life universally governing the human family.
('65', 64, 1, 10, 116195) Fulfilment of the law would make life livable, would spread peace and content, end all clashes and conflicts, put an end to starvation and pauperization, solve the problem of population and even end disease and suffering.
('65', 64, 1, 11, 116417) But if varna reveals the law of one’s being and thus the duty one has to perform, it confers no right, and the idea of superiority or inferiority is wholly repugnant to it.
('65', 64, 1, 12, 116590) All varnas are equal, for the community depends no less on one than on another.
('65', 64, 1, 13, 116670) Today varna means gradations of high and low.
('65', 64, 1, 14, 116716) It is a hideous travesty of the original.
('65', 64, 1, 15, 116758) The law of varna was discovered by our ancestors by stern austerities.
('65', 64, 1, 16, 116829) They sought to live up to the law to the best of their capacity.
('65', 64, 1, 17, 116894) We have distorted it today and have made ourselves the laughing stock of the world.
('65', 64, 1, 18, 116978) No wonder that we have today amongst the Hindus a section which is bending its energies to a destruction of the institution which in their opinion spells the ruin of the Hindus And certainly one need have no mercy for the hideous distortion, which means nothing but destruction of Hinudism.
('65', 64, 3, 19, 117269) I do not for a moment suggest that there should be no restrictions about food and drink or about marital relations.
('65', 64, 3, 20, 117385) I do not myself regard it a duty to eat whatever is offered and in whatever
('65', 64, 4, 21, 117461) 1 The Gujarati original of what follows appeared in Harijanbandhu 23 9 1934.
('65', 65, 0, 1, 117538) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 65, 1, 2, 117579) company I should chance to be, and I regard it as nothing short of self indulgence to marry according to one’s fancy.
('65', 65, 1, 3, 117697) Strict restraint is the law of life and must, therefore, govern these relations no less than others.
('65', 65, 1, 4, 117798) I hold that there are rules about diet.
('65', 65, 1, 5, 117838) Man is not an omnivorous animal, nor may he pick up his mate wherever he likes.
('65', 65, 1, 6, 117918) But restrictions on marital or social relations have nothing to do with varnadharma, which is a different thing altogether.
('65', 65, 1, 7, 118042) I can conceive blameless marital relations between different varnas, and people of different varnas seated together to eat food permissible to all.
('65', 65, 1, 8, 118190) There is evidence enough to show that in ancient times there were no watertight compartments between varnas, so far as marital and social relations went, and I have no doubt that, in making varna a mere matter of restrictions about food and drink and marriage, we have done Hinduism grave harm.
('65', 65, 1, 9, 118485) Though the law of varna is a special discovery of some Hindu seer, it has universal application.
('65', 65, 1, 10, 118582) Every religion has some distinguish ing characteristic, but if it expresses a principle or law, it ought to have universal application.
('65', 65, 1, 11, 118718) That is how I look at the law of varna.
('65', 65, 1, 12, 118758) The world may ignore it today but it will have to accept it in the time to come.
('65', 65, 1, 13, 118839) I would define the law briefly thus: The law of varna means that everyone shall follow as a matter of dharma—duty—the hereditary calling of his forefathers, in so far as it is not inconsistent with fundamental ethics.
('65', 65, 1, 14, 119057) He will earn his livelihood by following that calling.
('65', 65, 1, 15, 119112) He may not hoard riches, but devote the balance for the good of the people.
('65', 65, 1, 16, 119188) The four varnas have been compared in the Vedas to the four members of the body, and no simile could be happier.
('65', 65, 1, 17, 119301) If they are members of one body, how can one be superior or inferior to another?
('65', 65, 1, 18, 119382) If the members of the body had the power of expression and each of them were to say that it was higher and better than the rest, the body would go to pieces.
('65', 65, 1, 19, 119540) Even so, our body politic, the body of humanity, would go to pieces, if it were to perpetuate the canker of superiority or inferiority.
('65', 65, 1, 20, 119676) It is this canker that is at the root of the various ills of our time, especially class wars and civil strife.
('65', 65, 1, 21, 119787) It should not be difficult for even the meanest understanding to see that these wars and strife could not be ended except by the observance of the law of varna.
('65', 65, 1, 22, 119948) For it ordains that everyone shall fulfil the law of one’s being by doing in a spirit of duty and service that to which one is
('65', 66, 0, 1, 120075) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 67
('65', 66, 1, 2, 120125) Earning of livelihood is the necessary result.
('65', 66, 1, 3, 120172) But the law has to be fulfilled for its own sake.
('65', 66, 1, 4, 120222) Its due observance by a large part of mankind will end the conflicting inequalities and give place to an equality in diversity.
('65', 66, 1, 5, 120350) All callings would be equally reputable—whether that of the minister or of the lawyer, of the doctor or the leather worker, of the carpenter or the scavenger, of the soldier or the trader, of the farmer or the spiritual teacher.
('65', 66, 1, 6, 120579) In this ideal state of things, there would be no room for the monstrous anomaly of the three varnas lording it over the Shudra, or of the Kshatriya and the Vaishya enjoying themselves in their palaces and the Brahmin contenting himself with a cottage and the Shudra toiling for the rest and living in a hovel.
('65', 66, 1, 7, 120889) This chaotic state of things indicates that the law of varna has become a dead letter.
('65', 66, 1, 8, 120976) When, if ever, the ideal state of things, as indicated above, had been reached in India, I do not know.
('65', 66, 1, 9, 121080) But I do hold that it is the only ideal state that is easy enough to approach and that it is not only for the Hindus but for the whole of humanity.
('65', 66, 1, 10, 121228) Under such dispensation, all property will be held by its respective holders in trust for the community.
('65', 66, 1, 11, 121333) No one will claim it as his own.
('65', 66, 1, 12, 121366) The king will hold his palace in trust for his people and will collect the taxes only to be used for the benefit of the people.
('65', 66, 1, 13, 121494) He has the right to have no more than is enough to keep him, the rest belongs to, and shall be spent only for, the people.
('65', 66, 1, 14, 121617) Indeed, he will, by virtue of his resourcefulness as a ruler, add to what he collects from the people and return it to them manifold.
('65', 66, 1, 15, 121751) The Vaishya likewise is such a trustee.
('65', 66, 1, 16, 121791) The Shudra is made so.
('65', 66, 1, 17, 121814) Indeed, if one may have preference, the Shudra, who performs body labour in a spirit of service and duty, who has nothing to’ call his own and who has no desire for ownership, is worthy of the world’s homage; he is the lord of all because he is the greatest servant.
('65', 66, 1, 18, 122081) The dutiful Shudra will, of course, repudiate any such claim, but the gods will shower their choicest blessings on him.
('65', 66, 1, 19, 122201) One may not say this of the proletariat of the present day.
('65', 66, 1, 20, 122261) They certainly own nothing, but I expect they covet ownership.
('65', 66, 1, 21, 122324) The calling of labour and service is no pleasant duty to them.
('65', 66, 1, 22, 122387) It is a painful task, for it does not satisfy even the cravings of the flesh.
('65', 66, 1, 23, 122465) My praise is for the ideal labourer.
('65', 66, 1, 24, 122502) It is the estate I have longed to attain.
('65', 66, 1, 25, 122544) But this duty of labour cannot be imposed on anybody.
('65', 66, 1, 26, 122598) In fact, the panegyric may be uttered only by those of the three varnas who fulfil the law themselves, viz., the law of regarding and behaving
('65', 67, 0, 1, 122741) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 67, 1, 2, 122782) themselves as the servants of the community and holding all the property in trust for it.
('65', 67, 1, 3, 122872) The three varnas exist today only in name, they are supposed to invest one with a higher status than that of the Shudras and have ceased to imply any duty to be performed.
('65', 67, 1, 4, 123044) There is nothing, therefore, to be surprised at, nor to be sorry for, when in such a state of things the Shudras should be jealous of the others’ possessions and their estate and seek to share them.
('65', 67, 1, 5, 123243) When the law of varna was discovered, there could be no compulsion from without.
('65', 67, 1, 6, 123324) The world can only be sustained by a willing and dutiful observance of it.
('65', 67, 1, 7, 123399) In an age where competition is held to be the law of life, and possession in the largest measure of the world’s goods the summum bonum, and when everyone counts oneself free to follow any calling one likes, this attempt to hold up varna as the law of life may well be regarded as an idle dream, and an attempt to revive it as childish folly.
('65', 67, 1, 8, 123741) Be that as it may, it is my firm conviction that it is true socialism.
('65', 67, 1, 9, 123812) In the language of the Gita, it is equality of the spirit, without which no other equality is possible.
('65', 67, 1, 10, 123916) The performance of it, no matter how slight, bodes well both for him who performs it and for the rest of mankind.
('65', 67, 1, 11, 124030) I may add that, though the varnas are to be four, the number is not, in my opinion, unalterable.
('65', 67, 1, 12, 124127) In the future reconstruction, the number may be more or even less than four.
('65', 67, 1, 13, 124204) What is essential is that one must seek one’s livelihood, and no more, from following the vocation to which one is born.

('65', 67, 4, 16, 124415) 70. ‘BLESSED POVERTY’ 1
('65', 67, 5, 17, 124439) Several years ago, a close friend and associate belonging to a rich prosperous family, who had received a high degree of education and had travelled and seen much in different parts of the world, solemnly abjured the use of all vehicular and other means of transport and has ever since stuck to his resolve through all vicissitudes of weather and health.
('65', 67, 5, 18, 124794) He has kept up correspondence with me.
('65', 67, 5, 19, 124833) I have preserved one of his letters which I received during my Harijan tour,
('65', 67, 6, 20, 124910) 1 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 23 9 1934. The text reproduced here, except the last paragraph, is from the abridged version in Harijan.
('65', 68, 0, 1, 125066) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 69
('65', 68, 1, 2, 125116) in order to share it with the readers of the Harijanbandhu.
('65', 68, 1, 3, 125176) I am sure the following excerpt from it recounting some of his experiences will be appreciated by them:
('65', 68, 2, 4, 125280) Of the many vows that I took, I have found the one about travelling on foot to be the most beneficial.
('65', 68, 2, 5, 125383) It has afforded me the richest experience.
('65', 68, 2, 6, 125426) As a result of it, my faith in God today is much stronger than it was when I set out from Ahmedabad about a couple of years ago.
('65', 68, 3, 7, 125555) Having had experience of both riches and poverty, I am in a position to testify today that, whilst I have almost always found pride and licence threatening the life of the rich and whilst those who wielded authority could not without difficulty escape the intoxication of power, poverty alone left enough scope for a spontaneous and natural devotion to God, a spirit of service and the capacity to suffer and to endure.
('65', 68, 3, 8, 125975) I have now clearly realized that the state of voluntary poverty is really a blessed state and that riches, in the worldly sense, are nothing in comparison.
('65', 68, 3, 9, 126131) May God always keep me in poverty and keep me free from the slightest desire for possession or from the care for the morrow.
('65', 68, 4, 10, 126256) Everywhere I have found that men despise the sinning and the fallen, and yet who amongst us can claim to be immaculate?
('65', 68, 4, 11, 126376) I have at last grasped the great secret of shunning sin but not the sinner.
('65', 68, 4, 12, 126452) This friend has travelled on foot from Gujarat to and beyond Dehra Dun, has passed through hundreds upon hundreds of villages and come in contact with the villagers.
('65', 68, 4, 13, 126618) His testimony should, therefore, command our respect.
('65', 68, 4, 14, 126672) Kindred spirits in all climes and ages have borne similar testimony to the joy and beauty of travelling on foot and renouncing all worldly possessions.
('65', 68, 4, 15, 126824) Thoreau’s Walden in praise of walking is well known.
('65', 68, 4, 16, 126877) All the great reformers of the world who have from time to time effected religious revolutions have eschewed the use of vehicles and walked thousands of miles for delivering their mission.
('65', 68, 4, 17, 127066) Yet, by the intensity of their faith and the strength of their realization, they were able to achieve what we, in our aeroplane age, with all the gee gaws at our command, could hardly aspire to.
('65', 68, 4, 18, 127261) Not mad rush, but unperturbed calmness brings wisdom.
('65', 68, 4, 19, 127315) This maxim holds as true today as when it was first propounded ages ago.
('65', 68, 5, 20, 127388) Those who hear of this aspirant’s experience will not all take to walking nor will they pray to become poor.
('65', 68, 5, 21, 127497) Also they may not distinguish between the sin and the sinner and learn to love the sinner
('65', 68, 6, 22, 127587) 1 What follows is translated from Gujarati.
('65', 69, 0, 1, 127631) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 69, 1, 2, 127672) and abhor sin.
('65', 69, 1, 3, 127687) But it will be no mean achievement if we learn the value of this attitude and try to follow it as best as we can.
('65', 69, 1, 4, 127801) A Harijan worker at any rate ought to do nothing less than this.
('65', 69, 2, 5, 127866) Harijan, 12 10 1934, and Harijanbandhu, 23 9 1934
('65', 69, 3, 6, 127916) 71. ROBBERY IN THE NAME OF RELIGION
('65', 69, 4, 7, 127952) I give below extracts from a letter 1 which Shri Chhotalal Gandhi of Ankleshwar has written to me regarding the Harijans of Sajod.
('65', 69, 4, 8, 128083) While the wound of Talaja is still fresh, here is another.
('65', 69, 4, 9, 128142) Everywhere it is the same.
('65', 69, 4, 10, 128169) The law says that Harijan Hindus enjoy equal civil rights with caste Hindus.
('65', 69, 4, 11, 128246) Even the officials are ready to help.
('65', 69, 4, 12, 128284) But the fanatic Hindus seem to care little for the law or order of the officers.
('65', 69, 4, 13, 128365) How to overcome such utter ignorance?
('65', 69, 4, 14, 128403) Ahimsa seems defeated and love seems to dry up.
('65', 69, 4, 15, 128451) But I find the pen quoting the lines: “As long as the elephant relied on his own strength, it availed him not” and “Rama is the strength of the weak” and they comfort me.
('65', 69, 4, 16, 128622) Ahimsa is true ahimsa only if it keeps shining even in the midst of darkness all around.
('65', 69, 4, 17, 128711) The remedy for himsa is ahimsa, for hatred love and for untruth truth, as the remedy for cold is sunshine.
('65', 69, 4, 18, 128818) If there are sincere, religious minded reformers in Sajod, they are sure to win in the end.
('65', 69, 4, 19, 128910) Let the fanatic caste Hindus do as they please.
('65', 69, 4, 20, 128958) The reformers should shelter the oppressed Harijans.
('65', 69, 4, 21, 129011) They should rigidly adhere to the rule that they will refuse to avail themselves of any facility not permitted to the Harijans.
('65', 69, 4, 22, 129139) They should of course secure for the latter officers’ help whenever necessary.
('65', 69, 4, 23, 129218) They should plead with the caste Hindus to keep within proper limits.
('65', 69, 4, 24, 129288) Let the orthodox Hindus take bath or do any other expiation if the Harijans exercise their rights and enter a public place.
('65', 69, 4, 25, 129412) The Shastras do not enjoin punishment of the Harijans.
('65', 69, 4, 26, 129467) They only say that anybody who regards himself polluted should take a bath.
('65', 69, 4, 27, 129543) No Shastra suggests that we should harass or beat the person by whom we regard ourselves polluted.
('65', 69, 4, 28, 129642) This is so simple a thing that the reformers should have confidence in themselves and, keeping within the bounds of ahimsa, go on doing their duty.
('65', 69, 4, 29, 129790) The suggestion to send some well known public worker to Sajod

('65', 69, 5, 31, 129875) It described the harassment of Harijans in Sajod, in Ankleshwar taluka, consequent on the insistence of the authorities that the Harijan pupils in the local school should be permitted to sit with the other pupils.

('65', 79, 0, 1, 143548) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 79, 1, 2, 143589) I do not see any harm in accepting a maintenance allowance from your brothers.
('65', 79, 1, 3, 143668) You cannot but accept it from some source or the other if you devote all your time to serving.
('65', 79, 1, 4, 143763) As your brothers cannot render service themselves there is nothing surprising if they supported one who wishes to serve; it will be a noble act.
('65', 79, 1, 5, 143908) So far you could be said to have been observing aparigraha 1. But accumulating the amount in balance is as good as stealing and outright possession.
('65', 79, 1, 6, 144057) What can a really poor man do for his friends?
('65', 79, 1, 7, 144104) Should he steal and give them money?
('65', 79, 1, 8, 144141) This is not friendship but enmity which you are practising.
('65', 79, 1, 9, 144201) Why should you not announce to all your friends that you are no more a Chandiwala 2 but only a poor servant.
('65', 79, 1, 10, 144310) Their friendship will be proved true if they remain your friends even in your poverty.
('65', 79, 1, 11, 144397) Have you any idea how you and they became friends?
('65', 79, 1, 12, 144448) You had money and they squandered it right and left.

('65', 79, 1, 14, 144560) At any rate, this is my reading.

('65', 82, 6, 8, 148513) MY DEAR AMRITLAL,
('65', 82, 7, 9, 148531) With reference to our conversation of yesterday, I know that my letters and my talks about the Congress attitude in respect of the Princes and the people of the Indian States have given rise to some misunderstanding.
('65', 82, 7, 10, 148748) It surprises me that anybody should think that I do not consider them to be an integral part of the Indian nation.
('65', 82, 7, 11, 148863) Of course they are, even as Indians residing in the other parts of geographical India are.
('65', 82, 7, 12, 148954) Though we are under different systems of Government, surely we are one.
('65', 82, 7, 13, 149026) I was also surprised to be told by you that some persons attribute to me the opinion that people of the Indian States who are members of the Congress are so by sufference.
('65', 82, 7, 14, 149198) There is a definite provision in the Congress constitution for their being enrolled as members, and those who subscribe to the Congress objective and carry out the other rules governing the membership have as much right to be enrolled as members as any other Indian.
('65', 82, 8, 15, 149465) Yours sincerely, SHRI AMRITLAL D. SHETH (CAMP) WARDHA

('65', 85, 3, 6, 151850) I was certainly shocked to hear this.
('65', 85, 3, 7, 151888) I felt that it was wrong for a person like you, who had taken so much interest in khadi, to own a cotton mill; but I could not decide whether I should write to you.
