('65', 86, 5, 22, 154554) 100. DISCUSSION ON SWADESHI 2
('65', 86, 6, 23, 154584) [Before September 28, 1934]
('65', 86, 7, 24, 154612) Q. How does this new swadeshi differ from the old?
('65', 86, 8, 25, 154663) A. The old emphasized the indigenous nature of the products, irrespective of the method or the produce or the prospects of the product.
('65', 86, 8, 26, 154799) I have ruled out organized industries, not because they are not swadeshi, but because they do not need special support.
('65', 86, 8, 27, 154919) They can stand on their own legs and, in the present state of our awakening, can easily command a market.
('65', 86, 8, 28, 155025) According to the new orientation, if it is new, I would certainly have our swadeshi organization to seek out all village industries and find how they are faring.
('65', 86, 8, 29, 155187) We will have experts and chemists who will be prepared to place their knowledge at the disposal of villagers.
('65', 86, 8, 30, 155297) We will, through our experts, offer to test the
('65', 86, 9, 31, 155345) 1 Omission as in the source 2 This appeared under the title “More Talks on Swadeshi”.
('65', 86, 9, 32, 155431) Mahadev Desai has summarized here the discussion Gandhiji had with a number of persons.
('65', 87, 0, 1, 155519) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 87, 1, 2, 155560) articles manufactured by village handicraftsmen and give them suggestions to improve their wares and would sell them if they would accept our conditions.
('65', 87, 2, 3, 155714) Q. Would you take up any and every handicraft?
('65', 87, 3, 4, 155761) A. Not necessarily.
('65', 87, 3, 5, 155781) I should examine each one of them, find out their place in the economy of the village life and, if I see that they must be encouraged because of inherent merit, I should do so.
('65', 87, 3, 6, 155958) Now, for instance, I should be loath to allow the village broom to be replaced by the modern broomstick or brush.
('65', 87, 3, 7, 156072) I would ask Mrs. Gandhi and other women of the household to tell me about the relative merits of both.
('65', 87, 3, 8, 156175) Mind you, I would consider the advantages from all points of view.
('65', 87, 3, 9, 156242) Thus, the village broom, I should think; must be preferred because it indicates tenderness and kindness to small life, whereas the brush makes a clean sweep of those things.
('65', 87, 3, 10, 156416) Thus, I should see a whole philosophy behind the broom, for I do not think the Creator makes any distinction between minute insects and (in His estimation) minute men.
('65', 87, 3, 11, 156584) Thus I should pick up all kinds of village crafts and industries which are about to die and deserve revival, both because of their intrinsic merit and their other useful aspects, and I should thus go on making discoveries.
('65', 87, 3, 12, 156807) Take our trifling tooth sticks, for instance.
('65', 87, 3, 13, 156853) I am quite sure, if you were to deprive the bulk of the Bombay citizens of their tooth sticks, their teeth would suffer.
('65', 87, 3, 14, 156974) I cannot contemplate with equanimity the modern tooth brush replacing the tooth stick.
('65', 87, 3, 15, 157061) These brushes are unhygienic.
('65', 87, 3, 16, 157091) Once used, they deserve to be thrown away.
('65', 87, 3, 17, 157134) However much disinfectants you may use to sterilize them, they can never be as good as fresh ones.
('65', 87, 3, 18, 157233) But the babul or neem tooth stick is used once for all and has highly astringent properties.
('65', 87, 3, 19, 157326) Again, it serves the purpose of a tongue scraper.
('65', 87, 3, 20, 157376) The West has yet to discover anything so hygienic as the Indian tooth stick.
('65', 87, 3, 21, 157453) You may not know that a doctor in South Africa claimed to have controlled tuberculosis among the Bantu miners by insisting on the regular use by them of these tooth sticks.
('65', 87, 3, 22, 157626) I would be no party to the advertisement of modern tooth brushes even when they are made in India.
('65', 87, 3, 23, 157725) I should declare my preference for the tooth stick.
('65', 87, 3, 24, 157777) This is cent per cent swadeshi.
('65', 87, 3, 25, 157809) If I take care of it, the rest will take care of itself.
('65', 87, 3, 26, 157866) Ask me to define the right angle and I should do it easily, but do not ask me to define the angles between the acutest and the most obtuse you can make.
('65', 87, 3, 27, 158019) If I have the definition of a right angle, I can make whatever angle I need.
('65', 88, 0, 1, 158096) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 89
('65', 88, 1, 2, 158146) swadeshi is eloquent enough as its own definition, I have called mine cent per cent swadeshi, because swadeshi is in danger of being watered down.
('65', 88, 1, 3, 158293) Cent per cent swadeshi gives sufficient scope for the most insatiable ambition for service and can satisfy every kind of talent.
('65', 88, 2, 4, 158422) Q. You see swaraj at the end of it?
('65', 88, 2, 5, 158458) A. Why not?
('65', 88, 2, 6, 158470) Once I said in spinning whcel lies swaraj, next I said in prohibition lies swaraj.
('65', 88, 2, 7, 158553) In the same way I would say in cent per cent swadeshi lies swaraj.
('65', 88, 2, 8, 158620) Of course, it is like the blind men describing the elephant.
('65', 88, 2, 9, 158681) All of them are right and yet not wholly right.
('65', 88, 2, 10, 158729) If we tap all our resources, I am quite sure we can be again the richest country in the world, which we were, I suppose, at one time.
('65', 88, 2, 11, 158863) We can repeat the phenomenon, if we cease to be idle and profitably occupy the idle hours of the millions.
('65', 88, 2, 12, 158970) All we need is to be industrious, not like a machine, but like the busy bee.
('65', 88, 2, 13, 159047) You know I am now advertising what I call ‘‘innocent honey”?
('65', 88, 3, 14, 159108) Q. What is that?
('65', 88, 4, 15, 159125) A. Honey scientifically drawn by scientific bee keepers.
('65', 88, 4, 16, 159182) They keep the bees and make them collect honey without killing them.
('65', 88, 4, 17, 159251) That is why I call it innocent or non violent honey.
('65', 88, 4, 18, 159304) That is an industry which admits of great expansion.
('65', 88, 5, 19, 159357) Q. But can you call it absolutely non violent?
('65', 88, 5, 20, 159404) You deprive the bee of its honey, as you deprive the calf of its milk.
('65', 88, 6, 21, 159475) A. You are right, but the world is not governed entirely by logic.
('65', 88, 6, 22, 159542) Life itself involves some kind of violence, and we have to choose the path of least violence.
('65', 88, 6, 23, 159636) There is violence even in vegetarianism, is there not?
('65', 88, 6, 24, 159691) Similarly, if I must have honey, I must be friendly to the bee and get it to yield as much honey as it will.
('65', 88, 6, 25, 159800) Moreover, in the scientific bee culture, the bee is never deprived of its honey altogether.
('65', 88, 7, 26, 159892) Harijan, 28 9 1934
('65', 88, 8, 27, 159911) 101. SOME CONUNDRUMS
('65', 88, 9, 28, 159932) A Brahmin of Mithila writes a long letter in Hindi, but wants a reply in the English Harijan.
('65', 88, 9, 29, 160026) From his style I can quite clearly see that he knows English well.
('65', 88, 9, 30, 160093) His letter contains questions of universal importance.
('65', 88, 9, 31, 160148) The original is being sent to the editor of Harijan Sevak.
('65', 88, 9, 32, 160207) I gladly give below the substance of the letter.
('65', 88, 9, 33, 160256) The correspondent belongs to an orthodox family, but has shed
('65', 89, 0, 1, 160318) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 89, 1, 2, 160359) all prejudice against Harijans and permits all but those who are manifestly unclean, such as unwashed Doms, to draw water from a well which has hitherto been open only to the so called high class Hindus.
('65', 89, 1, 3, 160563) He says:
('65', 89, 2, 4, 160572) 1. Why don’t you preach to Harijans cleanliness, abstention from carrion eating and the like, just as you preach to caste Hindus removal of untouchability?
('65', 89, 2, 5, 160728) 2. What is the distinguishing characteristic of a sanatani ‘Hindu?, Why do you claim to be a sanatani Hindu?
('65', 89, 2, 6, 160837) 3. You have said that, when a man forsakes his hereditary calling, he creates confusion of caste.
('65', 89, 2, 7, 160935) How far is this consistent with the meaning inferable from the use of the expression 1 in the first chapter of the Gita?
('65', 89, 2, 8, 161056) 4. What have you to say to the verses in the smritis on the marriage of a Brahmin woman with a Shudra man?
('65', 89, 2, 9, 161163) 5. You say there is no superiority or inferiority among the four varnas.
('65', 89, 2, 10, 161236) I believe in what you say, but is it consistent with many texts one can quote from the Shastras which clearly enunciate the opposite?
('65', 89, 2, 11, 161370) See what the smritis have to say of Shudras.
('65', 89, 2, 12, 161415) 6. You say that varna or caste is determined generally by birth.
('65', 89, 2, 13, 161480) You also say that a Brahmin who does not show in his conduct the marks of one falls.
('65', 89, 2, 14, 161565) To what varna does he belong?
('65', 89, 2, 15, 161595) What about a Shudra who shows the mark of a Brahmin?
('65', 89, 2, 16, 161648) 7. It is said that a man becomes what he eats and that he is corrupted if he takes food or even water prepared or even touched by a corrupt person.
('65', 89, 2, 17, 161796) And you say that prohibition against inter dining is not an integral part of varna or caste rule.
('65', 89, 2, 18, 161894) Is that so?
('65', 89, 2, 19, 161906) 8. When workers like me work against untouchability, sanatanist opponents say all sorts of things against you.
('65', 89, 2, 20, 162017) We combat most things.
('65', 89, 2, 21, 162040) But your having taken the life of the dying calf in the Ashram we have not been able to explain.
('65', 89, 2, 22, 162137) Are you able to throw light on this question?
('65', 89, 3, 23, 162183) The original letter is well reasoned and is written with a pure motive.
('65', 89, 3, 24, 162255) I don’t know if I have, in the process of condensation, done
('65', 89, 4, 25, 162316) 1 Bhagavad Gita, I. 41
('65', 90, 0, 1, 162339) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 91
('65', 90, 1, 2, 162389) justice to the spirit in which the original has been written.
('65', 90, 1, 3, 162451) If I have not, the correspondent should know that the injustice is wholly unintended.
('65', 90, 1, 4, 162537) Now for the reply.
('65', 90, 1, 5, 162556) 1. I do preach to the Harijans cleanliness, abstention from carrion eating and intoxicating drinks and drugs, necessity.
('65', 90, 1, 6, 162677) Of taking education themselves and giving it to their children, also abstention from eating the leavings from caste Hindus’ plates, etc.
('65', 90, 1, 7, 162814) Only, I do not put these before Harijans as condition precedent to the removal of untouchability.
('65', 90, 1, 8, 162912) On the contrary, I suggest to caste Hindus that the shortcomings are not inherent in Harijans but that they are due to our criminal neglect of—even deliberate suppression of—these brethren of ours.
('65', 90, 1, 9, 163110) Therefore, the disappearance of these shortcomings will take place sooner for our fraternizing with Harijans even as they are and then helping them to become better men and women.
('65', 90, 1, 10, 163290) That is the least penance caste Hindus can do for the past wrongs.
('65', 90, 1, 11, 163357) We must approach Harijans as penitents or debtors, not as their patrons or creditors extending generosity to the undeserving.
('65', 90, 1, 12, 163483) 2. Belief in, and practice of, varnashrama dharma may be said to be the distinguishing characteristic of Hindu dharma.
('65', 90, 1, 13, 163602) The translation appearing in this Harijan of a Gujarati preface 1 I have written for a collection of my writings on the subject explains what I mean by varnashrama dharma.
('65', 90, 1, 14, 163774) I regard myself a sanatani Hindu, because I try to the best of my ability to obey the eternal precepts of the faith as embodied in the Shastras as I understand them.
('65', 90, 1, 15, 163940) 3. That a person creates confusion of caste when he leaves his hereditary calling is obvious.
('65', 90, 1, 16, 164034) When a Brahmin begins to earn his bread by, say, following the profession of a barber or engineer, he does create confusion of caste, as much as when a barber or an engineer begins to impart religious instruction as a means of livelihood.
('65', 90, 1, 17, 164273) In the Gita, the adjective used in reference to women is ‘wicked’.
('65', 90, 1, 18, 164340) It has, therefore, reference probably to promiscuous intercourse rather than the offspring born of the sacred tie of marriage.
('65', 90, 1, 19, 164467) 4. I do not regard as revelation the collection of verses printed under one cover as smritis.
('65', 90, 1, 20, 164561) I have no doubt that there are many interpolations in the smritis and other scriptural books.
('65', 90, 1, 21, 164655) As I have said often enough in these columns, I reject as interpolations everything in the smritis or other writings that is inconsistent with truth and non violence or other fundamental and universal principles of ethics.
('65', 90, 2, 22, 164878) 1 Vide “ Introduction to Varnavyavastha”, 23 9 1934.
('65', 91, 0, 1, 164931) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 91, 1, 2, 164972) There is abundant testimony in the ancient writings to show that such marriages were permitted.
('65', 91, 1, 3, 165068) 5. This question is answered in the answer to the fourth question.
('65', 91, 1, 4, 165135) The idea of superiority and inferiority is repugnant to the most elementary principles of morality.
('65', 91, 1, 5, 165235) A Brahmin who considers himself superior to any single creature of God ceases to be a knower of Brahma.
('65', 91, 1, 6, 165339) If we are children of the same God, how can there be any rank among us?
('65', 91, 1, 7, 165411) The very first mention of varna in the Vedas likens the four varnas to the four main parts of the body.
('65', 91, 1, 8, 165515) Is the head superior to the arms, the belly and the feet, or the feet superior to the other three?
('65', 91, 1, 9, 165614) What will happen to the body, if these members began a quarrel about rank?
('65', 91, 1, 10, 165689) The law of varna is one of absolute equality among all the creatures of God.
('65', 91, 1, 11, 165766) It is the basis of all the religions of the world.
('65', 91, 1, 12, 165817) The verses in the smritis about Shudras deserve to be summarily rejected as being contrary to the spirit of humanity.
('65', 91, 1, 13, 165935) 6. Both the Brahmin and the Shudra who forsake their svadharma are fallen.
('65', 91, 1, 14, 166010) In their fallen state, they belong to no varna.
('65', 91, 1, 15, 166058) They can repair their mistake by resuming svadharma—their own calling.
('65', 91, 1, 16, 166129) 7. It is insolence for any person to regard a fellow being as corrupt and, therefore, untouchable.
('65', 91, 1, 17, 166228) A man is corrupted by harbouring corrupt thoughts, making corrupt speech and doing corrupt acts, never by taking water or food at the hygienically clean hands of fellow beings.
('65', 91, 1, 18, 166405) I do believe that a man has to choose the ingredients of the food he eats.
('65', 91, 1, 19, 166480) 8. Workers must not seek to defend me against aspersions nor resent them.
('65', 91, 1, 20, 166554) They are the common lot of reformers.
('65', 91, 1, 21, 166592) Aspersions have never hurt any person in the world.
('65', 91, 1, 22, 166644) What hurts is the wicked thing a man does.
('65', 91, 1, 23, 166687) Workers have enough on their hands in having to defend the cause they have taken up.
('65', 91, 1, 24, 166772) I have no sense of shame or repentance over the taking of the life of the dying calf, whose agony I could see but could not alleviate in any other manner.
('65', 91, 1, 25, 166927) I must not dwell here on the ethics of the act.
('65', 91, 1, 26, 166975) If the correspondent or any reader is curious about it, he must procure the writings 1 in Young India and Navajivan of the time when the act was performed.
('65', 91, 2, 27, 167131) Harijan, 28 9 1934
('65', 91, 3, 28, 167150) 1 Vide “The Fiery Ordeal”, 4 10 1928; “The Tangle of ahimsa”, 11 10 1928; “A conundrum”, 18 10 1928; “Jain ahimsa”,25 10 1928 and “More about ahimsa”, 1 11 1928.

('65', 97, 7, 11, 173712) I think it my duty to let you know what I have told him in reply.

('65', 97, 7, 17, 174309) I am doing you no injustice by writing this.

('65', 98, 5, 19, 175955) Let the Harijan men and women help them with courage and fearlessness.

('65', 98, 5, 24, 176321) They apprehend more harassment if they gave evidence.
('65', 98, 5, 25, 176375) Nor is their apprehension without a ground.
('65', 98, 5, 26, 176419) That is why those Harijans who are prepared to testify to harassment deserve to be complimented.
('65', 98, 5, 27, 176516) It is certain that such harassment is not going to last long, because, on the one hand, caste Hindus are becoming more and more aware of their duty towards Harijans, and, on the other, Harijans are becoming more

('65', 99, 1, 3, 176939) God always takes the side of justice.
('65', 99, 1, 4, 176977) With this faith, let Harijans and caste reformers continue to do their duties.
('65', 99, 2, 5, 177056) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 30 9 1934
('65', 99, 3, 6, 177097) 116. SHUDRA BY CHOICE
('65', 99, 4, 7, 177119) A co worker has sent a few questions regarding the varna system out of which I propose to take up only one.
('65', 99, 4, 8, 177227) The question can be thus put in my own words:
('65', 99, 5, 9, 177273) Since you are running after varnadharma please solve some of my problems if you can.
('65', 99, 5, 10, 177358) The Gita describes agriculture, animal husbandry and commerce as the natural functions of the Vaishyas.
('65', 99, 5, 11, 177462) Commerce means selling by one person to another goods produced by a third.
('65', 99, 5, 12, 177537) Or, the seller may produce the goods himself.
('65', 99, 5, 13, 177583) The number of people engaged in agriculture and animal husbandry runs into crores.
('65', 99, 5, 14, 177666) Even so Bharwads 1, Mochis 2, Chamars, and [some] peasants are today regarded as Shudras, whereas according to the definition given above they ought to be all regarded as Vaishyas.
('65', 99, 5, 15, 177847) In my view and yours all the four varnas should be looked upon as equal, living humbly on the same level, not mounted on one another,s shoulders arrogantly crushing those below them.
('65', 99, 5, 16, 178030) But we know our society has a different opinion.
('65', 99, 5, 17, 178079) In these circumstances why should not such peasants, Bharwads, Chamars, etc., as are not employed as labourers but earn their liveli hood by their own independent effort be regarded as Vaishyas?
('65', 99, 5, 18, 178274) The peasant tends his own farm,
('65', 99, 6, 19, 178306) Bharwads and Chamars engage in animal husbandry.
('65', 99, 6, 20, 178355) They are not anybody’s servants.
('65', 99, 6, 21, 178388) If we do not accept them as cattle breeders, then they are traders, in so far as they themselves sell what they produce.
('65', 99, 6, 22, 178509) In no way can they be covered by the definition of a Shudra.
('65', 99, 6, 23, 178570) On the contrary, why isn’t anybody who is a servant a Shudra— whether he is judge or governor, soldier or scavenger?
('65', 99, 7, 24, 178687) 1 Shepherds 2 Cobblers
('65', 100, 0, 1, 178710) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 101
('65', 100, 1, 2, 178759) These complications are real.
('65', 100, 1, 3, 178789) They crop up because the varna system has broken down.
('65', 100, 1, 4, 178844) The solution does not lie in regarding shepherds, etc., as Vaishyas.
('65', 100, 1, 5, 178913) Would the proud Vaishyas admit in their supposedly exclusive varna those who are regarded as Shudras?
('65', 100, 1, 6, 179015) The above argument is no doubt convincing.
('65', 100, 1, 7, 179058) But justice cannot be administered just by a convincing argument.
('65', 100, 1, 8, 179124) For administering justice one has to reach the bottom and it can be reached only through experience.
('65', 100, 1, 9, 179225) Experience tells us that the varna system has been wiped out.
('65', 100, 1, 10, 179287) So, for the restoration of varnadharma we must all voluntarily become Shudras.
('65', 100, 1, 11, 179366) Of course we are Shudras but only because we cannot help it.
('65', 100, 1, 12, 179427) But there is no merit in an act done out of helplessness.
('65', 100, 1, 13, 179485) It is no act of merit, if I give a few coins to somebody out of compulsion.
('65', 100, 1, 14, 179561) But if I give willingly what I have hitherto given out of compulsion, it would be such an act.
('65', 100, 1, 15, 179656) The same is true of the Shudra varna.
('65', 100, 1, 16, 179694) He who realizes this may belong to any so called higher varna but by considering himself a Shudra he makes a beginning of the restoration of the varna system.
('65', 100, 1, 17, 179853) Let us consider its implications.
('65', 100, 1, 18, 179887) One who has become a Shudra by choice would serve others as a matter of dharma.
('65', 100, 1, 19, 179967) He may or may not earn his livelihood, but with pure heart would devote himself body and mind to service.
('65', 100, 1, 20, 180073) He would purposely restrict himself to marrying amongst and dining with such of the so called Shudras who follow the rules regarding personal cleanliness, etc.
('65', 100, 1, 21, 180233) He would completely identify himself with the class regarded as Shudra.
('65', 100, 1, 22, 180305) He would accept their poverty as far as possible.
('65', 100, 1, 23, 180355) He would try to help them get over their weaknesses.
('65', 100, 1, 24, 180408) Such a Shudra in spite of his possessing spiritual knowledge of a Brahmin, the fortitude of a Kshatriya and the business acumen of a Vaishya would earn his bread only through his service.
('65', 100, 1, 25, 180596) In the varna system each varna may follow the good points of all the four varnas.
('65', 100, 1, 26, 180678) It ought to be so.
('65', 100, 1, 27, 180697) For instance, the smriti enjoins: “Do not kill.
('65', 100, 1, 28, 180745) Speak the Truth.
('65', 100, 1, 29, 180762) Do not steal.
('65', 100, 1, 30, 180776) Follow the path of sanctity.
('65', 100, 1, 31, 180805) Control your sense organs.
('65', 100, 1, 32, 180832) This in brief is the dharma Manu has prescribed for all the four varnas.” (1) Or, “Do not kill.
('65', 100, 1, 33, 180928) Speak the Truth.
('65', 100, 1, 34, 180945) Do not steal.
('65', 100, 1, 35, 180959) Do not yield to desire, anger, greed and be loving and good for all living creatures.
('65', 100, 1, 36, 181045) This dharma is common to all the four varnas”.
('65', 100, 1, 37, 181092) (2) Hence, what distinguishes one varna from another is that its
('65', 101, 0, 1, 181157) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 101, 1, 2, 181199) special characteristics are conspicuously developed in its case and through them alone should the particular varna earn its livelihood.

('65', 101, 4, 5, 181376) 117. NOTES
('65', 101, 5, 6, 181387) AN ODIOUS PRACTICE1
('65', 101, 6, 7, 181407) A friend 2 from Dholka writes: In the voters’ rolls for the Municipal, the Local Boards’ and the Councils’ elections that are being published at present, the names of franchise holders, when they happen to be common folk, are, instead of being put down in full, recorded in an abbrevated form.
('65', 101, 6, 8, 181701) This is, especially in the case of Harijans, an insult to the holders of the names.
('65', 101, 6, 9, 181785) As I perused these lists in the papers, I felt that this was an uncalled for and gratuitous, though unintended, insult to the Harijans which must be stopped.
('65', 101, 6, 10, 181943) I discussed this question with the Assistant Collector in charge of Dholka taluka.
('65', 101, 6, 11, 182026) I understand that instructions have been given to the Talatis in this taluka to reocrd the names of Harijans in full.
('65', 101, 6, 12, 182144) But in other places the odious practice remains in force.
('65', 101, 6, 13, 182202) What is wanted is a general declaration of the official policy in this respect.
('65', 101, 6, 14, 182282) This might at first sight appear to be a trifling matter.
('65', 101, 6, 15, 182340) But it has significance.
('65', 101, 6, 16, 182365) I have no doubt in my mind that the contemptuous way in which these people are treated in their daily intercourse is in some measure aggravated by this practice.
('65', 101, 6, 17, 182527) The correspondent is certainly right.
('65', 101, 6, 18, 182565) By itself the matter might seem to be trivial, but it is one more instance of arrogation of caste superiority.
('65', 101, 6, 19, 182676) It does, therefore, call for prompt attention.
('65', 101, 6, 20, 182723) Apart from injuring Harijan feelings, the use of undignified nicknames in voters’ lists scarecely does credit to our good taste.
('65', 101, 6, 21, 182852) Let us hop that all those who have the service of the Harijans at heart will henceforth scrupulously eschew this objectionable practice and that the authorities will lose no time in taking the necessary steps to discontinue it in the course of administrative routine.
('65', 101, 7, 22, 183120) Harijan, 12 10 1934
('65', 101, 8, 23, 183140) 1 The gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 30 9 1934. 2 Dahyabhai M. Patel

('65', 110, 4, 9, 194225) Bapu” 1
('65', 110, 5, 10, 194233) I woke up at 2.30 and started thinking about my dharma towards you.
('65', 110, 5, 11, 194301) I couldn’t go to sleep again and left the bed at 2.45. After cleaning my teeth and drinking warm water with honey, I have set down to write this.
('65', 110, 5, 12, 194447) I want the loan which Narandas may give you to be debited to his private account.
('65', 110, 5, 13, 194529) Till I am quite sure, I do not wish to draw your expenses from a public fund or secure them from friends in public life.
('65', 110, 5, 14, 194650) It would be compromising dharma to do so.
('65', 110, 5, 15, 194692) I do not yet believe in your regeneration.
('65', 110, 5, 16, 194735) I must have independent proof of that.
('65', 110, 5, 17, 194774) I, therefore, do not wish to ask you for an assurance to that effect.
('65', 110, 5, 18, 194844) However, I wish to assure myself through your conduct.
('65', 110, 5, 19, 194899) If you have produced a good impression on Ishvarlal with whom you are staying, ask him to write to me.

('65', 110, 5, 21, 195063) 1. Have you touched liquor any time after you wrote your first letter to me from there?
('65', 110, 5, 22, 195151) 2. Have you indulged in sexual pleasure through mind, speech or body?
('65', 110, 5, 23, 195221) 3. Do you smoke?
('65', 110, 5, 24, 195238) 4. Have you any other addiction?
('65', 110, 5, 25, 195271) Let there be this understanding between you and me.
('65', 110, 5, 26, 195323) If at any time you break your word to me or if it is proved that you have deceived me, I should fast for at least seven days.
('65', 110, 5, 27, 195449) I may fast even longer, if I wish and have the strength to do so, in case your breach of promise or misdeed pains me very much.
('65', 110, 5, 28, 195577) Though I was still hopeful about you, I had hardened my heart to stone and did not give you any monetary help.

('65', 125, 6, 19, 218198) CHIMODE’S WADA VEGETABLE MARKET AMRAOTI
('65', 125, 7, 20, 218238) [From Gujarati]
('65', 125, 8, 21, 218254) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('65', 125, 8, 22, 218300) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('65', 125, 9, 23, 218324) 159. NEED FOR EXACTNESS
('65', 125, 10, 24, 218348) A correspondent sends a newspaper cutting containing a notice in praise of khadi.
('65', 125, 10, 25, 218430) From it I take the following relevant paragraphs:
('65', 125, 11, 26, 218480) A rupee spent on foreign cloth means one anna and a half to Indians, while annas fourteen plus half an anna go direct into foreign trade’s growth.
('65', 125, 12, 27, 218627) A rupee spent on mill cloth means half the amount for the mill owner,
('65', 125, 13, 28, 218697) 1 Literally, ‘age’.
('65', 125, 13, 29, 218717) The analogy is of the four yugas of Hindu mythology representing progressive physical and moral deterioration in the people during each succeeding age.
('65', 125, 13, 30, 218869) 2 Illegible in the source
('65', 126, 0, 1, 218895) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 127
('65', 126, 1, 2, 218944) annas six to instruments of production and two annas into foreigners’ pockets.
('65', 126, 2, 3, 219023) A rupee spent on khadi means the whole of the amount minus management expenses—one anna—to the producer alone.
('65', 126, 3, 4, 219134) The sender asks if it is true that every rupee invested in khadi means fifteen annas going to the producers and only one anna going to the salesmen.
('65', 126, 3, 5, 219283) I can only answer that the ideal set before the managers in charge of the A. I. S. A. stores is that the prices should be so regulated as to show on the total sales a surplus, in order to cover expenses, of one anna for every fifteen annas worth of khadi received from the producing depot.
('65', 126, 3, 6, 219573) The fifteen annas will, therefore, include several other items, e.g., freight, etc.
('65', 126, 3, 7, 219657) Hence it is altogether wrong to say that of every rupee invested in khadi fifteen annas go to the producer.
('65', 126, 3, 8, 219765) After khadi leaves the weavers’ hands, it undergoes many processes—washing, dyeing, calendaring, storing in intermediate depots and so on.
('65', 126, 3, 9, 219904) If the term ‘producer’ is confined to the grower, the picker, the ginner, the carder, the sliver maker, the spinner, the bobbin winder, the warper, the sizer and the weaver, but not the workers of the processes after weaving, the producer gets probably no more than eight annas in the rupee.
('65', 126, 3, 10, 220196) It is usual and proper to exclude the other processes, as they are not necessary for fulfilling the purpose of khadi and may or may not have been done by villagers or workers properly so called.
('65', 126, 3, 11, 220391) Washing, dyeing, etc., are often done through organized, i.e., capitalist concerns.
('65', 126, 3, 12, 220475) Now, all those who contribute to the increase in the selling price of khadi do not divide the wages .with the producer, in other words, do not take the bread out of the mouth of the producer, but help him to find a market for his manufacture, and this they do even when they are capitalist concerns.
('65', 126, 3, 13, 220775) For, the latter do not at present work for their profit, but work, no matter from what motive, for the sake of the producer.
('65', 126, 3, 14, 220900) Therefore the whole truth seems to me to be more conducive to the advertisement of khadi than the undoubted, though unconscious or ignorant, exaggeration in the noti ce under discussion.
('65', 126, 3, 15, 221087) If I was the draftsman of the notice, I should say: ‘When you buy a rupee worth of khadi, know that the producer retains the full fruit of his labour, whereas, when you buy cloth manufactured by indigenous mills, you wholly deprive him of that beneficial labour, without providing him with a substitute.
('65', 126, 3, 16, 221391) The agency
('65', 127, 0, 1, 221402) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 127, 1, 2, 221444) that sells khadi gets nothing but the bare living expenses and is, therefore, on a par with the therefore, Thus it will be found that a critical study of the economics of khadi will show that it is a crime against semi starved humanity for any Indian to use any cloth but khadi.
('65', 127, 1, 3, 221723) Such a person takes a morsel out of the mouth of some already famishing villager.
('65', 127, 1, 4, 221805) Khadi suffers, not because of any intrinsic defect; it suffers because of the ignorance of its friends and foes alike.
('65', 127, 1, 5, 221924) But it is necessary to examine the buyer’s case.
('65', 127, 1, 6, 221973) The advertise ment is misleading from his viewpoint.
('65', 127, 1, 7, 222026) Khadi will sell at half the present price, if he will revise his taste, i.e., if he will buy unbleached khadi and put all the ornamentation he likes, afterwards.
('65', 127, 1, 8, 222188) He need not bother his head about it, if the cost is no consideration.
('65', 127, 1, 9, 222259) But let the buyer to whom cost is a consideration know that he pays much less for unbleached and unadorned khadi than for prepared and bleached khadi.
('65', 127, 1, 10, 222410) Moreover, unbleached khadi lasts longer than bleached.
('65', 127, 1, 11, 222465) The public should also know that during the past twelve years khadi has become much cheaper and better in texture.
('65', 127, 1, 12, 222580) It has put more money into the pockets of the individual spinners by improving their tools and increasing their skill.
('65', 127, 1, 13, 222699) This could not have happened, if some educated men and women had not dedicated themselves to the task of helping the semi starved but partially employed millions.
('65', 127, 1, 14, 222862) The one key industry of India which supplemented the agricultural labour would never have died, if the distorted notion of varna or caste had not regarded these millions almost as untouchables, beneath the notice of the self styled higher class.
('65', 127, 1, 15, 223108) No doubt there are defects in the khadi organizations: there is not complete dedication, there is not enough critical study of every problem that demands a solution.
('65', 127, 1, 16, 223274) But this is not a matter of surprise.
('65', 127, 1, 17, 223312) We cannot, in a moment, get rid of habits of a lifetime.
('65', 127, 1, 18, 223369) We cannot, all of a sudden, develop the cunning of the hands The science of khadi requires technical and mechanical skill of a high order and demands as much concentration as is given by SirJ.
('65', 127, 1, 19, 223562) C. Bose to the tiny leaves of plants in his laboratory before he wrests from them the secrets of nature held by these fellow creatures of ours.
('65', 127, 1, 20, 223706) What is then wrong with the notice complained of is not its over valuation of khadi but its clumsy and inadequate presentation of its case.
('65', 127, 1, 21, 223846) And this comes from want of exactness due to inadequate appreciation of truth.
('65', 127, 1, 22, 223925) Every one of the three paragraphs hopelessly fails when tested on that infallible anvil.
('65', 127, 2, 23, 224014) Harijan, 5 10 1934
('65', 128, 0, 1, 224033) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 129

('65', 129, 6, 13, 226040) 163. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('65', 129, 7, 14, 226070) October 5, 1934
('65', 129, 8, 15, 226086) JAMNALAL, I got your letters.
('65', 129, 8, 16, 226116) I am glad that you have saved yourself from the unhappy business of buying a mill.
('65', 129, 8, 17, 226199) The effect which the fear of that tiger had on the minds of Janakimaiya and the children was a fine revelation of their nature.
('65', 129, 8, 18, 226327) I was very happy to observe that all of them were upset.

('65', 131, 4, 12, 229485) 166. LETTER TO LILAVATI MUNSHI
('65', 131, 5, 13, 229516) October 5, 1934
('65', 131, 6, 14, 229532) LILAVATI, Thus is my reply to your letter.
('65', 131, 6, 15, 229575) I am writing it for Munshi, however.
('65', 131, 6, 16, 229612) He who follows many ideals worships several gods.
('65', 131, 6, 17, 229662) How can he get peace of mind?
('65', 131, 6, 18, 229692) Gods have been imagined as extremely jealous and quick to take offence.
('65', 131, 6, 19, 229764) The devotee of one god has only one ideal in life.
('65', 131, 6, 20, 229815) He wishes to have vision of only one god of truth.
('65', 131, 6, 21, 229866) Such a man is ever contented and happy.
('65', 131, 6, 22, 229906) If legal practice helps one to realize that ideal, one must practise as a lawyer despite censure by the whole world.
('65', 131, 6, 23, 230023) If, on the other hand, practice of law stands in the way of one’s progress towards the ideal, one must have nothing whatever to do with it.
('65', 131, 6, 24, 230163) Legal practice, voluntary poverty, the Congress throne, people’s criticism—these and many other such things are but so many forms of trust.
('65', 131, 6, 25, 230303) The devotee of one god who accepts praise and censure with an equal mind and lives in comfort in Malabar Hill would be equally happy in an ill lighted chawl in Worli too.
('65', 131, 6, 26, 230474) This is how Munshi wishes to live.
('65', 131, 6, 27, 230509) But it is a mental experiment.
('65', 131, 6, 28, 230540) Why is he, then, afraid about it?
('65', 131, 6, 29, 230574) What has happend to his penetrating intellect and to all his reading of the Shastras?
('65', 131, 6, 30, 230660) If one’s mind is pure one has the Ganga flowing by one’s door step, as they say.
('65', 131, 6, 31, 230741) On the other hand, I have seen many a rogue who has been to Kashi and also bathed in the Ganga there.

('65', 132, 1, 2, 230964) 167. LETTER TO RAMJI
('65', 132, 2, 3, 230985) October 5, 1934
('65', 132, 3, 4, 231001) BHAI RAMJI,
('65', 132, 4, 5, 231013) I have read your letter carefully.
('65', 132, 4, 6, 231048) I cannot think of any changes in the programme of studies.
('65', 132, 4, 7, 231107) The problem of khadi can be solved only by a perfect study of the science of khadi.
('65', 132, 4, 8, 231191) It cannot be solved by yielding to the fancies of people.
('65', 132, 4, 9, 231249) Khadi has an important role in times of famine.
('65', 132, 4, 10, 231297) But the inhabitants of a famine stricken area should content themselves with the lowest payment.
('65', 132, 4, 11, 231394) If there is any other occupation through which they can earn more, we should not put the spinning wheel or the takli before them.
('65', 132, 4, 12, 231524) The money received for the purpose of self sufficiency in cloth cannot be given to victims of famine.
('65', 132, 4, 13, 231626) The State or the rich ought to buy up the khadi produced in famine areas.
('65', 132, 4, 14, 231700) Till the rich identify themselves with the poor, khadi can have no place as a means of relief in times of famine.
('65', 132, 4, 15, 231814) Apart from the rich, the other classes cannot consume the khadi produced during famine.
('65', 132, 4, 16, 231902) The poor would be wearing the khadi produced by themselves and the middle classes would buy their requirements in the market.
('65', 132, 4, 17, 232028) There has to be, therefore, extra demand for khadi produced during famine.
('65', 132, 4, 18, 232103) For further explanation, read what I am going to write in Harijan when I get time.

('65', 137, 10, 19, 239925) 176. LETTER TO B. SRIRANGASAYI
('65', 137, 11, 20, 239956) October 6, 1934
('65', 137, 12, 21, 239972) MY DEAR SRIRANGASAYI, I have your letter.
('65', 137, 12, 22, 240014) It is refreshing to know that the Socialist Party in Andhra appreciates all the amendments suggested by me.
('65', 137, 12, 23, 240122) I say the Socialist Party because I take it that your letter is representative of the Party’s opinion as you have signed it in your capacity as Secretary.
('65', 138, 0, 1, 240277) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 139
('65', 138, 1, 2, 240326) But you know in what unmeasured terms the meeting in Banaras has condemned the amendments.
('65', 138, 1, 3, 240417) Even when I first conceived spinning franchise as a token of the dignity of labour and its universal recognition, a friend had shown me a booklet containing the constitution of the Soviets and drawn my attention to the fact that in Russia labour franchise had a definite place.
('65', 138, 1, 4, 240695) But here I do not know whether you represent the general body of Socialists.
('65', 138, 1, 5, 240772) What about those who have passed the resolutions of condemnation?
('65', 138, 1, 6, 240838) You take exception to my wish that the rich should regard themselves as trustees for the whole of society rather than as owners of the wealth they might possess.
('65', 138, 1, 7, 241000) Of course, it is an uphill task, but by no means impossible.
('65', 138, 1, 8, 241061) Indeed I see definite signs of that idea spreading and being accepted.
('65', 138, 1, 9, 241132) You suggest that the poor should be regarded as trustees for the rich.
('65', 138, 1, 10, 241203) But you forget that it is implied in the proposition I have laid down.
('65', 138, 1, 11, 241274) Because, have I not said that labour is as much capital as metal?
('65', 138, 1, 12, 241340) Therefore, workers, instead of regarding themselves as enemies of the rich, or regarding the rich as their natural enemies, should hold their labour in trust for those who are in need of it.
('65', 138, 1, 13, 241531) This they can do only when, instead of feeling so utterly helpless as they do, they realize their importance in human economy and shed their fear or distrust of the rich.
('65', 138, 1, 14, 241702) Fear and distrust are twin sisters born of weakness.
('65', 138, 1, 15, 241755) When labour realizes its strength it won’t need to use any force against moneyed people.
('65', 138, 1, 16, 241844) It will simply command their attention and respect.
('65', 138, 2, 17, 241896) The Hindu, 11 10 1934

('65', 144, 1, 2, 250629) 186. WOMEN AND VARNA1
('65', 144, 2, 3, 250651) An esteemed friend writes: 2
('65', 144, 3, 4, 250680) From your recent writing 3 on varna in Harijan it seems that the principle of varna adumbrated by you is intended to apply only to men.
('65', 144, 3, 5, 250816) What, then, about women?
('65', 144, 3, 6, 250841) What would determine a woman’s varna?
('65', 144, 3, 7, 250879) Perhaps you will answer that before marriage a woman would take her varna from her father; after marriage from her husband.
('65', 144, 3, 8, 251003) Should one understand that you support Manu’s notorious dictum that there can be no independence for woman at any stage of her life, that before marriage she must remain under the tutelage of her parents, after marriage under that of her husband and, in the event of her widowhood, under that of her children?
('65', 144, 3, 9, 251313) It is .
('65', 144, 3, 10, 251321) the commonest thing nowadays to find a woman serving as a schoolmistress, while her ‘husband is doing business as a money lender.
('65', 144, 3, 11, 251451) To what varna would the woman under these circumstances belong?
('65', 144, 3, 12, 251515) To what varna between these would their children belong?
('65', 144, 4, 13, 251572) In my opinion, the question raised is irrelevant in the circumstances prevailing today.
('65', 144, 4, 14, 251660) As I have pointed out in the writing referred to, owing to the confusion of the varnas, today there are in reality no varnas, the varna principle has ceased to operate.
('65', 144, 4, 15, 251829) The present state of Hindu society may be described as that of anarchy; the four varnas today exist in name only.
('65', 144, 4, 16, 251943) If we must talk in terms of varna, there is only one varna today for all, whether men or women; we are all Shudras.
('65', 144, 4, 17, 252059) In the resuscitated varnadharma, as I conceive it, a girl before her marriage will belong to the varna of her father, just like her brother.
('65', 144, 4, 18, 252200) Inter marriages between different varnas will be rare.
('65', 144, 4, 19, 252255) A girl will, therefore, retain her varna unimpaired even after her marriage.
('65', 144, 4, 20, 252332) But should the husband belong to a different varna, then, on marriage, she would naturally adopt his varna and relinquish that of her parents.
('65', 144, 4, 21, 252475) Nor need such a change of varna be understood to imply a slur against anybody or touch anybody’s susceptibilities since the institution of varna in the age of resuscitation would imply absolute
('65', 144, 5, 22, 252669) 1 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 7 10 1934. 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('65', 144, 5, 23, 252768) 3 Vide “Introduction to Varnavyavastha”, 23 9 1934.
('65', 145, 0, 1, 252820) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 145, 1, 2, 252862) social equality of all the four varnas.
('65', 145, 1, 3, 252902) I do not envisage the wife, as a rule, following an avocation independently of her husband.
('65', 145, 1, 4, 252994) The care of the children and the upkeep of the household are quite enough to fully engage all her energy.
('65', 145, 1, 5, 253100) In a well ordered society the additional burden of maintain ing the family ought not to fall on her.
('65', 145, 1, 6, 253201) The man should look to the maintenance of the family, the woman to household management; the two thus supplementing and complementing each other’s labours.
('65', 145, 1, 7, 253357) Nor do I see in this any invasion of woman’s rights or suppression of her freedom.
('65', 145, 1, 8, 253440) The saying attributed to Manu that “For woman there can be no freedom” is not to me sacrosanct.
('65', 145, 1, 9, 253536) It only shows that probably, at the time when it was promulgated, women were kept in a state of subjection.
('65', 145, 1, 10, 253644) The epithets used in our literature to describe a wife are ardhangana, “the better half”, and sahadharmini, “the help mate”.
('65', 145, 1, 11, 253769) The husband addressing the wife as devi or ‘‘goddess” does not show any disparagement.
('65', 145, 1, 12, 253856) But, unfortunately, a time came when the woman was divested of many of her rights and privileges and was reduced to a status of inferiority.
('65', 145, 1, 13, 253997) But there could be no question of depreciation of her varna.
('65', 145, 1, 14, 254058) For, varna does not connote a set of rights or privileges; it prescribes duties or obligations only.
('65', 145, 1, 15, 254159) And no one can divest us of our duty, unless we ourselves choose to shirk it.
('65', 145, 1, 16, 254237) The woman who knows and fulfils her duty realizes her dignified status.
('65', 145, 1, 17, 254309) She is the queen, not the slave, of the household over which she presides.
('65', 145, 1, 18, 254384) I need hardly say after this that, if the position set forth by me with regard to the role of the woman in society is accepted, the question of the varna of the children will cease to present any problem, as there will be no more any discrepancy as between the varnas of the husband and the wife.
('65', 145, 1, 19, 254681) Harijan, 12 10 1934

('65', 149, 2, 3, 258902) October 8,1934
('65', 149, 3, 4, 258917) MY DEAR DEORUKHKER,
('65', 149, 4, 5, 258937) So far as the modification of the communal decision is concerned, the Harijan part of it cannot be modified except with the unanimous consent of all the parties concerned, and I shall be certainly no party to any modification which worsens the position of Harijans Or which has not their consent.
('65', 149, 4, 6, 259234) So far as the elections are concerned, I am quite clear that it would be detrimental to the Harijan cause to involve the Harijans in any shape or form in the fight with the Government in which the Congress is engaged.
('65', 149, 4, 7, 259452) There are many other and more tangible ways open to caste Hindus to show their sympathy, and more than sympathy, to the Harijans.
('65', 149, 5, 8, 259582) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('65', 149, 6, 9, 259612) SHRI B. J. DEORUKHKER KRISHNA BUILDING NO.
('65', 149, 6, 10, 259655) 4 POIBAWADI, PAREL, BOMBAY
('65', 149, 7, 11, 259682) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('65', 149, 8, 14, 259966) He had also requested Gandhiji to reconsider his views on the question of putting up Harijan candidates to contest the Assembly elections.

('65', 151, 1, 2, 261433) 197. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL October 8, 1934 BHAISHRI VALLABHBHAI, I read your letters to Mahadev.
('65', 151, 1, 3, 261536) If you can come with Dr. Ansari, do come.
('65', 151, 1, 4, 261578) I have received numerous wires regarding Ishwar Sharan 1. I didn’t send the others to you, but I am sending Baba Raghavdas’s with this.
('65', 151, 1, 5, 261714) Ishwar Sharan is opposed by Krishnakant 2. Aney has suggested that the latter may be replaced by Chintamani 3 and Ishwar Sharan should be asked to withdraw, and that Bhagwandas may not be opposed.
('65', 151, 1, 6, 261911) This seems to me worth doing if it can be managed.
('65', 151, 1, 7, 261962) In any case, Ishwar Sharan should withdraw in favour of Chintamani.
('65', 151, 1, 8, 262030) Opposition to Bhagwandas will create much bitterness.
('65', 151, 1, 9, 262084) I have sent you a wire 4 regarding this.
('65', 151, 1, 10, 262125) Next about Abhyankar.
('65', 151, 1, 11, 262147) After I had sent that wire, I received the accompanying letter from Bapuji.
('65', 151, 1, 12, 262223) I, therefore, need not take your time trying to explain the reasoning behind that wire.
('65', 151, 1, 13, 262311) I had long wires from Nariman and Mathuradas pleading against postponement of the Congress.
('65', 151, 1, 14, 262403) The expenditure was unneces sary.
('65', 151, 1, 15, 262437) I am not at all keen on postponement.
('65', 151, 1, 16, 262475) I merely acted as a postman.
('65', 151, 1, 17, 262504) Surely, neither you nor I can be a party to anything that might harm the Congress or the Parliamentary Board.
('65', 151, 1, 18, 262614) And, moreover, I can’t judge about these things from my retreat here.
('65', 151, 1, 19, 262684) The Khan Brothers have got stuck in Bengal.
('65', 151, 1, 20, 262728) It has become extremely difficult now to persuade them to go to Bombay on the 19th.
('65', 151, 1, 21, 262812) What can we do?
('65', 151, 1, 22, 262828) I have, of course, written 5. I am very much afraid that you might fall ill.
('65', 151, 1, 23, 262905) However, I remember the case of William, the Prince of orange.
('65', 151, 1, 24, 262968) As long as God wanted him to live and serve, he remained unharmed even in the midst of a shower of bullets.
('65', 151, 1, 25, 263076) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro 2: Sardar Vallabhbhaine, pp.
('65', 151, 2, 26, 263154) 1 Munshi Ishwar Sharan, a Harijan worker of Allahabad 2 Krishnakant Malaviya 3 C. Y. Chintamani, Editor, The Leader 4 This is not available.
('65', 151, 2, 27, 263295) 5 Vide “Letter to Prafulla Chandra Ghosh”, 7 10 1934.

('65', 152, 1, 2, 263398) 198. LETTER TO M.
('65', 152, 2, 3, 263416) October 9, 1934
('65', 152, 3, 4, 263432) MY DEAR M.,
('65', 152, 4, 5, 263444) I have your letter.
('65', 152, 4, 6, 263464) Your pride is still speaking in you.
('65', 152, 4, 7, 263501) You want to repeat the very thing that undid you!
('65', 152, 4, 8, 263551) Can pride take a man deeper?
('65', 152, 4, 9, 263580) No, you must not [come] back here to take your penance.
('65', 152, 4, 10, 263636) You will be received with open arms when the sense of sin is self evident.
('65', 152, 4, 11, 263711) Your letter is evidence of the contrary.
('65', 152, 4, 12, 263752) You have not even the honesty to say to those concerned what you have actually done, if only to guide them in future.
('65', 152, 4, 13, 263870) You must come down [your] pedestal before you can realize the enormity of the treble sin.
('65', 152, 4, 14, 263960) Remember a fellow sinner is speaking to you.
('65', 152, 4, 15, 264005) Only I have the sense of sin and I fly from it.
('65', 152, 4, 16, 264053) You want to come to it.

('65', 153, 6, 9, 264953) 201. LETTER TO KANTI GANDHI
('65', 153, 7, 10, 264981) October [9], 1 1934
('65', 153, 8, 11, 265001) KANTI, I got your long letter.
('65', 153, 8, 12, 265032) Nobody else will read it.
('65', 153, 8, 13, 265058) I understand your feeling.
('65', 153, 8, 14, 265085) I have arranged the money for you from Ramachandran.
('65', 153, 8, 15, 265138) My relations with him are such that I need not hesitate about this and this is quite the right thing to do for you as well as for me.
('65', 153, 8, 16, 265272) When he is there it does not look nice to send money direct from here.
('65', 153, 8, 17, 265343) I shall certainly return it to him so you may draw the money without hesitation.
('65', 153, 8, 18, 265424) If you do not find it enough, write to me.
('65', 153, 8, 19, 265467) It is very good that you keep account of each and every pie.
('65', 153, 8, 20, 265528) I understand the state of your mind which you so vividly describe.
('65', 153, 8, 21, 265595) Don’t force yourself to do anything.
('65', 153, 8, 22, 265632) Place your foot only where you can plant it firmly knowing all that is happening around you.
('65', 153, 8, 23, 265725) It has been my experience throughout that nothing that is done in an unnatural manner endures, but that instead there is only increase in hypocrisy.
('65', 153, 8, 24, 265874) That is why I am fighting to get out of the Congress.
('65', 153, 8, 25, 265928) I shall be
('65', 153, 9, 26, 265939) 1 From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary

('65', 154, 1, 2, 266035) satisfied if only one quality at any rate endures among you all.

('65', 154, 1, 4, 266137) He who clings to truth will in time come to see his errors.
('65', 154, 1, 5, 266197) He will correct them and go ahead.
('65', 154, 1, 6, 266232) Nowadays I receive letters from Harilal regularly.

('65', 155, 5, 7, 268160) 204. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('65', 155, 6, 8, 268199) October 10, 1934
('65', 155, 7, 9, 268216) DEAR SATISBABU,
('65', 155, 8, 10, 268232) I have your letter.
('65', 155, 8, 11, 268252) As to the Ashram at Delhi, the fact that there is the other Central one should not be overemphasized.
('65', 155, 8, 12, 268354) There should be an ashram or institution at the headquarters, and the idea is that the office should be taken there, with accommodation for the whole of the staff, and provision for a technical institute.
('65', 155, 8, 13, 268559) If the provinces can raise sufficient money for themselves, each of them can certainly have such training centres.
('65', 155, 8, 14, 268674) Karachi has almost a model institute where, under first class expert guidance, all kinds of articles are manufactured from leather.
('65', 155, 8, 15, 268806) Sewing is also done there, and the ground is exceedingly well kept.
('65', 155, 8, 16, 268874) The whole thing is due to the enterprise of Mohatta Bros.
('65', 155, 8, 17, 268932) Now it has become so popular that even non Harijans are applying for admission.
('65', 155, 8, 18, 269012) Therefore, the idea of the Delhi institute is not in conflict with yours, but on the contrary it is in support of yours—only Delhi can’t find the funds for other centres.
('65', 155, 8, 19, 269183) Bangalore is also developing such things.
('65', 155, 8, 20, 269225) Kathiawar has three.
('65', 155, 8, 21, 269246) But they were there prior to the establishment of the Harijan Board, and they have now come under the influence of the Central Board.
('65', 155, 8, 22, 269380) The establishment of an institute at Delhi was an idea conceived by Ghanshyamdas before Sabarmati was given [over].
('65', 155, 8, 23, 269496) It is, and will remain, an all India concern.
('65', 155, 8, 24, 269542) Whether it will be so in fact depends largely upon what the management is able to make of it.
('65', 155, 8, 25, 269636) I do not sup pose we shall get in the near future over 100 acres of land and buildings worth over two lakhs.
('65', 155, 8, 26, 269745) In acreage the Delhi plot is nothing, but the situation is very good.
('65', 155, 9, 27, 269815) 1 The message was sent through S. Satyamurthi.
('65', 156, 0, 1, 269862) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 157
('65', 156, 1, 2, 269911) Ghanshyamdas wants to develop the scheme after his own fashion, and to spend a lot of his substance on it.
('65', 156, 1, 3, 270018) I do hope that my proposal 1 to Devibabu and Bhagirathji will be accepted and that we shall not have to lose the money Satcowriebabu has taken away.
('65', 156, 1, 4, 270167) It is an unfortunate incident which should be redressed so far as it is possible.
('65', 156, 1, 5, 270249) The paragraph you quote from McCarrison is very interesting.
('65', 156, 1, 6, 270310) McCarrison I have found to be a reliable writer, but he is somewhat hasty in generalizing.
('65', 156, 1, 7, 270401) I have had considerable correspondence with him.
('65', 156, 1, 8, 270450) Are you not sweeping in your statement that starch is identified with sugar as a food?
('65', 156, 1, 9, 270537) Now sugar can be given with impunity to babies.
('65', 156, 1, 10, 270585) I have never heard that starch can be given to them with equal impunity.
('65', 156, 1, 11, 270658) Then, starch can never be taken without cooking.
('65', 156, 1, 12, 270707) Sugar requires no cooking.
('65', 156, 1, 13, 270734) And even if rice is cooked, surely you do not claim the same value for rice as you would for raisins from the point of view of harmlessness.
('65', 156, 1, 14, 270875) I am testing just now the effect of unboiled milk, fresh from the udder.
('65', 156, 1, 15, 270948) I have heard so much in praise of unboiled milk that I want to try its effect myself.
('65', 156, 1, 16, 271034) The only difficulty is that you can’t take all the milk that you want to at one meal.
('65', 156, 1, 17, 271120) You have to divide it, and you can’t get the goats or the cows, as the case may be, to yield the milk whenever you want to milk them.
('65', 156, 1, 18, 271254) The question then is: Does unboiled milk retain its full quality throughout the day if you stored it in ice or kept in a corked bottle with a wet towel wrapped round it?
('65', 156, 1, 19, 271424) I have tried it myself.
('65', 156, 1, 20, 271448) The: milk retains the full flavour.
('65', 156, 1, 21, 271484) Whether it retains the full quality, I have no knowledge.
('65', 156, 1, 22, 271542) If you can throw light upon it, please do.
('65', 156, 1, 23, 271585) I shall watch the development of your researches about the full use of all the parts of carcasses.
('65', 156, 2, 24, 271684) SHRI SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA CALCUTTA
('65', 156, 3, 25, 271722) From a photostat: G.N. 1626a
('65', 156, 4, 26, 271751) 1 Vide “Letter to Devibabu”, 3 10 1934.

('65', 159, 7, 10, 275057) 210. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('65', 159, 8, 11, 275088) October 11, 1934
('65', 159, 9, 12, 275105) NARANDAS,
('65', 159, 10, 13, 275115) I have your letter.

('65', 162, 1, 2, 278296) 215. A GREAT HARIJAN SEVAK GONE1
('65', 162, 2, 3, 278329) Rajasaheb Kalakanker, whose untimely death was announced week before last, was a great Harijan sevak.
('65', 162, 2, 4, 278431) He was ailing for nearly a year.
('65', 162, 2, 5, 278464) I could hardly recognize him when I saw him last in Calcutta, where he was undergoing treatment.
('65', 162, 2, 6, 278561) He was a most liberal minded zamindar of U. P. It can be truly said of him that he lived for his ryots to the best of his ability.
('65', 162, 2, 7, 278692) His tastes were simple.
('65', 162, 2, 8, 278716) He mixed freely with people.
('65', 162, 2, 9, 278745) His love for Harijans was no less than for others.
('65', 162, 2, 10, 278796) He endeavoured by his open example to have caste Hindus of his zamindari abolish untouchability and let Harijans enjoy the same rights as they themselves enjoyed.
('65', 162, 2, 11, 278959) All schools, wells, temples under his own direct management were freely thrown open to Harijans.
('65', 162, 2, 12, 279056) Let us hope that the bereaved Ranisaheba and other members of Kalakanker’s family will carry out the noble traditions bequeathed by him and thus perpetuate the Rajasaheb’s memory.
('65', 162, 3, 13, 279236) Harijan, 12 10 1934
('65', 162, 4, 14, 279256) 216. WHOSE VICTORY?
('65', 162, 5, 15, 279276) Harijan servants have need to exercise the greatest forbearance at this time of their trial.
('65', 162, 5, 16, 279369) The Temple entry Bill is gone.
('65', 162, 5, 17, 279400) The sanatanists are jubilant.
('65', 162, 5, 18, 279430) We must not mind their joy.
('65', 162, 5, 19, 279458) Only yesterday we were what they are today.
('65', 162, 5, 20, 279502) We may not hate them.
('65', 162, 5, 21, 279524) We must love them.
('65', 162, 5, 22, 279543) Let the reformers treasure the following lines a sister sends me from AE.’s 2 Interpreters, which she venerates almost as a devout Christian his Bible.
('65', 162, 5, 23, 279695) These are the beautiful lines:
('65', 162, 6, 24, 279726) Love and hate have a magical transforming power.
('65', 162, 6, 25, 279775) They are the great soul changers.
('65', 162, 6, 26, 279809) We grow through their exercise into the likeness of what we contemplate.
('65', 162, 6, 27, 279882) By intensity of hatred, nations create in themselves the character they imagine in their enemies.
('65', 162, 6, 28, 279980) Hence it comes that all passionate conflicts result in an interchange of characteristics.
('65', 162, 6, 29, 280070) We might say, with truth, that those who hate open a door by which their enemies enter and make their own the secret place of the heart.
('65', 162, 7, 30, 280207) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('65', 162, 7, 31, 280238) 2 George William Russel (1867 1935), Irish poet, philosopher and painter.
('65', 162, 7, 32, 280312) The Interpreters (1920) is a symposium in the Platonic fashion.
('65', 163, 0, 1, 280376) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 163, 1, 2, 280418) Love is the only thing that can transform sanatanists.
('65', 163, 1, 3, 280473) Let us realize that they are what they are, in spite of themselves.
('65', 163, 1, 4, 280541) We have no right to judge them or become impatient with them.
('65', 163, 1, 5, 280603) Surely, it is enough if we are true to ourselves, that is, if we act up to our belief and render full twenty shillings in the pound to the Harijans.
('65', 163, 1, 6, 280752) Again, let us realize that in their victory lies their defeat; in our humiliation lies our victory.
('65', 163, 1, 7, 280852) Sanatanists can no longer plead the Temple entry Bill in defence of their opposition to the entry of Harijans to our temples by our common consent.
('65', 163, 1, 8, 281000) Reformers can now prosecute the temple entry question with re doubled zeal.
('65', 163, 1, 9, 281076) The reformers would sin, if they felt that the burial of the Bill meant the burial of the temple entry movement.
('65', 163, 1, 10, 281189) It is not so.
('65', 163, 1, 11, 281203) Wherever we can, without bitterness, have temples opened by the consent of sanatanists, we must do so.
('65', 163, 1, 12, 281306) It is possible that those who were holding themselves aloof from the temple entry movement, on account of the Temple entry Bill being prosecuted, will, now that it is out of the way, join the movement to have them opened without the aid of the law.
('65', 163, 1, 13, 281555) For, be it remembered that the Bill is not dead, it is only suspended.
('65', 163, 1, 14, 281626) Legislation has to come, if sanatanists do not heartily co operate with the reformers in having temples opened to Harijans precisely on the same terms as to caste Hindus.
('65', 163, 1, 15, 281797) Harijan, 12 10 1934
('65', 163, 2, 16, 281817) 217. INSTRUCTIVE FIGURES
('65', 163, 3, 17, 281842) The Maharashtra branch of the A. I. S. A., whose head office is situated in Wardha, has at my request furnished me with some most instructive figures about the incidence of the distribution of every rupee spent on khadi among the various persons engaged in the manufacture and distribution of khadi.
('65', 163, 3, 18, 282142) The following are the figures for white khadi of 10 to 14 counts of yarn: Rs. A. P. Farmer for cotton 0 4 6 Ginning 0 0 6 Carding 0 1 0 Spinning 0 3 6 Weaving 0 4 0 Freight 0 0 8
('65', 164, 0, 1, 282321) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 165
('65', 164, 1, 2, 282370) Bleaching 0 0 8 Management 0 1 2
('65', 164, 3, 3, 282403) This khadi constitutes roughly 50 per cent of the stock.
('65', 164, 3, 4, 282460) Therefore, on that quantity, the management gets only one anna two pies (0 1 2) in the rupee worth of khadi and workers up to the weaver Rs. 0 13 6 in the rupee.
('65', 164, 3, 5, 282622) It is satisfactory to note that the farmer, the spinner and the weaver get the largest portion among themselves.
('65', 164, 3, 6, 282735) In the higher counts, the farmer gets much less and the spinner tops the list.
('65', 164, 3, 7, 282814) But the incidental charges increase.
('65', 164, 3, 8, 282851) They go as high as 25 per cent.
('65', 164, 3, 9, 282883) Then, again, on fancy articles there may be cent per cent increase on khadi.
('65', 164, 3, 10, 282960) Indeed, in the cost of khadi in a fancy kerchief costing one rupee, the portion going to Daridranarayana may be only half an anna or less.
('65', 164, 3, 11, 283099) For socks or stockings made of hand spun yarn on tiny hand machines, the cost of yarn would be trifling.
('65', 164, 3, 12, 283204) The cost of an Andhra sari, as it may come from Andhra, may be Rs. 25, and it may be sold after fancy work done on it at Rs. 150. The moral is obvious: the simpler the khadi, the larger the amount that goes into the pockets of the poorest workers.
('65', 164, 3, 13, 283452) The fancy work no doubt makes khadi popular in homes which could not otherwise look at it.
('65', 164, 3, 14, 283543) I may add also that there are some popular varieties of saris and dhotis manufactured for poor people.
('65', 164, 3, 15, 283646) On these no management charges are at all added.
('65', 164, 3, 16, 283695) And there is no such thing as net profit in any of the numerous stores managed by the A. I. S. A. The management charges are added in order to make khadi self supporting.
('65', 164, 3, 17, 283866) This has not yet happened.
('65', 164, 3, 18, 283893) The Committee of the A. I. S. A. is constantly taxing itself so as to reduce prices and to make the management so efficient as to bring down the expenses to a minimum.
('65', 164, 4, 19, 284061) Harijan, 12 10 1934

('65', 169, 7, 13, 291625) 227. LETTER TO J. N. SAHNI
('65', 169, 8, 14, 291652) October 14, 1934

('65', 171, 4, 13, 293538) 231. LETTER TO S. AMBUJAMMAL WARDHA, October 14, 1934
('65', 171, 5, 14, 293592) MY DEAR AMBUJAM, You have filled me with deep anxiety, and I have not known what to do.
('65', 171, 5, 15, 293680) In my despair I sent a long telegram to Harihara Sharma.
('65', 171, 5, 16, 293737) At first I thought I would wire to Father.
('65', 171, 5, 17, 293780) Then I became afraid lest he should be angry and your position should become more awkward than it already is.
('65', 171, 5, 18, 293890) Though I have not interfered with your fast, I have not felt happy over it.
('65', 171, 5, 19, 293966) However, I do hope that it ended without any injury to the body, and that you were enjoying inward happiness during the fast.
('65', 171, 5, 20, 294092) You must not give way to despair if even the fast has not induced the parents to grant you the permission to come to me.
('65', 171, 5, 21, 294213) You must try again and again but no more fasting should be undertaken.
('65', 171, 5, 22, 294284) You should try to deserve their permission by your correct conduct and patient argument with them.
('65', 171, 5, 23, 294383) I am sure that they will listen to your request when they realize that it is not in a momentary fit that you have desired to come to me, but that it is a longing of the soul which you dare not suppress.
('65', 171, 5, 24, 294586) 2 I do hope that you will listen to me.
