('65', 172, 8, 13, 295438) 233. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('65', 172, 9, 14, 295466) October 15, 1934
('65', 172, 10, 15, 295483) So much has been written in the Press regarding my proposed retirement from the Congress that it has become necessary to state the position as it occurs to me today.
('65', 172, 10, 16, 295649) No doubt is left on my mind that many Congressmen do not like my proposals 1 to make the Article regarding the habitual wearing of khaddar stiffer and a more workable spinning franchise compulsory and replace by the words “truthful and non violent” the words “peaceful and legitimate” in the Congress creed.
('65', 172, 10, 17, 295957) opinion so far expressed renders it wholly unnecessary for me to put these proposals before fellow delegates, in order to test their feelings on them.
('65', 172, 10, 18, 296108) I have not and never had any desire to carry them by a mere majority.
('65', 172, 10, 19, 296178) For their proper working a hearty assent of an overwhelming majority is required, by my test.
('65', 172, 10, 20, 296272) I cannot be satisfied with any majority, howsoever decisive, given as a price for my remaining in the Congress.
('65', 172, 10, 21, 296384) Such a position cannot flatter my pride or vanity.
('65', 172, 10, 22, 296435) It can only humiliate me.
('65', 172, 10, 23, 296461) I do not want to become a patron of
('65', 172, 11, 24, 296497) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 17 9 1934.
('65', 173, 0, 1, 296541) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 173, 1, 2, 296583) the Congress.
('65', 173, 1, 3, 296597) I regard myself as a humble servant of the nation and a fellow worker for the sake of service.
('65', 173, 1, 4, 296692) My proposed retirement is neither a threat nor an ultimatum.
('65', 173, 1, 5, 296753) It is a natural consequence of the rejection of amendments, because hearty acceptance of the amendments is necessary to enable me to render efficient service.
('65', 173, 1, 6, 296912) It is now as clear as crystal that I cannot secure that hearty assent from the Congress.
('65', 173, 1, 7, 297001) Subject, therefore, to whatever the informal meeting of the members of the A. I. C. C. may have to say, I propose to retire from the Congress immediately after closing of the session.
('65', 173, 1, 8, 297185) In this step, I have the fullest concurrence of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Dr. Anrsari.
('65', 173, 1, 9, 297275) The latter tells me that he had made up his mind at Port Said where he saw my statement that my retirement was in every way in the best interests of the nation.
('65', 173, 1, 10, 297436) He had no doubt also as to the time for retirement.
('65', 173, 1, 11, 297488) It is wholly wrong to think, as some have done, that the recent visit of Sardar Patel and Babu Rajendra Prasad was for the purpose of pressing me to remain in the Congress.
('65', 173, 1, 12, 297661) They had never any doubt as to the correctness of my position.
('65', 173, 1, 13, 297724) I may also state that many of my most valued co workers, including the Khan Brothers, have heartily endorsed the contemplated retirement.
('65', 173, 1, 14, 297862) All these know that my retirement from the Congress does not mean the loss of my services.
('65', 173, 1, 15, 297953) On the contrary, my services are always at the country’s beck and call and may be commanded without any Congressman feeling any the least embarrassment because of my retirement from the Congress.
('65', 173, 1, 16, 298149) I feel that the presence in the Congress of a man like me, having fundamental differences on many of the most important questions, with many colleagues, must be a source of weakness rather than strength.
('65', 173, 1, 17, 298353) Hence the decision.
('65', 173, 1, 18, 298373) Lest my contemplated retirement should be exploited in order to damage the Parliamentary fight in which the Congress is now engaged, I would like all Congressmen to know that I am firmer than ever in my conviction that notwithstanding whatever I have said before to the contrary, I hold the representation of the Congress on the legislatures to be necessary.
('65', 173, 1, 19, 298732) Boycott of legislatures was never meant to be a permanent step.
('65', 173, 1, 20, 298796) Those who have no convictions to the contrary and are otherwise free should hold themselves at the disposal of the Congress to serve the nation through entering the legislatures.
('65', 173, 1, 21, 298975) The present election campaign is a fight not among men but among political principles represented by men or women professing to
('65', 174, 0, 1, 299103) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 175
('65', 174, 1, 2, 299152) represent them.
('65', 174, 1, 3, 299168) It is the paramount duty of voters who believe that the Congress stands in the amplest manner for the nation’s goal of inde pendence and that it has counted and will count no sacrifice too great to achieve that goal, to give their vote to the Congress candidates.
('65', 174, 1, 4, 299432) Having cleared the ground thus for my retirement, I would invite the attention of Congressmen to the amendments appended hereto giving effect to my proposal for reducing the number of delegates from 6,000 to 1,000. At the most, I hold it to be vital for the growth of the Congress.
('65', 174, 1, 5, 299714) Unwieldy and merely spectacular as the Congress had become in the years before 1920, it has tended more and more again to degenerate into the same spectacular body.
('65', 174, 1, 6, 299879) Entertainments and exhibitions, good as they are in their places, have overshadowed the business part of the annual session.
('65', 174, 1, 7, 300004) My amendments remedy the evil.
('65', 174, 1, 8, 300035) These amendments are to be regarded solely as my individual view.
('65', 174, 1, 9, 300101) In order that the change contemplated may not come without due warning to the nation, with the consent of Sardar Vallabhbhai I have taken the liberty of placing the amendments before the public.
('65', 174, 1, 10, 300296) There is no question of threat or ultimatum behind the amendments.
('65', 174, 1, 11, 300363) It will be open to the Subjects Committee and then to the Congress to reject the amendments, but I would warn them against so doing without the most careful conside ration.
('65', 174, 1, 12, 300536) Let Congressmen understand that I am the author of the constitution 1, as it is.
('65', 174, 1, 13, 300617) They will also bear in mind that I have had an exceptional opportunity of carefully studying its working.
('65', 174, 1, 14, 300723) Experience has revealed several flaws in the constitution.
('65', 174, 1, 15, 300782) My proposal is devised to remove them.
('65', 174, 1, 16, 300821) That experience may discover other flaws in my proposal is quite likely.
('65', 174, 1, 17, 300894) When they are discovered, the Congress will deal with them but so far as I can judge, my proposal meets with the present situation, and makes the whole Congress organization, if it is at all honestly worked, a most efficient body and more truly representative of Congressmen than it has ever been.
('65', 174, 1, 18, 301192) Briefly, it amounts to this.
('65', 174, 1, 19, 301221) The maximum of 1,000 delegates will now be distributed not according to the population of each province but in accordance with the number of Congressmen on the Congress register in each province and there will be one delegate to every 1,000 or more Congressmen.
('65', 174, 1, 20, 301483) Therefore, in order to have the full quota of 1,000 for all India, we shall need 1,000,000 Congressmen on our
('65', 174, 2, 21, 301593) 1 For the constitution as passed at the Nagpur session in 1920, vide “Congress constitution adopted at Nagpur session”, december 1920.
('65', 175, 0, 1, 301728) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 175, 1, 2, 301770) register.
('65', 175, 1, 3, 301780) In order to keep up to its level of population, every province will at least have to make an effort to keep its register of members up to the mark.
('65', 175, 1, 4, 301928) In order to check the tendency that has unfortunately grown up of buying members just for voting purposes at four annas each, the proposed change requires that no one shall be entitled to vote at any election before the expiry of six months after the date of his paying a subscription of four annas.
('65', 175, 1, 5, 302228) Then again, hitherto, we have had persons in any part of India elected as delegates in any other part of India.
('65', 175, 1, 6, 302340) The result has been a number of bogus delegates at all Congress sessions.
('65', 175, 1, 7, 302414) Some Provincial Congress Committees have been known to have offered almost a free run to anybody who has wanted to be elected as a delegate.
('65', 175, 1, 8, 302555) This is effectively dealt with under the amendments by restricting the election of delegates to only those who might be on the Congress register in the constituency for which they stand.
('65', 175, 1, 9, 302742) The actual number of delegates to be elected shall depend upon and vary with the total number of Congressmen of six months’ standing on the Congress register for the whole of India.
('65', 175, 1, 10, 302924) In order to ensure the election of delegates who are real representatives, choice is confined to Congressmen on the registers of the different constituencies whose number would vary from year to year with the number of Congressmen on the register.
('65', 175, 1, 11, 303172) Under this proposal, the expenses of election are reduced to a minimum.
('65', 175, 1, 12, 303244) The possibility for fraud, too, is reduced, where there is desire for tolerable honesty.
('65', 175, 1, 13, 303333) No constitution that human intelligence can devise will ever be foolproof or knave proof.
('65', 175, 1, 14, 303423) Another change of importance is that delegates themselves become the A. I. C. C. members for the year, thus obviating the necessity for election of an A. I. C. C. and delegates from their provinces become the Provincial Congress Committee members in their respective provinces.
('65', 175, 1, 15, 303701) Thus I have combined three elections in one and ensured continuity of work.
('65', 175, 1, 16, 303777) Then there is the amendment making Calcutta a separate province When I was in Calcutta, it was suggested to me that I should induce the Working Committee to propose the amendment.
('65', 175, 1, 17, 303957) If the idea commends itself to Congressmen, the same facility may be extended to some other cities.
('65', 175, 1, 18, 304057) The experiment has worked well in Bombay.
('65', 175, 1, 19, 304099) There is a proposal to replace the new A. I. C. C. by 1,000 members elected by the delegates who will attend the Congress.
('65', 175, 1, 20, 304222) If this suggestion is fantastic or too hastily conceived, it will have to be
('65', 176, 0, 1, 304299) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 177
('65', 176, 1, 2, 304348) withdrawn.
('65', 176, 1, 3, 304359) But seeing that we might not have another session of the Congress before the beginning of 1936, I thought that it would be better if the change was inaugurated by a more representative A. I. C. C. delegates assembled will have to divide themselves into provincial blocks and each block will elect, for the present, its quota according to the existing proportion.
('65', 176, 1, 4, 304722) Congressmen will note, too, that in the amendment there is no provision for the taluk and district committees.
('65', 176, 1, 5, 304833) This is a deliberate omission.
('65', 176, 1, 6, 304864) The duty of creating some organization in taluks and districts devolves upon the Provincial Congress Committees, which will appoint committees or agencies or have committees elected in accordance with the spirit of the amendments, i.e., by dividing districts and taluks into constituencies or circles for the purpose of electing committees, which must necessarily be small.
('65', 176, 1, 7, 305238) At present, provincial organizations contain an unwieldy number.
('65', 176, 1, 8, 305303) The result has been much cry and little wool.
('65', 176, 1, 9, 305349) I may note two more important changes.
('65', 176, 1, 10, 305388) The Congress has always insisted, in resolutions, on the use of Hindi in the conduct of its business, but members have not, in any appreciable measure, responded to their own oft repeated resolutions.
('65', 176, 1, 11, 305589) I have sought, therefore, to introduce a slight education test by requiring every applicant for membership to sign his or her name in Devanagari or the Urdu script.
('65', 176, 1, 12, 305754) This much can be learned in one hour.
('65', 176, 1, 13, 305792) I remember having given no more time to my wife and a 60 year old client for teaching them to sign their names in English script.
('65', 176, 1, 14, 305922) Is it too much to expect an aspirant after Congress membership to give one hour for the sake of the nation?
('65', 176, 1, 15, 306030) The other change contemplated is to regularize the convention of giving the President power of appointing his own colleagues of the Working Committee, including Secretaries and Treasurer.
('65', 176, 1, 16, 306218) The idea is to save time and some degree of vexation.
('65', 176, 1, 17, 306272) Not to accept the recommendation of the President in such a matter would be a vote of no confidence.
('65', 176, 1, 18, 306373) No president can work if his colleagues are imposed upon him.
('65', 176, 1, 19, 306435) Now I come to two other resolutions.
('65', 176, 1, 20, 306472) One is to free the Reception Committee from the burden of elaborate arrangements for entertainments and exhibition.
('65', 176, 1, 21, 306588) These have been, according to the idiosyncrasies of the Reception Committees, entrusted more or less to the All India Spinners’ Association, as they should have been always
('65', 177, 0, 1, 306761) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 177, 1, 2, 306803) entirely left to it.
('65', 177, 1, 3, 306824) I have held special views about exhibitions which I do not wish to reiterate here.
('65', 177, 1, 4, 306907) The resolution I have suggested regularizes the usually held convention.
('65', 177, 1, 5, 306980) The idea behind my suggestion is that the primary and only function of the Reception Committee should be to make the annual session of the Congress a thorough success from the practical business point of view.
('65', 177, 1, 6, 307190) The present mode makes it impossible for important village or district centres to invite the Congress.
('65', 177, 1, 7, 307293) The result has been that its educative influence has never travelled outside the principal cities.
('65', 177, 1, 8, 307392) There is no reason whatsoever why the Congress should not be able to meet even in a village.
('65', 177, 1, 9, 307485) If they have business ability, the village that invites the Congress will financially not only not lose but gain.
('65', 177, 1, 10, 307599) There are many important stations on the railway line throughout India, where the Congress can easily meet without the slightest inconvenience to its members.
('65', 177, 1, 11, 307758) All this can only happen when we develop the instinct for identifying ourselves with the masses and desire to know them and their wants and to appreciate the beauty of village life, when it is shorn of the squalor and poverty that make it what it is today in India.
('65', 177, 1, 12, 308024) That brings me to the last resolution.
('65', 177, 1, 13, 308063) That resolution seeks to bring into being an association that will look after village industries.
('65', 177, 1, 14, 308161) I have named the spirit behind it, cent per cent swadeshi.
('65', 177, 1, 15, 308220) What goes under the name swadeshi is no doubt good enough but that swadeshi is bound to make progress without any effort on the part of the Congress.
('65', 177, 1, 16, 308370) Special effort was, in the early stages, necessary when the deliberate fashion was to despise everything that was swadeshi, and when it was a mark of civilization, if not also of patriotism, to adopt foreign manners and customs and to use fashionable foreign articles.
('65', 177, 1, 17, 308639) I well remember my student days when we, the students, used to look with admiration at the fashionable dresses of our teachers which were made of foreign stuff and were looking forward to the day when we should be able to afford the necessary freedom to be dressed even as they were.
('65', 177, 1, 18, 308923) The Congress can certainly claim to have changed all this and evoked a spirit of swadeshi but it must not rest on its past achievements and move in a circle.
('65', 177, 1, 19, 309081) It has now to penetrate into the villages and not be satisfied with the ability of the cities to manufacture articles of use and luxury, in imitation of the foreign ones.
('65', 177, 1, 20, 309252) It has now to understand which village industry has died and why.
('65', 177, 1, 21, 309318) Whilst the Government has perhaps the largest share in pauperizing the villages, cities, that have developed out of ruin to villages, cannot escape their responsibility for the growing pauperism
('65', 178, 0, 1, 309513) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 179
('65', 178, 1, 2, 309562) of the dumb millions and it is not yet too late to resuscitate villages by organizing their industries as far as possible.
('65', 178, 1, 3, 309685) By so doing, we can surely put many millions of rupees into the pockets of the villagers without much, if any, capital output.
('65', 178, 1, 4, 309812) Let me quote some startling figures.
('65', 178, 1, 5, 309849) The All India Spinners’ Association is serving over 5,000 villages and through them supporting 220,000 spinners and weavers and 20,000 carders.
('65', 178, 1, 6, 309993) During the ten years of its existence, over 2_ crores of rupees have been distributed amongst these villagers.
('65', 178, 1, 7, 310104) In other words, at least that much wealth was produced in the country through the efforts of the Association and the whole of it contributed to the prosperity of villagers, not by destroying any of their industries but by utilizing their idle hours.
('65', 178, 1, 8, 310354) Out of the two and a quarter crores of rupees, three quarters went into the pockets of spinners alone and 95 lakhs of rupees into the pockets of farmers, for cotton which the Association bought for the spinners.
('65', 178, 1, 9, 310566) On an average, these three classes of workers, spinners, weavers and carders, added Rs. 12 per year to their earnings.
('65', 178, 2, 10, 310685) In individual cases, it has been found as much as 43 per cent has been added to the earning of spinners.
('65', 178, 2, 11, 310790) This is not a fairy tale.
('65', 178, 2, 12, 310816) These are figures specially prepared at my instance and can be verified by any research scholar who cares to.
('65', 178, 2, 13, 310926) The figures I have given are an under estimate, but the A. I. S. A. touches the centre of village life.
('65', 178, 2, 14, 311030) I admit that its organization presents little attraction to those who are not saturated with the village spirit, but the organization which I have now in view presents varied scope for Indian talent.
('65', 178, 2, 15, 311230) Some of the perishing industries must be revived, if villagers are to live.
('65', 178, 2, 16, 311306) I am quite convinced that some of these village industries can be revived and are worth reviving.
('65', 178, 2, 17, 311404) With a little scientific research and a little organizing ability the proposed new association can do a vast amount of work, if, of course, it has the backing of the people, which will be the main capital it will start with.
('65', 178, 2, 18, 311629) If such an association is to succeed, it must be in the hands of those who have some knowledge of the work and abundant faith in their mission and have love for the villagers.
('65', 178, 2, 19, 311805) It must be autonomous like the A. I. S. A. A political, democratic organization like the Congress cannot meddle with the work of experts, without spoiling their work and damaging the prestige of the Congress.
('65', 178, 2, 20, 312014) I, therefore, strongly recommend the adoption of the
('65', 178, 3, 21, 312067) 1 The Bombay Chronicle, 16 l0 1934, here adds: “Roughly this means a 20 per cent addition to their annual earning.”
('65', 179, 0, 1, 312183) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 179, 1, 2, 312225) resolution for creating an All India Village Industries Association.
('65', 179, 1, 3, 312294) The exhibition that I have referred to in my resolution regarding the Reception Committee contemplates the exhibition of the result of the activities of the All India Village Industries Association as now contemplated.
('65', 179, 1, 4, 312513) The two together will bring before the public the marvellous result that can be produced through the industries of villagers in their own homes.
('65', 179, 1, 5, 312658) It is my certain conviction that if the so called higher classes will but identify themselves with the so called lower classes and lend them the support of their intelligence and ability, India can become a land flowing with milk and honey and can also achieve her economic independence without deadly war, either with the Government or with the capitalists.
('65', 179, 1, 6, 313017) Political independence will follow as a matter of course, without the intervention of civil disobedience.
('65', 179, 1, 7, 313123) The vital amendments of the constitution and the two resolutions have all been conveyed in that spirit and no other.
('65', 179, 1, 8, 313240) For me, complete independence of India is an impossible dream without the higher classes merging themselves in those millions who are miscalled the lower classes.
('65', 179, 1, 9, 313403) And I would like to examine all the three resolutions in that spirit and no other.
('65', 179, 2, 10, 313486) APPENDIX
('65', 179, 3, 11, 313495) The following are the proposed amendments to the constitution: 1. Any person over the age of 18 years, who believes in Article I of this constitution, shall, on making a written declaration and presenting an application in the form hereto and on payment of four annas, be entitled to be placed on the register of Congress members, kept at any office duly authorized thereto —within his own district.
('65', 179, 3, 12, 313895) 1. (a) The application shall be presented in duplicate and may be handed in personally or sent by post or messenger.
('65', 179, 3, 13, 314012) 2. It shall state in full, name, age, sex, occupation and address (stating distinctly village, taluk, district and province) of the applicant and shall have been duly signed in his own or her handwriting in Devanagari or Urdu character.
('65', 179, 3, 14, 314249) 3. On receiving the application and on finding it to be in order, the registering officer shall file the application marking on it the date of receipt, serial number and such other particulars as may be prescribed, and shall send one of the duplicates to the Provincial Headquarters.
('65', 180, 0, 1, 314533) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 181
('65', 180, 1, 2, 314582) 4. An applicant, on being enrolled, shall receive a certificate of membership as per schedule hereto and printed on durable paper, either in the language of the province in which the applicant resides or in Hindi, in Devanagari or Urdu script.
('65', 180, 1, 3, 314826) 5. (a) No member shall be entitled to vote at an election of members of any Congress committee, unless he shall have been continuously on the Congress register for six months prior to the date of election.
('65', 180, 1, 4, 315032) (b) A member shall be entitled to vote or be eligible for an office only within the registration area mentioned in his certificate.
('65', 180, 1, 5, 315164) 6. In addition to the existing provinces, the city of Calcutta shall be constituted an independent Congress province.
('65', 180, 1, 6, 315282) 7. In the case of towns and villages having a population of 2,000 or more inhabitants, the Provincial Congress Committee concerned shall divide it into suitable circles, provided that no circle shall contain less than 1,000 inhabitants.
('65', 180, 1, 7, 315519) Each such circle shall constitute a village.
('65', 180, 1, 8, 315564) 8. The delegation to the Congress shall be reduced from 6,000 to not more than 1,000 and shall be in proportion of one to every 1,000 or more members on the Congress rolls, kept in the several provinces.
('65', 180, 1, 9, 315768) 9. (a) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall report by letter or wire to the Working Committee the total strength of the original members of not less than six months standing, in terms of Article 5(a).
('65', 180, 1, 10, 315973) Each report must reach the office of the Working Committee on or before the date and time fixed by the Working Committee in that behalf.
('65', 180, 1, 11, 316110) (b) Only the members so reported shall be entitled to vote at election of delegates in that province and in case of failure to report in time, the province may be disentitled to elect its delegates.
('65', 180, 1, 12, 316309) 10. On receipt of figures for total number of eligible voters, the Working Committee shall fix dates for the election of delegates and the proportion for each province, in accordance with their strength of membership, and call upon the provincial committees to proceed with the election of their quota of delegates.
('65', 180, 1, 13, 316625) All elections shall take place according to single transferable vote.
('65', 180, 1, 14, 316695) 11. Thereupon each province shall be divided into as many constituencies as would give five delegates to each constituency.
('65', 180, 1, 15, 316819) 12. No village or circle shall have voting unless it has at least ten duly qualified members on its roll.
('65', 181, 0, 1, 316925) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 181, 1, 2, 316967) 13. No one, not being a duly qualified voter on any of the registers, in his constituency, shall offer himself for election as delegate.
('65', 181, 1, 3, 317104) 14. Each province shall complete its elections on or before the time appointed by the Working Committee.
('65', 181, 1, 4, 317209) 15. A complete certified list of delegates shall reach the office of the Working Committee not later than the date fixed by the Working Committee.
('65', 181, 1, 5, 317356) 16. Delegates so elected shall constitute a provincial quota of the A. I. C. C. of the Congress, as also the P. C. C. of that province, and shall represent the respective organizations as from the date of the annual session of the Congress till the commencement of the next following session.
('65', 181, 1, 6, 317649) The whole of the Congress delegates shall constitute the A. I. C. C. 17. The A. I. C. C. shall meet at least once again during the period before the next session and oftener if required by the Working Committee or by a joint requisition addressed to the Working Committee by not less than 100 members.
('65', 181, 2, 7, 317951) ELECTION TO A. I. C. C.
('65', 181, 3, 8, 317975) 18. (a) For the period following the current session of the Congress, an A. I. C. C. containing 1,000 members shall be elected by the existing delegates and they shall replace the existing A. I. C. C. and the several P. C. Cs.
('65', 181, 3, 9, 318202) The number of delegates allotted to each province shall be according to its existing quota.
('65', 181, 3, 10, 318294) Delegates shall vote only for representatives of their own provinces.
('65', 181, 3, 11, 318364) (b) The Working Committee shall forthwith proceed to form the new province of Calcutta and a Provincial Committee for it out of the Bengal P. C. C. 19. No Provincial Congress Committee and no subordinate Committee shall be reconsidered by the Working Committee, unless it has complied with all the conditions laid down in this constitution or any rules framed thereunder by the Working Committee.
('65', 181, 3, 12, 318761) 20. On failure on the part of any provincial organization to function in terms of the constitution, the Working Committee may form one to carry on Congress work in that province.
('65', 181, 3, 13, 318940) 21. The Working Committee shall appoint one or more Inspectors to examine the records, papers and account books of all
('65', 182, 0, 1, 319059) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 183
('65', 182, 1, 2, 319108) Congress organizations which shall furnish all information and give to Inspectors access to offices and records.
('65', 182, 1, 3, 319221) 22. The Working Committee shall have the power to frame rules and issue instructions in matters not provided for in the constitution and for the proper working of the constitution.
('65', 182, 1, 4, 319402) 23. The President shall select from among delegates members of the Working Committee including Secretaries and Treasurers for his year of office.
('65', 182, 2, 5, 319548) ALL INDIA VILLAGE INDUSTRIES ASSOCIATION Whereas organizations claiming to be swadeshi have sprung up all over the country with and without the assistance of Congressmen, whereas much confusion has arisen in the public mind as to the true nature of swadeshi, whereas the aim of the Congress has been from its inception progressive identification with the masses, whereas village reorganization and village reconstruction is one of the items in the Congress constructive programme, whereas such reconstruction necessarily implies revival and encouragement of dead or dying village industries, besides the central industry, hand spinning, and whereas this work is possible only through concentrated special effort unaffected by and independent of the political activities of the Congress, Mr. Kumarappa is hereby authorized to form under the aegis of the Congress and as part of its activities, an autonomous organization under the advice and guidance of Gandhiji called the All India Village Industries Association with power to frame its own constitution, to raise funds and to perform such acts as may be considered necessary for the advancement of its objects.
('65', 182, 3, 6, 320711) FUNCTION OF RECEPTION COMMITTEE Whereas, under the vital changes made in the constitution, the annual function will be wholly occupied with serious business before it, there shall be no distraction inside the enclosure containing the central pandal and out houses and whereas it is desirable to free the Reception Committee from the burden of making elabo rate arrangements for entertainments and providing spectacular demonstrations, the work of organizing exhibitions and spectacular demonstrations shall be entrusted to the All India Spinners’ Association and the All India Village Industries’ Association, which bodies shall organize them so as to combine instruction with entertainment for the benefit of the people flocking from villages.
('65', 182, 3, 7, 321456) The Hindu, 16 10 1934

('65', 183, 1, 2, 321520) 234. LETTER TO DR.
('65', 183, 1, 3, 321539) D. S. SARDESAI October 15, 1934
('65', 183, 2, 4, 321571) DEAR DR.
('65', 183, 2, 5, 321580) SARDESAI, I thank you for your letter.
('65', 183, 2, 6, 321619) I have had a talk with Jamnalalji, and he tells me that the Ruiya Charities Trust is not yet in operation.
('65', 183, 2, 7, 321726) But when it is, Jamnalalji says that he would undoubtedly bear your hospital in mind.
('65', 183, 2, 8, 321812) But he wants me to warn you against building any hope on it just now.
('65', 183, 2, 9, 321882) Little Sumitra 1 is living on milk, fruit and some non starchy vegetables such as marrow, green leaves and the like.
('65', 183, 2, 10, 321999) Will you please tell me if it is necessary for her to add anything to this diet?
('65', 183, 2, 11, 322080) I ask this question because her grandmother wrote to say that you had advised that she should take ordinary food.
('65', 183, 2, 12, 322194) She was taking that food before, but she has always been constipated.
('65', 183, 2, 13, 322264) What is more, she has had fever off and on.
('65', 183, 2, 14, 322308) I then put her on the diet she is now having and it seems to have suited her well.
('65', 183, 2, 15, 322391) There was an interruption only for one day.
('65', 183, 2, 16, 322435) She had a little chapati, and the next day she developed high fever.
('65', 183, 2, 17, 322504) I stopped the chapati and the fever stopped and has not returned since.
('65', 183, 2, 18, 322576) If you do not hold it absolutely necessary for her to have bread, rice and dal, I would far rather not take the risk and let her go on with as much milk and fruit as she can take.
('65', 183, 2, 19, 322756) Once more thanking you for the attention you are giving her,
('65', 183, 3, 20, 322817) Yours sincerely,
('65', 183, 4, 21, 322834) D. S. SARDESAI, L.R.C.P. & S. OPHTHALMIC SURGEON SANDHURST ROAD, GIRGAUM, BOMBAY

('65', 186, 10, 19, 326061) 242. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('65', 186, 11, 20, 326091) October 17, 1934
('65', 186, 12, 21, 326108) HARILAL,
('65', 186, 13, 22, 326117) You are constantly in my thoughts.
('65', 186, 13, 23, 326152) If I had time, I would go on inflicting long letters on you.
('65', 186, 13, 24, 326213) If the change that you have described endures, a painful episode in my life would end and I would be extremely happy in this the last stage of my life.
('65', 186, 13, 25, 326365) I do not wish that you should do anything beyond your strength.
('65', 186, 13, 26, 326429) Only as much as your reason and heart accept will endure and seem natural.
('65', 186, 13, 27, 326504) I am sure that if you followed rules of diet, etc., you would be completely all right.
('65', 186, 13, 28, 326591) Do not regard yourself as an old man.
('65', 186, 13, 29, 326629) I would not be pained if you could do nothing, but I would certainly be pained if you were to break your word to me or do
('65', 187, 0, 1, 326751) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 187, 1, 2, 326793) anything which might amount to breach of trust with anybody.
('65', 187, 1, 3, 326854) At the moment, it is I who trust you most.
('65', 187, 1, 4, 326897) Others, that is Ba, Ramdas, Devdas, Kanti, etc., are less hopeful for they have memories of bitter experiences.
('65', 187, 1, 5, 327009) I have them, too, but I had never given up hope about you, and always believed that one day you would be reformed.
('65', 187, 1, 6, 327124) I believe that that day has come now.
('65', 187, 1, 7, 327162) May God help you.
('65', 187, 1, 8, 327180) Write to me and give me exact details of your debts and the names of the parties to whom you owe them.
('65', 187, 1, 9, 327283) I wish to help you as much.
('65', 187, 1, 10, 327311) as I can consistently with my dharma.
('65', 187, 1, 11, 327349) Do you have to pay interest on the loans?
('65', 187, 1, 12, 327391) I see that you have not been able to give up smoking.
('65', 187, 1, 13, 327445) So long as you find it absolutely necessary to smoke, you may do so as if you were taking medicine.
('65', 187, 1, 14, 327545) Perhaps you do not know that it is not in the least difficult to give up smoking.
('65', 187, 1, 15, 327627) It can be done by adopting a simple diet.
('65', 187, 1, 16, 327669) What do you eat?
('65', 187, 1, 17, 327686) Are you ready to make changes in your diet?
('65', 187, 1, 18, 327730) I had a long letter from Maneklal.
('65', 187, 1, 19, 327765) He says that you are afraid of temptations in Rajkot.
('65', 187, 1, 20, 327819) If there is the slightest truth in that, let me know.
('65', 187, 1, 21, 327873) Have no hesitation at all in telling me the exact truth.
('65', 187, 1, 22, 327930) Write to me frankly and open out your heart as you would do to a very intimate friend.
('65', 187, 1, 23, 328017) You made many friends in the past.
('65', 187, 1, 24, 328052) Forget now the harm that those friendships did you.
('65', 187, 1, 25, 328104) Now regard me as your only friend.
('65', 187, 1, 26, 328139) That will certainly do you no harm.
('65', 187, 1, 27, 328175) And, moreover, there is a Supreme Friend between you and me, who dwells in our hearts and, therefore, knows our thoughts.
('65', 187, 1, 28, 328297) I very much wish to send for you here and keep you with me.
('65', 187, 1, 29, 328357) But my condition is quite peculiar just now.
('65', 187, 1, 30, 328402) I don’t enjoy a moment’s leisure.
('65', 187, 1, 31, 328436) I rise up at 2.30 every morning.
('65', 187, 1, 32, 328469) Today I rose at 1.45. It is nearing 3.30 now.
('65', 187, 1, 33, 328515) If I called you, I would feel tempted to talk with you, which, however, I cannot afford to do.
('65', 187, 1, 34, 328610) I can’t stop thinking about you all the times, though.
('65', 187, 1, 35, 328665) Maybe, father’s love doesn’t fall away from even a devotee of Mother Gita, or perhaps the Gita teaches that I should be thus concerned with you.
('65', 187, 1, 36, 328810) Be that as it may.
('65', 187, 1, 37, 328829) If you have no fear just now of being overcome by temptations, remain there for the time being and learn spinning on the takli, etc., thoroughly.
('65', 187, 1, 38, 328975) If you are not keeping a diary, start doing so.
('65', 187, 1, 39, 329023) A letter for Manu is enclosed.
('65', 187, 1, 40, 329054) Ramdas is fairly well.
('65', 187, 1, 41, 329077) He is still in hospital, though.
('65', 187, 1, 42, 329110) There is no fever, but he has not regained strength.

('65', 192, 12, 21, 335883) 254. FOR HARIJANS’ SAKE
('65', 192, 13, 22, 335907) A correspondent asks:
('65', 192, 14, 23, 335929) Why do you insist on sacrificial spinning or self spinning?
('65', 192, 14, 24, 335989) Sacrificial spinning is spinning to give away.
('65', 192, 14, 25, 336036) Self spinning is to convert your own yarn into khadi for personal use.
('65', 192, 14, 26, 336107) In either case, you take away something from the
('65', 193, 0, 1, 336156) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 193, 1, 2, 336198) mouth of the poor spinner, whom you call the lowliest paid worker.
('65', 193, 1, 3, 336265) In sacrificial spinning, you do serve the poor a little by assisting to lower the price of khadi.
('65', 193, 1, 4, 336363) In the other, it is sheer snatching the bread from a poor spinner’s mouth.
('65', 193, 1, 5, 336438) This would be partly or wholly true, if spinning had become universal.
('65', 193, 1, 6, 336509) But today there are some Harijans whose wage earning capacity has been reduced by 50 per cent because they, being weavers, have no hand spun yarn to weave from.
('65', 193, 1, 7, 336670) They are now trying to eke out a precarious living anyhow.
('65', 193, 1, 8, 336729) These would not be reduced to this sad condition, if there was sacrificial spinning going on in the country on any large scale.
('65', 193, 1, 9, 336857) I have already stated 1 in these columns how in Orissa representatives of nearly ten thousand weavers, who are almost (because unclassified) Harijans, were starving for want of work, which is the same thing as saying want of hand spun yarn.
('65', 193, 1, 10, 337098) It is useless to say that they can weave mill spun yarn.
('65', 193, 1, 11, 337155) These ten thousand weavers were doing it.
('65', 193, 1, 12, 337197) But, owing to Japanese competition, the demand for hand woven mill spun cloth has considerably decreased.
('65', 193, 1, 13, 337303) It is possible for khadi weavers to find a local market for their khadi, not for hand woven cloth of mill spun yarn.
('65', 193, 1, 14, 337420) Time was when there was an abundance of hand spun yarn because there were hunderds, if not thousands, of sacrificial spinners, and there was a dearth of weavers.
('65', 193, 1, 15, 337582) Now sacrificial spinning has gone out of vogue, and there is practically a plethora of weavers who would gladly weave hand spun yarn.
('65', 193, 1, 16, 337716) Therefore, for a long time to come and so long as there is demand for khadi on the market and until spinning has become so general as to supply the demand, both sacrificial and self spinning have a definite place in national economy.
('65', 193, 1, 17, 337950) It means definite, tangible service of the poor and, among them, specially Harijans.
('65', 193, 1, 18, 338035) Moreover, such spinning, seeing that it has to be done by intelligent, educated men and women, becomes allied to art and thus admits of great development.
('65', 193, 1, 19, 338190) The marvellous improvements that have taken place in the wheel and its accessories, the handgin and the carding bow, are all due to the interest that the educated middle class men and women have taken in the movement.
('65', 193, 1, 20, 338408) All the readers of Harijan do not know that the Secretary 2 of the A. I. S. A. is an M. A. and the son of a distinguished and successful banker of Bombay, that
('65', 193, 2, 21, 338568) 1 Vide “Will they do it?”, 25 5 1934. 2 Shankerlal Banker
('65', 194, 0, 1, 338626) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 195
('65', 194, 1, 2, 338675) its President 1 is one of the ablest businessmen India has produced, that the controller of the khadi organization in Tamil Nad is an equally distinguished ex lawyer 2, that the organizers in Bengal are an able physician 3 and an able chemist 4, and in U. P. an ex Principal 5 of a national college.
('65', 194, 1, 3, 338975) These are but a few names, out of many such I can give, who have dedicated themselves to the service of Daridranarayana, through khadi.
('65', 194, 1, 4, 339111) But for this band of devotees, the substantial progress that it has made would have been impossible, and the half crore rupees that have been distributed among, say, two hundred and fifty thousand workers, not as doles but wages for honest labour, during the years that the spinning movement has been going on, would not have been distributed.
('65', 194, 1, 5, 339455) In no other or better manner could such quick work have been done than through the wheel.
('65', 194, 1, 6, 339545) It has brought the lowliest in living touch with some of the most cultured men and women in the country, it has brought a ray of light into dark hovels, it has put heart into sinking bodies, it has provided milk for thousands of milkless children, enabled villagers who would care to have automatic famine insurance, reduced idleness and reclaimed thousands from a beggar’s life.
('65', 194, 1, 7, 339925) And yet the work is only in its beginning stages.
('65', 194, 1, 8, 339975) The workers are too few.
('65', 194, 1, 9, 340000) Those that are need more consecration and greater concentration.
('65', 194, 1, 10, 340065) Many more hundreds can be absorbed by this national and humanitarian effort.
('65', 194, 1, 11, 340142) Therefore, it is wrong to say that sacrificial spinning or selfspinning is harmful to the wage spinners.
('65', 194, 1, 12, 340247) It is the peremptory duty of all who can to devote at least half an hour daily to spin for the sake of Harijans—the outcastes of India.
('65', 194, 2, 13, 340383) Harijan, 19 10 1934
('65', 194, 3, 14, 340403) 255. NOTES
('65', 194, 4, 15, 340414) A SEVAK’S DIFFICULTY
('65', 194, 5, 16, 340435) A Lyallpur correspondent asks the following pertinent questions:
('65', 194, 6, 17, 340500) 1 G. D. Birla 2 C. Rajagopalachari 3 Dr. B. C. Roy 4 Satis Chandra Das Gupta 5 Acharya Jugal Kishore
('65', 195, 0, 1, 340601) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 195, 1, 2, 340643) (1) In many chawls where the Harijans are settled, there is a Muslim or a Sikh population.
('65', 195, 1, 3, 340734) There are practically no Hindus, or if there be two or three Hindu shopkeepers, they are exclusively under the thumb and control of those zamindars, whose orders they cannot disobey or whose displeasure they cannot incur.
('65', 195, 1, 4, 340956) Thus, those Hindus are incapable of rendering any help to the Harijans in supplying water to them.
('65', 195, 1, 5, 341055) How to solve this difficulty?
('65', 195, 2, 6, 341085) (2) There is an anti propaganda of ‘Adi Dharmis’, who wean them away from the Hindu society.
('65', 195, 2, 7, 341178) How to meet or counteract that propaganda?
('65', 195, 3, 8, 341221) (3) There is an untouchability within several sects of untouchables.
('65', 195, 4, 9, 341290) As to the first question, the first obvious step is to plead with the Muslims and Sikhs to permit the Harijans to use the common well.
('65', 195, 4, 10, 341425) The second is, side by side with the method of persuasion or after its failure, for the caste Hindus themselves to supply the necessary quantity of water to Harijans.
('65', 195, 4, 11, 341592) Of course, there is the recourse to the law courts.
('65', 195, 4, 12, 341644) Harijans are by law entitled to use common wells, roads, etc., in the same manner as the rest of the public.
('65', 195, 4, 13, 341753) But this remedy has to be used most sparingly.
('65', 195, 4, 14, 341800) For the second question, nothing but progressive repentance and consequent change on the part of caste Hindus can prevent the growing estrangement between them and the Harijans.
('65', 195, 4, 15, 341978) AdiDharmis are themselves Hindus.
('65', 195, 4, 16, 342012) Their separation is a revolt against caste Hindus for the latter’s oppression.
('65', 195, 4, 17, 342091) They will return to the fold when they see that untouchability has been entirely removed.
('65', 195, 4, 18, 342181) As for the third question, the removal of untouchability as between the various sects of untouchables will progress almost, if not entirely, in the same ratio as the removal of untouchability on the part of caste Hindus.
('65', 195, 4, 19, 342402) For, the observance of untouchability among untouchables is a direct result of its observance by caste Hindus.
('65', 195, 5, 20, 342513) “DARIDRANARAYANA” AND HARIJAN
('65', 195, 6, 21, 342543) There is a struggle going on between Daridranarayana and Harijan: Which includes the other?
('65', 195, 6, 22, 342635) Thoughtlessly the answer would be, ‘of course, Harijan’.
('65', 195, 6, 23, 342692) But a moment’s reflection shows that Daridranarayana is the larger form.
('65', 195, 6, 24, 342765) Harijans are undoubtedly Daridranarayana but they are ranked the lowest by the well to do.
('65', 196, 0, 1, 342856) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 197
('65', 196, 1, 2, 342905) Hence they are the nearest and dearest to Hara or Hari—God.
('65', 196, 1, 3, 342965) For, has He not called Himself Servant of His servants?
('65', 196, 1, 4, 343021) And whom will He serve most, if not those who are the most neglected by the world?
('65', 196, 1, 5, 343104) Daridranarayana however includes, besides Harijans, all those many millions who are not branded outcastes from their birth.
('65', 196, 1, 6, 343228) Therefore, service of Harijans necessarily includes that of Daridranarayana, but that of Daridranarayana may not always be also service of Harijans.
('65', 196, 1, 7, 343377) Writers for Harijan will, therefore, do well always to bear this distinction in mind.
('65', 196, 1, 8, 343463) For they should remember that the Harijan is a weekly wholly devoted to the Harijan cause and, therefore, excludes everything that has no bearing on that cause either directly or indirectly.
('65', 196, 1, 9, 343654) It is necessary to bear this distinction in mind, since I am devoting its columns freely to many matters which I have appeared to have hitherto excluded from them.
('65', 196, 1, 10, 343818) The fact is that during the hurricane tour I had little leisure to think, as I am now doing, of many efforts at construction, much less to write about them.
('65', 196, 1, 11, 343975) For their allround amelioration, there is limitless scope.
('65', 196, 1, 12, 344034) Do they not represent numerically a large part of humanity and, in point of usefulness, rank perhaps the highest in society?
('65', 196, 1, 13, 344159) Indian humanity would soon disintegrate, if they suddenly ceased to do the work they are doing at present with the brand of the outcaste on their foreheads for reward.
('65', 196, 2, 14, 344327) THE REFORMER’S PRAYER
('65', 196, 3, 15, 344349) A correspondent sends the following apposite prayer from Tagore’s Gitanjali:
('65', 196, 4, 16, 344426) Here is Thy footstool and there rest Thy feet, where live the poorest and lowliest and lost.
('65', 196, 4, 17, 344519) When I try to bow to Thee, my obeisance cannot reach down to the depth where Thy feet rest among the poorest and lowliest and lost.
('65', 196, 4, 18, 344651) Pride can never approach to where Thou walkest in the clothes of the humble among the poorest and lowliest and lost.
('65', 196, 4, 19, 344768) My heart can never find its way to where Thou keepest company with the companionless among the poorest, the lowliest and the lost.
('65', 196, 5, 20, 344899) Harijan, 19 10 1934

('65', 199, 7, 30, 350750) I am looking into the matter.

('65', 199, 7, 32, 350838) I should, however, like to see you adhere to your original assurance.
('65', 199, 7, 33, 350908) I will not readily let the burden of even Rs. 4,000 fall on you.
('65', 199, 7, 34, 350973) If the loss was due to no negligence on our part, I will not hesitate to stretch my hand before you.
('65', 199, 7, 35, 351074) I don’t wish to run the dairy at a loss even for one year.
('65', 199, 7, 36, 351133) Narandas is going through all the accounts.
('65', 199, 7, 37, 351177) In the budget for next year prepared three or four months ago, the aim is indeed to balance the two sides.
('65', 199, 7, 38, 351284) Meanwhile I learnt about the loss of Rs. 4,000. Narandas will now go to Sabarmati and guide me.
('65', 199, 7, 39, 351380) My intention in writing all this is to assure you that, having secured your support in this scheme
('65', 200, 0, 1, 351479) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 201
('65', 200, 1, 2, 351528) 1, I have not become indifferent to the losses.
('65', 200, 1, 3, 351576) It would be against my nature to go on burdening you with losses, however big they may be.
('65', 200, 1, 4, 351667) In all public activities under my charge throughout my life, I have always tried to balance the two sides.
('65', 200, 1, 5, 351774) I do not hesitate to incur a loss when I think it necessary to do so, but then I do it knowingly.
('65', 200, 1, 6, 351872) When conducting research in tanning, or when hoping for profit from Ramachandran lift 2, I did foresee the possibility of loss and had put an outer limit to it.
('65', 200, 1, 7, 352033) I had involved the late Revashankarbhai in the business of the Ramachandran lift and he had to make good Rs. 5,000. The scheme was then withdrawn.
('65', 200, 1, 8, 352180) In tanning, we may still have to continue to put up with losses.
('65', 200, 1, 9, 352245) It is an industry in which it is absolutely necessary that we should take interest.
('65', 200, 1, 10, 352329) Part of the loss in it will be met by Ghanshyamdas.
('65', 200, 1, 11, 352381) Into this modest venture in the service of the cow, I have drawn you.
('65', 200, 1, 12, 352451) It will mean loss of my reputation if you now withdraw.
('65', 200, 1, 13, 352507) I have inflicted this long explanation, which I have done after first accepting your decision, because I do not wish to lose my reputation with you.
('65', 200, 1, 14, 352656) You know very well that I have the utmost admiration for your frankness.
('65', 200, 1, 15, 352729) I don’t mind your decision at all.
('65', 200, 1, 16, 352764) All my business ventures rest wholly on my reputation.
('65', 200, 1, 17, 352819) The paper of bank notes, worthless in itself, is backed by some gold at least.
('65', 200, 1, 18, 352898) The paper of my notes is backed by nothing but Ramanama.
('65', 200, 1, 19, 352955) With whom, therefore, may I plead if not with a man like you?

('65', 202, 9, 21, 356038) 263. NEW LIFE FOR KHADI1
('65', 202, 10, 22, 356063) [Before October 21, 1934]
('65', 202, 11, 23, 356089) Even though khadi is the most powerful means for attaining freedom, our khadi organizations are carrying on the work only as an economic activity.
('65', 202, 11, 24, 356236) An element of democracy can be introduced in
('65', 202, 12, 25, 356281) 1 This is a summary of a discussion with some khadi workers about the need to reorganize khadi work.
('65', 203, 0, 1, 356382) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 203, 1, 2, 356424) these organizations only to a certain extent.
('65', 203, 1, 3, 356470) Conflict and even competition can have a place in democracy.
('65', 203, 1, 4, 356531) But these cannot be permitted in an economic organization.
('65', 203, 1, 5, 356590) Can we think of different or opposing groups in a commercial firm?
('65', 203, 1, 6, 356657) The whole administration of the firm would be thrown out of gear if such a thing happens.
('65', 203, 1, 7, 356747) Moreover, the khadi organizations are not merely economic organizations; they are benevolent institutions too.
('65', 203, 1, 8, 356858) Their aim is not to serve anybody’s selfish interests but to promote public welfare.
('65', 203, 1, 9, 356943) In democracy it is a rule to carry on work by humouring public opinion.
('65', 203, 1, 10, 357015) The aim of our khadi organizations is to attain not merely preya 1
('65', 203, 2, 11, 357082) but sreya 2 for the people.
('65', 203, 2, 12, 357110) Hence, at times they may have to carry on their work independently of the ever shifting public opinion.
('65', 203, 2, 13, 357214) They cannot be allowed to become the means of nurturing individual ambitions.
('65', 203, 2, 14, 357292) While thinking about the reorganization of khadi production you should not forget that in certain matters the economics of khadi and the commonly prevalent economics are poles asunder.
('65', 203, 2, 15, 357477) I am always reminded of one thing which the well known British economist Adam Smith has said in his famous treatise The Wealth of Nations.
('65', 203, 2, 16, 357616) In it he has described some economic laws as universal and absolute.
('65', 203, 2, 17, 357685) Then he has described certain situations which may be an obstacle to the operation of these laws.
('65', 203, 2, 18, 357783) These disturbing factors are the human nature, the human temperament or altruism inherent in it.
('65', 203, 2, 19, 357880) Now, the economics of khadi is just the opposite of it.
('65', 203, 2, 20, 357936) Benevolence which is inherent in human nature is the very foundation of the economics of khadi.
('65', 203, 2, 21, 358032) What Adam Smith has described as pure economic activity based merely on the calculations of profit and loss is a selfish attitude and it is an obstacle to the development of khadi; and it is the function of a champion of khadi to counteract this tendency.
('65', 203, 2, 22, 358288) Hence, the;tactics normally adopted in a profiteering business have no place in khadi activity.
('65', 203, 2, 23, 358384) For instance, cheating, fraud, falsehood, adulteration, exploiting people’s addictions or their baser feelings things practised in mill industries and ordinary trade—are to be completely shunned in khadi activity.
('65', 203, 2, 24, 358598) The policy of paying minimum wages to the weaver or spinner with a view to increasing profits can have no place in khadi activity.
('65', 203, 2, 25, 358729) At the same time, khadi activity cannot be carried on by incurring losses as a result of unpractical attitudes.
('65', 203, 2, 26, 358841) The reason why our khadi organizations incur losses today is the inefficiency of our
('65', 203, 3, 27, 358926) 1 Material welfare 2 Spiritual welfare
('65', 204, 0, 1, 358965) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 205
('65', 204, 1, 2, 359014) workers.
('65', 204, 1, 3, 359023) In khadi activity spinners and other workers get full reward of their labour but the middlemen and organizers get nothing more than their due share.
('65', 204, 1, 4, 359172) Now take the case of standardization, i.e., producing khadi with a uniform policy.
('65', 204, 1, 5, 359255) Such uniformity cannot be expected in khadi.
('65', 204, 1, 6, 359300) Rajagopalchari had once remarked that a poor woman cannot be expected to spin yarn of uniform quality as in a mill.
('65', 204, 1, 7, 359416) She is not a lifeless machine, but a human being.
('65', 204, 1, 8, 359466) She has her own happiness and unhappiness, she has feelings and is subject to illness.
('65', 204, 1, 9, 359553) Sometimes she may not be well, sometimes her child or some other relative.
('65', 204, 1, 10, 359628) may be ill and she may be upset and this cannot but affect the quality of her spinning.
('65', 204, 1, 11, 359716) Unless your heart is made of stone, you must accept her yarn irrespective of its quality provided she does not deliberately spin bad yarn.
('65', 204, 1, 12, 359855) Her yarn must be dear to us, for it has been sanctified by her honest labour.
('65', 204, 1, 13, 359933) A mill product does not have that personal touch.
('65', 204, 1, 14, 359983) Hence, it cannot bring us this spiritual satisfaction.
('65', 204, 1, 15, 360038) Mechanicaly produced goods can merely please the eye, but the art of khadi appeals to our human feelings.
('65', 204, 1, 16, 360144) It touches the heart.
('65', 204, 1, 17, 360166) Outer beauty is a secondary matter in khadi.
('65', 204, 1, 18, 360211) That is why I have protested against the sale of bleached khadi.
('65', 204, 1, 19, 360276) Bleaching increases cost of production, weakens the material and it then becomes difficult to detect any malpractice.
('65', 204, 1, 20, 360394) Our duty is not to indiscriminately pamper the people’s taste, but to canalize it in the proper direction.
('65', 204, 1, 21, 360501) The starch in khadi automatically goes out after two or three washings and it becomes spotlessly white.
('65', 204, 1, 22, 360605) Not only this, but it also acquires a kind of softness which is destroyed by bleaching.
('65', 204, 1, 23, 360693) If the khadi wearer himself undertook these minor processes subsequent to weaving, the cost of khadi would be much less.
('65', 204, 1, 24, 360814) It is up to the khadi experts to think of the best way of inducing people to take up such processes.
('65', 204, 1, 25, 360915) If khadi activity is to be carried on not merely as a business but as a means to uplift the starving masses, we shall have to penetrate the spinner’s home.
('65', 204, 1, 26, 361071) We shall have to persuade him to wear the clothes made from the khadi produced by himself.
('65', 204, 1, 27, 361162) This no doubt means a great reduction in the cost of khadi production; it is also a total saving of the expenditure on sales.
('65', 204, 1, 28, 361288) So far we have been producing khadi, keeping the urban people in view.
('65', 204, 1, 29, 361359) From a negligible beginning khadi sales have reached millions of rupees.
('65', 204, 1, 30, 361432) We now produce many varieities of khadi.
('65', 204, 1, 31, 361473) But all this does not satisfy me.
('65', 204, 1, 32, 361507) My ambition in respect of khadi is very much higher than this.
('65', 204, 1, 33, 361570) It now extends to completely wiping out conditions of starvation from our villages.
('65', 205, 0, 1, 361654) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 205, 1, 2, 361696) can be achieved only when the village people themselves produce khadi and send to the cities whatever remains after local consumption.
('65', 205, 1, 3, 361831) The secret of the power of khadi lies in the fact that it can find customers right in the place of its production.
('65', 205, 1, 4, 361946) It is not necessary to go out anywhere in search of a market for it.
('65', 205, 1, 5, 362015) The proportion of expenditure on management in khadi production pains me.
('65', 205, 1, 6, 362089) We can reduce this expenditure a lot if all the time we keep in view the main purpose of khadi.
('65', 205, 1, 7, 362185) As I have stated earlier, the methods of reducing the cost of production of manufactured goods adopted by the industries that are run for profit cannot be applied in the case of khadi.
('65', 205, 1, 8, 362370) In the case of khadi the use of machinery can be increased only within certain limits.
('65', 205, 1, 9, 362457) But there is no limit to increasing art, skill, efficiency and honesty.
('65', 205, 1, 10, 362529) If we have no faith in these we must wash our hands off khadi.
('65', 205, 1, 11, 362592) If we want to bring down the cost of khadi production, we must retain only the minimum personnel to manage the organization, and these too should be altruistic, and we should dispense with all the intermediaries and brokers.
('65', 205, 1, 12, 362817) As a matter of fact, when the khadi activity has fully developed it would have no need of an outer organization.
('65', 205, 1, 13, 362930) Self sufficiency and self propaganda are the natural characteristics of khadi.
('65', 205, 1, 14, 363009) The science of khadi is still in its infancy.
('65', 205, 1, 15, 363055) It is making steady progress.
('65', 205, 1, 16, 363085) As I go deeper into it, and do research on its laws and understand them, I realize my own limited knowledge of the subject.
('65', 205, 1, 17, 363209) With the exception of China, there is hardly any country in the world having greater resources than ours.
('65', 205, 1, 18, 363315) For today, no other country except China has man power greater than we have.
('65', 205, 1, 19, 363392) But today this wealth of ours is lying unutilized.
('65', 205, 1, 20, 363443) The spinning wheel is a means to put this wealth to use.
('65', 205, 1, 21, 363500) Hitherto we have been carrying on khadi work along proper lines.
('65', 205, 1, 22, 363565) Consequently, we have reached so far.
('65', 205, 1, 23, 363603) Not only was it inevitable, but in the situation that prevailed it alone was relevant and proper.
('65', 205, 1, 24, 363701) The real uphill task is ahead of us.
('65', 205, 1, 25, 363738) For traversing the remaining distance we shall have to follow accordingly higher standards and think of appropriate measures.
('65', 205, 1, 26, 363864) Hence, if Andhradesha aspires to have provi ncial autonomy in the matter of khadi, it can have it for the asking.
('65', 205, 1, 27, 363978) It would not be difficult even to pay up the liabilities of your organization.
('65', 205, 1, 28, 364057) That is why I have no doubt that if you wish to work along the lines I have suggested, you would be able to do it without any hindrance.
('65', 205, 2, 29, 364194) [From Gujarati]
('65', 205, 3, 30, 364210) Harijanbandhu, 21 10 1934
('65', 206, 0, 1, 364236) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 207

('65', 209, 1, 2, 367396) 270. SPEECH AT VITHALBHAI PATEL’S DEATH ANNIVERSARY1
('65', 209, 2, 3, 367449) BOMBAY, October 22, 1934
('65', 209, 3, 4, 367474) I knew Vithalbhai from the time that I came to India in 1915. You would be surprised to know that when I first met him I had no idea that he was a Hindu.
('65', 209, 3, 5, 367628) I later came to know that he made no distinctions between Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and Christians.
('65', 209, 3, 6, 367726) He even dressed like that.
('65', 209, 3, 7, 367753) He used to grow a beard and wear a Turkish cap and a jacket.
('65', 209, 3, 8, 367814) I remained under that impression for a long time.
('65', 209, 3, 9, 367864) Then we met at Godhra in 1917. 2 There I saw him dressed like a fakir.
('65', 209, 3, 10, 367935) A meeting was arranged in the Harijan colony.
('65', 209, 3, 11, 367981) At that time very few Hindus had come there.
('65', 209, 3, 12, 368026) Vithalbhai was one of them.
('65', 209, 3, 13, 368054) In the mean time I came to know that he was a Hindu and Sardar’s elder brother.
('65', 209, 3, 14, 368134) At that time he had come dressed in short dhoti, a paheran 3 and a cap, and so I did not recognize him.
('65', 209, 3, 15, 368238) He burst out laughing.
('65', 209, 3, 16, 368261) After this we came closer day by day.
('65', 209, 3, 17, 368299) I could see that he was a great servant of the country and that he did not care for money, nor accumulated it for personal pleasure.
('65', 209, 3, 18, 368432) I used to hear about his brave work in the Bombay Legislative Assembly.
('65', 209, 3, 19, 368504) After that I also saw his career in the Congress and realized that it was no easy thing to join issue with Vithalbhai.

('65', 219, 1, 3, 390366) hereby authorized to form under the advice and guidance of Mr. Gandhi an association called the All India Village Industries Association, as part of the activities of the Congress.
('65', 219, 2, 4, 390547) The said Association shall work for the revival and en couragement of the said industries and for the moral and physical advancement of the villages and shall have the power to frame its own constitution, to raise funds and perform such acts as may be necessary for the fulfilment of its objects.
('65', 219, 2, 5, 390844) Commending the resolution to the house, Gandhiji said: 2
('65', 219, 3, 6, 390901) During my Harijan tour this year, a large number of people used to come to me to narrate their tales of woe.
('65', 219, 3, 7, 391010) Never before had I travelled as I did during this tour.
('65', 219, 3, 8, 391066) And, in Utkal, I had an extraordinary experience since I was touring on foot.
('65', 219, 3, 9, 391144) There is no limit to the state of unemployment in our seven lac villages.
('65', 219, 3, 10, 391218) The people subsist on agriculture.
('65', 219, 3, 11, 391253) And millions of people suffer losses in agriculture.
('65', 219, 3, 12, 391306) And what can we say about the present state?
('65', 219, 3, 13, 391351) Today the farmers do not produce enough even for the seeds.
('65', 219, 3, 14, 391411) You can hardly find such poverty anywhere else.
('65', 219, 3, 15, 391459) That is also one of the reasons why people disposed of gold worth lacs of rupees.
('65', 219, 3, 16, 391541) This has of course its political reason.
('65', 219, 3, 17, 391582) But the helplessness of the people was also one reason.
('65', 219, 3, 18, 391638) The spinning wheel has emerged to meet this unemployment.
('65', 219, 3, 19, 391696) Apart from India there is perhaps no other country where people depend so completely on agriculture.
('65', 219, 3, 20, 391797) Madhusudan Das had said that village people must be provided with some additional occupation.
('65', 219, 3, 21, 391891) He had gone to Germany and learnt leather work.
('65', 219, 3, 22, 391939) I have always remembered his one remark that those who always work with oxen must have bovine intelligence.
('65', 219, 3, 23, 392047) Our farmers lost their work and became dull minded.
('65', 219, 3, 24, 392099) A friend left a socialist paper with me.

('65', 219, 3, 26, 392168) It says that the people of India are being reduced to subhuman state.

('65', 220, 1, 30, 394296) They will revive the industries that can be revived.

('65', 222, 2, 4, 397689) Gandhiji in replying to the several questions that had arisen from the discussions said that the first amendment wanted that the words “dead and dying” should be deleted from the resolution while the second wanted the replacement of certain words.
('65', 222, 2, 5, 397937) 2 The work of the Association would be to revive the industries that were ruined or dead or were in the state of dying.
('65', 222, 2, 6, 398057) The work as to which of the industries should be revived and which should be allowed to die away was to be left to the Association.
('65', 222, 2, 7, 398189) By the revival of the village industries it was the intention of the resolution not only to help the villages financially but improve them morally and physically as well.
('65', 222, 2, 8, 398360) It was not the intention of the movers of the resolution that the villagers should be exploited, but they wanted to help them.
('65', 222, 2, 9, 398487) The Congress was not going to approach the villagers as anybody’s agents.
('65', 222, 2, 10, 398561) It was the intention of the Congress to find out why people were working for 18 hours, if there were any so working.
('65', 222, 2, 11, 398678) The speaker wanted that everyone would work not more than 9 hours and that could be, done by increasing the earning capacity of the villagers.
('65', 222, 2, 12, 398821) For this the speaker wanted the help of those who were well off and could sacrifice a little more for the sake of the villagers by paying for the articles manufactured by the village artisans.
('65', 222, 2, 13, 399014) Today the condition was such that even if they worked for 18 hours they did not get enough to make both ends meet.
('65', 222, 2, 14, 399129) This could be done by the speaker and others of the Association when they went and mixed with the villagers freely and gained their confidence.
('65', 222, 2, 15, 399273) Continuing, Gandhiji said that his report that would be submitted to the Congress at a future date would be to say what the condition of the village industries was when he took up the work and what it had achieved in so many days.
('65', 222, 2, 16, 399504) For such a work in the seven lacs of villages in India it was necessary that Acharya Kripalanis and Dr. Roys and advocates should work hand in hand.

('65', 224, 2, 23, 404192) I have been trying to persuade the workers that if the capitalists have their gold and silver, we have our hands and feet.

('65', 225, 4, 7, 405830) 274. POLISHED v.
('65', 225, 4, 8, 405847) UNPOLISHED
('65', 225, 5, 9, 405858) In my writing 3 on cent per cent swadeshi, I have shown how some aspects of it can be tackled immediately with benefit to the starving millions both economically and hygienically.
('65', 225, 5, 10, 406038) The richest in the land can share the benefit.
('65', 225, 5, 11, 406085) Thus if rice can be pounded in the villages after the old fashion, the wages will fill the pockets of the rice pounding sisters and the rice eating millions will get some sustenance from the unpolished rice instead of pure starch which the polished rice provides.
('65', 225, 5, 12, 406349) Human greed, which takes no count of the health or the wealth of the people who come under its heels, is responsible for the hideous rice mills one sees in all the rice producing tracts.
('65', 225, 5, 13, 406536) If public opinion was strong, it would make rice mills an impossibility by simply insisting on unpolished rice and appealing to the owners of rice mills to stop a traffic that undermines the health of a whole nation and robs the poor people of an honest means of livelihood.

('65', 226, 0, 1, 407296) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 227
('65', 226, 1, 2, 407345) 275. ‘NOT TO COW BUT TO SCORN?’
('65', 226, 2, 3, 407377) A young Englishman who has lived in Madras for two years writes from his home in Essex: 1
('65', 226, 3, 4, 407467) I believe that, of the Hindu population, untouchables are in the majority.
('65', 226, 3, 5, 407542) Of course I may be wrong but if correct, then, I consider the most effective measure to adopt in righting and preventing the grievous humiliations put upon this great body of people is not to approach the perpetrators (high castes) but the development of a ‘line of defiance’ through the untouchables themselves.
('65', 226, 4, 6, 407855) The forming of a Brotherhood amongst themselves that will encourage the development of an existence, entirely independent of those to whom they appear to be objectionable, should, by degrees, build up a “strong point” and cause these now humbled folk not to cow, but to scorn and ignore the spurning and lashes now directed at them.
('65', 226, 5, 7, 408188) The writer evidently does not know that there is a cult among Harijans which is trying to do exactly what he advises me to do.
('65', 226, 5, 8, 408315) But that way does not lie the salvation of Harijans, certainly not of caste Hindus.
('65', 226, 5, 9, 408399) The logical result of what is preached by the correspondent must be another problem akin to the Hindu Muslim one, only much more intense.
('65', 226, 5, 10, 408537) That way is the way of hate which is violence.
('65', 226, 5, 11, 408584) The way I am trying to follow is the way of love which is non violence.
('65', 226, 5, 12, 408656) Having belonged to the oppressor class and having by choice made the attempt to become one with the oppressed, I have learnt that the true way of securing justice is to inculcate mutual respect, in other words, to evoke the spirit of equality or brotherhood in the place of that of superiority and inferiority.
('65', 226, 5, 13, 408967) This can best be done by the ‘superior’ class being induced to descend from its fancied height.
('65', 226, 5, 14, 409063) The so called ‘inferior, class has to be taught, not to scorn, but to be induced to shed the fear that is born of a consciousness of inferiority.
('65', 226, 5, 15, 409209) Therefore the Harijan Sevak Sangh is performing the double duty of asking the caste Hindus, on the one hand, to repent of the injustice that they have done to the Harijans and is working, on the other hand, among the Harijans by spreading education among them and by bringing to their notice the evils that oppression always breeds
('65', 226, 6, 16, 409541) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('65', 227, 0, 1, 409578) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 227, 1, 2, 409620) among the oppressed.
('65', 227, 1, 3, 409641) To deprive a man of his natural liberty and to deny to him the ordinary amenities of life is worse than starving the body.
('65', 227, 1, 4, 409764) It is starvation of the soul—the dweller in the body.
('65', 227, 1, 5, 409818) Harijans are a powerful illustration of this process of starvation of the soul.
('65', 227, 1, 6, 409898) No amount of mere literary education or even economic betterment will restore the lost dignity of man.
('65', 227, 1, 7, 410001) That restoration can only come when self realization comes.
('65', 227, 1, 8, 410061) This realization will not come without repentance on the part of the superior class.
('65', 227, 1, 9, 410146) Superiority complex and inferiority complex are two faces of the same coin.
('65', 227, 1, 10, 410222) Both are equally bad.
('65', 227, 1, 11, 410244) Both require treatment.
('65', 227, 1, 12, 410268) Mere transference of scorn from the ‘superior’ caste Hindu to the ‘inferior’ Harijan does not remedy the disease, it only aggravates it.
('65', 227, 1, 13, 410405) ‘Not to cow’ is sound advice.
('65', 227, 1, 14, 410435) But ‘to scorn’ is as bad as cowing.
('65', 227, 1, 15, 410471) ‘Love one another’ is, therefore, the only advice an impartial observer can give.
('65', 227, 1, 16, 410553) And I hope that the writer of the letter sees the weakness of the formula.

('65', 227, 3, 18, 410648) 276. SPEECH AT SUBJECTS COMMITTEE MEETING, A.I.C.C.
('65', 227, 4, 19, 410700) October 26, 1934
('65', 227, 5, 20, 410717) You have in your affection misread the whole of my position.
('65', 227, 6, 21, 410778) If you have given me the position of a general commanding an army, you must allow that general to judge whether he serves the army by being at its head or whether he serves the army by retiring and giving place to lieutenants who have served well.
('65', 227, 6, 22, 411026) It is always the wisest thing for the general to swing to power or office or withhold that power that came to him unsought, because there are occasions when generals have been found to consider themselves unequal to hold the reins, and in the interests of the army, the interests of the cause for which the army and its chief are fighting to give up the command.

('65', 236, 6, 17, 433218) Mahatma Gandhi explained the changes that had been made in the constitution.

('65', 236, 6, 19, 433440) The speaker had not the courage himself to suggest the change, but since some of the members of the sub committee suggested the change, he accepted it.

('65', 237, 6, 21, 436541) This would be nearly half of the present number.
('65', 237, 6, 22, 436590) According to Gandhiji, it was not a bad change.
('65', 237, 6, 23, 436638) The A. I. C. C. became a still more business like and responsible body.
('65', 237, 6, 24, 436710) Instead of the suggested A. I. C. C. of l,000 members, the A. I. C. C. had been reduced to 166.
