('65', 239, 4, 9, 440540) Mahatma Gandhi submitted the following report to the Subjects Committee:
('65', 239, 5, 10, 440613) Pursuant to your yesterday’s resolution, we have considered the Working Committee’s recommendations for the amendment of the Congress constitution and beg to submit our draft as annexed herewith.
('65', 239, 5, 11, 440809) We are happy to state that we have been able to achieve complete unanimity.
('65', 239, 6, 12, 440885) The main alterations made by us in the Working Committee’s draft may be summarized as follows:
('65', 239, 7, 13, 440980) 1. In Article II instead of the words “subject to the previous approval of the Working Committee” we have substituted the words, “in accordance with the rules framed by it (as Provincial Congress Committee) in that behalf and approved by the Working Committee”.
('65', 239, 8, 14, 441242) 2. In Article III, we have made minor alterations; such as the change in the names of the provinces U. P. and C. P. (Hindustani) — into Hind and Mahakoshal respectively and the deletion of the last clause in C1. (c) which was superfluous.
('65', 239, 9, 15, 441481) 3. In Article IV we have incorporated the labour franchise passed by the Subjects Committee with a slight verbal change so as to bring it in harmony with the khadi clause.
('65', 239, 9, 16, 441653) We have also added a new and important clause to this Article as
('65', 240, 0, 1, 441718) VOL.65: 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 241
('65', 240, 1, 2, 441767) follows:
('65', 240, 2, 3, 441776) No person being a member of any elective Congress Committee shall be a member of any similar committee of a communal organization the object or programme of which involves political activities which are in the opinion of the Working Committee anti national and in conflict with those of the Congress.
('65', 240, 3, 4, 442077) 4. In Article V, we have changed the original scheme of delegates in the following manner:
('65', 240, 4, 5, 442168) (l) The number of delegates has been increased from l,000 to 2,000, each representing a constituency of not less than 500 instead of l,000 primary members.
('65', 240, 5, 6, 442324) (2) The urban area will be entitled to have not more than 511 delegates in the aggregate and the rural area not more than 1,489. No province shall have more than its proportion of delegates that would belong to it, if it was fixed on the population basis as heretofore and every province shall be entitled to not less than ten, even though the number of its primary members may be inadequate to send that number.
('65', 240, 6, 7, 442737) (3) The claims of the city of Bombay have been recognized by giving it a maximum of 21 delegates: for providing for this weightage we have been obliged to deprive the rural area of 11 delegates.
('65', 240, 7, 8, 442932) (4) Where the delegates of a province exceed 100, the Provincial Congress Committee shall consist of the All India Congress Committee members for that province plus those elected by the delegates to bring up the total to 100. Where the delegates are less than 100, the whole will constitute the Provincial Congress Committee.
('65', 240, 8, 9, 443258) (5) The President of the Congress is to be elected by the delegates for the ensuing session in the following manner.
('65', 240, 9, 10, 443375) Soon after the election of delegates they should meet under the Chairmanship of the President of the Provincial Congress Committee and elect the President, the Chairman registering the number of votes secured by each nominee, where there is more than one, and where there is only one nominee, he will be deemed to have received as
('65', 241, 0, 1, 443706) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 241, 1, 2, 443748) many votes as there are delegates present at the meeting.
('65', 241, 1, 3, 443806) These elections will take place simultaneously on the date fixed by the Working Committee in that behalf.
('65', 241, 1, 4, 443912) These results shall be posted to the Working Committee by the Provincial Congress Committee and the nominee securing the highest number of votes shall be declared President for the ensuing year.
('65', 241, 1, 5, 444107) The same meeting of delegates shall elect its quota of members for the All India Congress Committee.

('65', 241, 2, 7, 444463) These members to be elected at the meeting of delegates referred to by the single transferable vote.
('65', 241, 2, 8, 444564) The same meeting of delegates to elect members of Provincial Congress Committees where necessary.
('65', 241, 3, 9, 444662) Regard being had to the fact that the All India Congress Committee has been considerably reduced, members desire to emphasize the necessity of making it clear in the constitution that the Working Committee should not initiate new policies but should merely be the executive body carrying out the policies laid down from time to time by the All India Congress Committee.

('65', 244, 1, 2, 450836) When the resolution regarding the Indian States was about to be moved, Mahatmaji stated that the problem of the Indian States was a very delicate one.
('65', 244, 2, 3, 450987) Gandhiji has prepared the following draft resolution, indicating the Working Committee’s views on the Indian States peoples.
('65', 244, 2, 4, 451112) Gandhiji, however, advised that this proposal be not adopted by Congress, but that a formula be evolved by a sub committee, in consultation with States’ subjects’ representatives.
('65', 244, 2, 5, 451292) This sub committee’s report would be placed before the next meeting of the A. I. C. C. Gandhiji’s draft formula runs:
('65', 244, 3, 6, 451410) As numerous resolutions have been received from various groups for adoption by Congress, and urging it to define its policy in regard to Indian States, it is hereby resolved as follows: Congress adheres to its policy of the internal administration of various States.
('65', 244, 3, 7, 451677) Congress, however, regards the whole of geographical India as an indivisible whole, notwithstanding the fact that it is cut up into parts governed under different systems and, therefore, expresses its regret over the tendency of some Princes to regard as foreigners Indians from parts of India other than their own, and repeats its appeal, made at the previous sessions of Congress, to establish respon sible government within their jurisdiction, and recognize the necessity of guaranteeing civic and political liberty of people living in their territories.
('65', 244, 3, 8, 452235) This Congress assures the people residing in different States of full sympathy with their just aspirations and for fuller self expression.

('65', 245, 4, 4, 452520) ARTICLE I
('65', 245, 5, 5, 452530) The object of the Indian National Congress is the attainment of poorna swaraj (Complete Independence) by all legitimate and peaceful means.
('65', 245, 6, 6, 452670) THE INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
('65', 245, 7, 7, 452699) ARTICLE II
('65', 245, 8, 8, 452710) The Indian National Congress shall comprise: (1) Members enrolled in primary committees under Article III, (2) Provincial Congress Committees, (3) Annual Session, (4) All India Congress Committee, (5) Working Committee,
('65', 245, 9, 9, 452930) and may comprise (a) committees or associations directly organized by the A. I. C. C. or the Working Committee, or (b) committees organized by any Provincial Congress Committee in accordance with the rules framed by it in that behalf and approved by the Working Committee.
('65', 245, 10, 10, 453203) MEMBERSHIP
('65', 245, 11, 11, 453214) ARTICLE III
('65', 245, 12, 12, 453226) (a) Any person over the age of 18 years who believes in Article I shall, on making a written declaration to that effect and presenting an application in form A annexed hereto and on payment of four annas, be entitled to be placed on the register of Congress members kept at any office duly authorized in that behalf within the district in which he ordinarily resides or carries on business.
('65', 245, 12, 13, 453617) Provided that no person shall be a member of more than one primary committee at the same time.

('65', 246, 1, 3, 454005) (c) It shall state the full name, age, sex, and occupation of the applicant as also the village, the taluk, the district and the province in which he ordinarily resides or carries on business.
('65', 246, 1, 4, 454198) (d) The official receiving the application, after recording on it the date of receipt, serial number and such other particulars as may be prescribed shall send one of the duplicates to the office of the Provincial Congress Committee concerned.
('65', 246, 1, 5, 454442) (e) The applicant, on being enrolled, shall receive a certificate of membership as per form B annexed hereto and printed on durable paper, either in the language and script of the province in which he resides or in the Hindustani language written in Devanagari or Urdu script.
('65', 246, 1, 6, 454719) (f) Unless otherwise directed by the Working Committee the year of the membership shall be reckoned from April 1st to March 31st and there shall be no reduction in the subscription to be paid by members joining in the middle of the year.

('65', 248, 2, 4, 457675) ELECTION OF DELEGATES
('65', 248, 3, 5, 457697) ARTICLE VI
('65', 248, 4, 6, 457708) (a) At the end of every Annual Session the Working Committee shall fix a date and time not earlier than eight months after the date of such decision when every Provincial Congress Committee shall send to the Working Committee a certified list of members of its primary committees qualified to vote.
('65', 248, 4, 7, 458007) The list must reach the office of the Working Committee on or before the said or any other extended date [or] time.
('65', 248, 4, 8, 458123) (b) Members included in the said list shall alone be entitled to vote at the election of delegates in that province.
('65', 248, 4, 9, 458240) (c) In the event of a Provincial Congress Committee failing to furnish the list in time, the province concerned may be disentitled to elect its delegates.
('65', 248, 4, 10, 458395) (d) On receipt of the aforesaid lists the Working Committee shall fix the date by which the election of delegates must be held and the quota of delegates which each province is entitled to return, and call upon the Provincial Congress Committees to procced with the election of their respective quota.
('65', 248, 4, 11, 458697) (c) For the purposes of election the provinces referred to in Article IV hereof shall be divided into rural and urban areas.
('65', 248, 5, 12, 458822) ‘Urban area’ means towns which have a population of more than ten thousand persons.
('65', 248, 5, 13, 458906) ‘Rural area’ means area other than urban.
('65', 248, 5, 14, 458948) (f) The rural area as also every town with a population of more than 10,000 persons in a district shall each be entitled to elect one delegate for every five hundred duly qualified members on the rolls of its primary committees or for such other number as may be fixed by the Working Committee in accordance with clause (h) hereof subject to the following: (i) The maximum number of delegates shall not exceed two thousand.
('65', 248, 5, 15, 459372) Out of the said number 511 shall be the maximum for the urban area and 1,489 for the rural area.
('65', 248, 5, 16, 459469) (ii) No province shall be entitled to return a larger number of
('65', 249, 0, 1, 459533) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 249, 1, 2, 459575) delegates than a proportion of one delegate; to every 1,50,000 of the inhabitants of such province including the Indian States or agencies therein, or a fraction thereof, in accordance with the census of 1921. PROVISO I: The maximum number of delegates sent by the urban area in each province shall not exceed 25% of the total number returnable by the province as aforesaid.
('65', 249, 1, 3, 459950) PROVISO II: Bombay (City) shall have a maximum quota of 21 elegates.
('65', 249, 1, 4, 460019) PROVISO III: Every province shall be entitled to return a minimum of 10 delegates irrespective of the strength of its primary members.
('65', 249, 1, 5, 460154) (g) (i) Where the rural area of a district has a sufficient number of duly qualified members on the rolls of its primary committees, the Provincial Congress Committee shall divide such area into suitable circles, so as to include in each circle not less than five hundred duly qualified members and each such circle shall be entitled to elect a delegate.
('65', 249, 1, 6, 460509) (ii) On a demand made in writing by 500 duly qualified members enrolled on the primary committees of one or more contiguous circles of a district, the said circles, where possible, shall be combined into a plural member constituency of not more than five seats.
('65', 249, 1, 7, 460771) (iii) Wherever possible, a town with a population of more than 10,000 persons shall be divided into plural member con stituencies of not less than five and not more than ten seats provided the constituency can have at least 500 duly qualified members to every seat.
('65', 249, 1, 8, 461037) But where the number of duly qualified members is less than 2,500, the town shall be formed into a plural member constituency with one scat to not less than 500 members each.
('65', 249, 1, 9, 461212) (iv) Election in plural member constituencies shall be by proportional representation by single transferable vote.
('65', 249, 1, 10, 461327) (h) If and when necessary, the Working Committee may readjust the proportion of 500 duly qualified members to one delegate and prescribe a higher figure for any urban or rural area so that the total number of urban and rural delegates in each province may be in the proportion of I to 3 and may not in the aggregate exceed the maximum prescribed for it under f (ii).

('65', 250, 4, 8, 462493) (a) On receipt by the Working Committee of the lists of delegates it shall fix a date on which the delegates in every province shall assemble in a meeting to transact the following business: (i) to propose the candidate or candidates for the Presidentship of the Congress for the ensuing year and to record the vote of each of the delegates asssembled on the proposals; (ii) to elect from among themselves one twelfth of their number as representatives of the province on the All India Congress Committee; (iii) in case the number of delegates for the province exceeds 100, to elect from among themselves a number of members which together with the members of the All India Congress Committee elected under clause (ii) would amount to 100 to constitute the Provincial Congress Committee of the province.

('65', 252, 1, 9, 467471) (i) At each sitting of the Congress, the order in which business shall be transacted shall be as follows: (i) The resolution recommended for adoption by the Subjects Committee.
('65', 252, 1, 10, 467648) (ii) Any substantive motion not included in (i) and which 25 delegates request the President in writing, before the commencement of the day’s sitting, to be allowed to place before the Congress; provided, however, that no such motion shall be allowed unless it has been previously discussed at a meeting of the Subjects Committee and has received the support of at least a third of the members then present.

('65', 255, 1, 3, 472650) (e) The Working Committee shall have the power: (i) to frame rules and issue instructions for the proper working of the constitution and in all matters not otherwise provided for; (ii) to superintend, direct and control all Congress Committees subject to review by the A. I. C. C.; (iii) to take such disciplinary action as it may deem fit against a committee or individual for misconduct, wilful neglect or default.

('65', 257, 2, 11, 478138) Report of the 48th Annual Session of the Indian National Congress, 1934
('65', 258, 0, 1, 478210) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 259
('65', 258, 1, 2, 478260) 281. SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION, BOMBAY1
('65', 258, 2, 3, 478301) October 28, 1934
('65', 258, 3, 4, 478318) MR. PRESIDENT, SISTERS AND BROTHERS,
('65', 258, 4, 5, 478355) First and foremost, I crave pardon from all sisters and brothers that copies of the resolution proposing changes in the present constitution have not reached you.
('65', 258, 4, 6, 478518) In spite of the trouble the Reception Committee had taken, there was so much to do that it seemed near impossible to get it done in three days; but they had resolved to complete the work within three days.
('65', 258, 4, 7, 478724) Today the Subjects Committee also sat for long and therefore copies of this resolution could not be printed.
('65', 258, 4, 8, 478833) There is much to amend but it is a matter for the legal pundits.
('65', 258, 4, 9, 478898) I shall explain to you in a few minutes the amendments that have been accepted.
('65', 258, 4, 10, 478978) We could have asked you to come again tomorrow evening for this same purpose; that means the Reception Committee would have had to spend so much money unnecessarily and your time and money would be wasted.
('65', 258, 4, 11, 479184) It has never been my intention to have my resolution passed by Unfair means by not letting you see it.
('65', 258, 4, 12, 479287) You are already acquainted with the present constitution.
('65', 258, 4, 13, 479345) Experience has shown that 6,000 delegates were an unwieldy number.
('65', 258, 4, 14, 479412) At the Nagpur Congress there were 14,000 delegates but they were not elected by any constituencies and represented mostly themselves.
('65', 258, 4, 15, 479546) Now it is proposed to reduce the number of delegates to 2,000. I wanted only 1,000 delegates but yielded to the opposition and accepted 2,000. I wanted the delegates to agree to this sacrifice in number in the cause of freedom.
('65', 258, 4, 16, 479774) There is at present no direct contact between the Congress delegates and electors.
('65', 258, 4, 17, 479857) This change in the constitution will not get us swaraj but will help the Congress to stand as a rival to the Assembly in showing that the Congress delegates also speak for their electorate.
('65', 258, 4, 18, 480047) Hereafter, Congress inspectors will look into the registers and only such Congressmen will be allowed to vote as have been on its rolls for at least six months.
('65', 258, 4, 19, 480208) Unless there are 500 Congressmen, they will not be entitled to elect a delegate to the Congress.
('65', 258, 4, 20, 480305) This is too poor,
('65', 258, 5, 21, 480323) 1 Gandhiji first spoke in Hindi at the 48th session of the Indian National Congress, presided over by Rajendra Prasad
('65', 259, 0, 1, 480441) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 259, 1, 2, 480483) compared to the Assembly where 8,000 voters elect one member, but I am satisfied with such a beginning for the organization representing poor people.
('65', 259, 1, 3, 480633) As swaraj cannot be attained without roping villages into the Congress scheme, it has been provided that of Congress shall represent rural areas, i.e., places with a population of l0,000 and under.
('65', 259, 1, 4, 480831) Representation will be by single transferable vote and there will be plural constituencies.
('65', 259, 1, 5, 480923) As for the A. I. C. C., it is always difficult to call 350 members who cannot afford the expense of frequent meetings.
('65', 259, 1, 6, 481042) Thus the A. I. C. C. has been reduced to the maximum of 166. Then again, no democrat would like that the Congress President should be elected by the Reception Committee on recommendations of Provincial Congress Committees but hereafter the delegates themselves will elect the President.
('65', 259, 2, 7, 481329) Gandhiji then explained the khadi clause and the spinning franchise and said:
('65', 259, 3, 8, 481407) I do not mind if you reject these, but if you adopt them, you should do so with absolute conviction.
('65', 259, 3, 9, 481508) Please vote not out of regard for me but in the interest of the motherland.
('65', 259, 3, 10, 481584) When I read the newspaper and the public comments on my proposals, I gave up the idea of publishing them for general consideration.
('65', 259, 3, 11, 481716) But members of the Working Committee thought it fit to put them before you.
('65', 259, 3, 12, 481792) I have listened to the opinions of others on the scheme for change.
('65', 259, 3, 13, 481860) They have presented their case very ably.
('65', 259, 3, 14, 481902) But they were either deceiving themselves or they were playing the role of an attorney.
('65', 259, 3, 15, 481990) And they claimed that they had climbed down from idealism to practicality.
('65', 259, 3, 16, 482065) But has socialism no ideals?
('65', 259, 3, 17, 482094) If I told them to give up even a single one of their ideals, they would defeat my resolution.
('65', 259, 3, 18, 482188) Do you ever realize that purna swaraj may come only in the next generation?
('65', 259, 3, 19, 482264) The socialist ideal is higher than even this.
('65', 259, 3, 20, 482310) I say we need a measuring rod.
('65', 259, 3, 21, 482341) Please [do not] think over this matter with the hope that on this resolution having passed, I may reconsider my retirement.
('65', 259, 3, 22, 482465) If I began my leadership of the Congress with a constitution for which I am mainly responsible, then, while taking my leave, I wish to present you this amended constitution so that you can gain by the experience of one who tried in collaboration with you to work this constitution and found some defects in it.
('65', 259, 3, 23, 482776) Therefore I wish you should carry these amendments.
('65', 260, 0, 1, 482828) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 261
('65', 260, 1, 2, 482878) One more thing is that the delegates should be sincere and truly representative of the people.
('65', 260, 1, 3, 482973) Indirectly we are the representatives of the mute millions.
('65', 260, 1, 4, 483033) We voice their views.
('65', 260, 1, 5, 483055) From 1886 this has been the position of the Congress.
('65', 260, 1, 6, 483109) But we represent the electorate only indirectly.
('65', 260, 1, 7, 483158) Can any one of us say whose representative he is?
('65', 260, 1, 8, 483208) Is he in contact with his own constituency and does he reflect their views?
('65', 260, 1, 9, 483284) Can the biggest among us say what place he represents?
('65', 260, 1, 10, 483339) Vallabhbhai is the uncrowned king of Gujarat but which constituency does he represent?
('65', 260, 1, 11, 483426) Whom do I represent?
('65', 260, 1, 12, 483447) I myself do not know it.
('65', 260, 1, 13, 483472) I challenge everyone to submit the Congress register of his electorate.
('65', 260, 1, 14, 483544) We must have a living contact with our constituency and with our voters; only then can we have our measuring rod.
('65', 260, 1, 15, 483658) The principle that I am putting before you is that the three elections should all be held simultaneously.
('65', 260, 1, 16, 483764) This will be economically feasible and save some expenditure.
('65', 260, 1, 17, 483826) If you accept this principle its future will be unshakable.
('65', 260, 1, 18, 483886) Then the delegates will be chosen by their electorates.
('65', 260, 1, 19, 483942) Then they would not, like today, gather for three days only to disappear later.
('65', 260, 1, 20, 484022) They would be active members of the Congress working all through the year.
('65', 260, 1, 21, 484097) Today, out of 6,350 delegates only 350 are members of the All India Congress Committee.

('65', 260, 1, 23, 484269) I have made a detailed scheme for organizing such village sessions.

('65', 261, 1, 2, 485471) In the end, Gandhiji appealed to the representatives to adopt the new constitution with the determination to make it a signal success.

('65', 264, 1, 2, 489927) 288. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('65', 264, 2, 3, 489955) October 30, 1934
('65', 264, 3, 4, 489972) I received during my silence in Bombay several queries from Pressmen, but I had no time to give written replies then.
('65', 264, 3, 5, 490090) Visitors continued to pour in for whom I had to scribble out replies practically till the time of my leaving the camp.
('65', 264, 3, 6, 490209) Now I answer these and some others that have cropped up since.
('65', 264, 3, 7, 490272) The first is whether I have already tendered my resignation.
('65', 264, 3, 8, 490333) Formally, I had not done so till October 28, but it is presently going, in the form of a letter addressed to Rajendrababu and other officials concerned.
('65', 264, 3, 9, 490486) 1 This does not mean that I cease to take interest in the politics of the country or in its political future.
('65', 264, 3, 10, 490596) Much less does it mean that I cease to take interest in the welfare of the organization for whose good I have left it.
('65', 264, 3, 11, 490715) But, what will happen is that I shall cease to be interested in the details of the working of the Congress.
('65', 264, 3, 12, 490823) And I shall certainly cease to shape the policy of the Congress organization as I had the privilege of doing till the last moment of the session.
('65', 264, 3, 13, 490969) Let me give one or two illustrations.
('65', 264, 3, 14, 491007) Whilst I was observing silence yesterday, Rajendrababu and several members of the Working Committee came to discuss with me the composition of the new Working Committee.
('65', 264, 3, 15, 491177) Hardly had we proceeded to discuss one or two names when I saw the utter incongruity of what I was doing.
('65', 264, 3, 16, 491283) I, therefore, immediately wrote out on my scribbling pad, “Surely, I may not discuss these things now.” Members present immediately realized the significance of my remark and they very generously removed themselves some distance from me and began to discuss them in whispers and I may state that, up to the time of dictating this at Wardha, I am unaware of the composition of the new Working Committee.
('65', 264, 3, 17, 491686) I was taking a lively interest, even up to the time of my departure, in the unfortunate Ajmer dispute.
('65', 264, 3, 18, 491789) But Congressmen may understand from these two illustrations that I can no longer be looked up to for advice or guidance in such matters.
('65', 264, 3, 19, 491926) If I continue to interest myself in the day to day working of the organization or in the domestic quarrels, not only would the whole of the salutary effect of my retirement be undone, but I would become a powerful factor for
('65', 264, 4, 20, 492151) 1 Vide “Note to Rajendera Prasad”, 30 10 1934 and “Letter to Rajendra Prasad”, 30 10 1934.
('65', 265, 0, 1, 492242) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 265, 1, 2, 492284) disturbance, not having the grasp of details which alone has hitherto been a predominant factor in enabling me to come to correct judgment in a vast majority of cases.
('65', 265, 2, 3, 492452) My interest in the Congress organization will, henceforth, be confined to watching, from at a distance, the enforcement of principles for which the Congress stands.
('65', 265, 2, 4, 492617) Congressmen may therefore expect, whenever I feel like giving it, a criticism of methods that may be pursued by the organization as a whole or its members as individuals.
('65', 265, 2, 5, 492788) But this again does not mean that I should be receiving letters as I have hitherto received asking me for guidance in daily transactions in connection with the Congress.
('65', 265, 2, 6, 492958) This they must henceforth seek from the President whose guidance will, I know, be invaluable or from those in whom they have confidence.
('65', 265, 2, 7, 493095) I must be left free for the work which I have in mind.
('65', 265, 2, 8, 493150) Let it be borne in mind that I do not regard politics as something different in kind from other national activities.
('65', 265, 2, 9, 493267) The root meaning of politics is the science of citizenship and it has also remote connection with polished manners and since the boundaries of citizenship have been extended to cover continents, the science of politics includes attainment of advancement of humanity along all lines, social, moral, economic and political, using the word ‘political’ here in the narrow sense in which we are accustomed to use it.
('65', 265, 2, 10, 493679) Ever since my return to India in 1915, it has been my earnest endeavour to restore the meaning of politics to its root and if we would be truthful through and through, we should recognize that the predominant part of the Congress programme has been progressively social, moral and economic.
('65', 265, 2, 11, 493970) And it becomes a powerful programme because it is intimately connected with the political, that is, the attainment of freedom of the country from foreign yoke, not from foreign friendship, that is, voluntary intercourse on terms of absolute equality with foreign nations.
('65', 265, 2, 12, 494242) If Congressmen forget the constructive programme and simply confine Congress activities to winning of Assembly and Council elections and of fruitless debates in the Assembly and the Councils, they will soon find that I have taken with me the kernel of politics and they have kept for themselves only the outermost husk, without even the vitamins.
('65', 265, 2, 13, 494589) But I have no such fear.
('65', 265, 2, 14, 494614) Parliamentary Congressmen will advance the Congress programmes and by their votes register the will of the nation.
('65', 266, 0, 1, 494729) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 267
('65', 266, 1, 2, 494779) This session of the Congress has been a revelation to me.
('65', 266, 1, 3, 494837) I had expected a battle royal with the members of the Working Committee about the vital amendments I had suggested and afterwards withdrawn, and equally vital alterations in the constitution on which I was insistent, but which had no connection whatsoever with my retirement from the Congress.
('65', 266, 1, 4, 495131) But I found that, apart from my retirement, which they had ascertained was a moral certainty, members of the Working Committee wanted the amendments after their own fashion.
('65', 266, 1, 5, 495305) Every one of them without exception had come to the conclusion that substitution of the words “legitimate and peaceful” by “truthful and nonviolent” was necessary, because of the ambiguity surrounding the two words.
('65', 266, 1, 6, 495521) I could not prevent them from enforcing their own independent judgment.
('65', 266, 2, 7, 495593) The same revelations awaited me in the Subjects Committee.
('65', 266, 2, 8, 495652) The alteration of the creed was not carried, but it was not summarily rejected.
('65', 266, 2, 9, 495732) It was referred to Provincial Congress Committees for opinion.
('65', 266, 2, 10, 495795) And now that I am out of the way and provinces are in a position to exercise their judgment freely and unfettered, I do hope that in order to be true to themselves and the Congress, their first act will be to pronounce their unequivocal opinion on the proposed amendments.
('65', 266, 2, 11, 496068) The ambiguity is patent.
('65', 266, 2, 12, 496093) Many have contested my proposition that “truthful and non violent” are synonymous with “legitimate and peaceful”.
('65', 266, 2, 13, 496207) If the Congress do not attach that meaning to the two words, they should unhesitatingly recommend their removal altogether.
('65', 266, 2, 14, 496331) In adopting this recommendation they will not travel outside the terms of reference.
('65', 266, 2, 15, 496416) Our creed is the measure by which we want mankind to judge us.
('65', 266, 2, 16, 496479) There should surely be no uncertainty about our measure.
('65', 266, 2, 17, 496536) What we insist upon in ordinary affairs of life is surely necessary in national affairs, Even as a mason without his square or a tailor without his yardstick is inconceivable, so also we cannot conceive of a big organization like the Congress without its measure.
('65', 266, 2, 18, 496800) If we have any doubt about the necessity for downright truthfulness and downright non violence for the attainment of complete independence, we should say so.
('65', 266, 2, 19, 496958) There will be nothing wrong in it.
('65', 266, 2, 20, 496993) That would not mean that we have abandoned truth or non violence.
('65', 266, 2, 21, 497059) It would mean that we have ceased to connect truthfulness and non violence with independence, have ceased to see the one as the cause and the other as its inevitable result, have ceased
('65', 267, 0, 1, 497245) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 267, 1, 2, 497287) to think that there is an indissoluble bond between the means and the end.
('65', 267, 1, 3, 497362) If there was difficulty about carrying the amendment to the creed, it was plain sailing with reference to other amendments, both in the Subjects Committee and in the open session.
('65', 267, 1, 4, 497542) What I observed to my delight was also the fact that those who wanted to oppose any of the amendments did so without any hesitation and yet in courteous terms.
('65', 267, 1, 5, 497702) Obedience was ungrudgingly tendered to the chair at all times, whereas I was prepared for boisterous scenes.
('65', 267, 1, 6, 497811) And all the amendments were passed although members knew that I was not remaining in the Congress.
('65', 267, 1, 7, 497910) The manner in which the 1,500 delegates assembled here waived their undoubted right of having copies of the amended draft constitution was an exhibition of generosity and faith of which any nation would be proud.
('65', 267, 1, 8, 498123) And yet all amendments were passed by the delegates with overwhelming majorities after they had understood what they were and what were their implications.
('65', 267, 1, 9, 498279) For they listened for over an hour to my simple unvarnished explanation of all amendments.
('65', 267, 1, 10, 498370) The cheers that punctuated my remarks on some of the most important amendments showed that they were following my exposition with the utmost attention.
('65', 267, 1, 11, 498522) All this was possible because of perfect loudspeaker arrangements that were made as well for the Subjects Committee as for the open session.
('65', 267, 1, 12, 498663) Now that the new constitution is an established fact, the Provincial Congress Committees should realize the necessity for honestly working it.
('65', 267, 1, 13, 498806) Although time has been given to them up to January 15 for holding A. I. C. C. elections and for reducing themselves to l00, where they are over 100, wherever it is possible they should at once do these two things.
('65', 267, 1, 14, 499020) Let me also utter a warning.
('65', 267, 1, 15, 499049) I hope no one will think that the khaddar clause and labour franchise clause do not come into immediate operation.
('65', 267, 1, 16, 499164) They do.
('65', 267, 1, 17, 499173) Those who do not believe in them, those who do not want to wear khaddar as a habit, to the exclusion of all other cloth, or do not want to do some manual labour for the sake of the country, will, if they are members of any elected organization, at once tender their resignations.
('65', 267, 1, 18, 499453) And Provincial Congress Committees will not elect as members of the Committees or of A. I. C. C. those who are not habitual wearers of khaddar or who do not want to do manual labour.
('65', 267, 1, 19, 499636) Spinning is undoubtedly the most natural and the
('65', 268, 0, 1, 499685) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 269
('65', 268, 1, 2, 499735) easiest form of labour and is connected with the khaddar clause.
('65', 268, 1, 3, 499800) But those who do not believe in spinning can certainly take up any other kind of manual labour.
('65', 268, 1, 4, 499896) Tailoring is quite easy, whether with the needle or with the sewing machine.
('65', 268, 1, 5, 499973) Sewing four caps would be equivalent to more than 500 yards of evenly spun yarn.
('65', 268, 1, 6, 500054) A day’s cleaning of a neighbouring village would undoubtedly be such an equivalent.
('65', 268, 1, 7, 500138) So would be house to house personal distribution for one day of, say, quinine powder or pills in malarial tracts.
('65', 268, 1, 8, 500252) What is meant by this clause to be symbolical may, in the end, result in many Congressmen becoming experts in the labour they perform and make phenomenal contribution to the economic advancement of the nation.
('65', 268, 1, 9, 500462) This is all civil resistance of the purest type.
('65', 268, 1, 10, 500511) I plead guilty of negligence in that I had not in the past insisted on these things so as to make them a condition precedent to launching out any civil disobedience.
('65', 268, 1, 11, 500677) I had been overborne by the argument that the nation would take up these things in the course of civil disobedience.
('65', 268, 1, 12, 500794) That expectation has not been realized.
('65', 268, 1, 13, 500834) My retirement from the Congress may be regarded as a penance for the negligence although it was wholly unconscious.
('65', 268, 1, 14, 500950) But calling myself, as I do, an expert in the science of civil resistance, I may not plead ignorance as excuse.
('65', 268, 1, 15, 501062) I hope, therefore, the vital clauses of the constitution will be immediately put into operation.
('65', 268, 1, 16, 501159) What I am aiming at is development of capacity for civil resistance so that there never may be any need for civil disobedience.
('65', 268, 1, 17, 501287) Disobedience that is wholly civil should never provoke retaliation.
('65', 268, 2, 18, 501355) The Hindu, 31 10 1934
('65', 268, 3, 19, 501377) 289. LETTER TO DR.

('65', 268, 5, 28, 501778) I allowed myself to be party to a discussion over the names of the new Working Committee.

('65', 269, 1, 4, 502178) But I saw that I was doing violence to my pledge that I shall cease to be a member of the Congress after the session.

('65', 275, 1, 2, 512287) 300. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('65', 275, 2, 3, 512318) October31/November 2, 1934
('65', 275, 3, 4, 512345) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('65', 275, 4, 5, 512361) I have been wanting to write to you every week; but it was impossible.
('65', 275, 4, 6, 512432) You know the situation now.
('65', 275, 4, 7, 512460) I am free and it is all to the good.
('65', 275, 4, 8, 512497) Here is a copy of my statement to the Press made immediately after the breaking of silence, that is, made on the 30th.
('65', 275, 4, 9, 512616) I want to devote next month at least to Harijan work and to launching out the contemplated Village Industries Association.
('65', 275, 4, 10, 512739) But I want to pave the way for the Frontier even from now.
('65', 275, 4, 11, 512798) I hope to be able to send my letter to the Government in a day or two.
('65', 275, 4, 12, 512869) If I do, you will have a copy of it herewith.
('65', 275, 4, 13, 512915) This is being dictated on 31st.
('65', 275, 4, 14, 512947) This may be posted from Wardha on the 2nd November.
('65', 275, 4, 15, 512999) My desire throughout is so to act as to disarm all suspicion about the character of civil disobedience.
('65', 275, 4, 16, 513103) At the present moment there is no question of others participating in it.
('65', 275, 4, 17, 513177) So far as I can see the future, there is no likelihood of my initiating or precipitating mass civil disobedience for some years to come.
('65', 275, 4, 18, 513314) I want to test the genuineness of public feeling by keeping myself aloof from the Congress and watching from a distance how Congressmen in general take to the constructive programme.
('65', 275, 4, 19, 513497) Civil resistance can properly culminate in civil disobedience only when people learn the art of civil resistance which is nothing less and nothing more than refraining from doing anything that would keep up a system which you seek to destroy.
('65', 275, 4, 20, 513740) I observe that without breaking a single law, villagers can somewhat better their economic condition by reviving their industries.
('65', 275, 4, 21, 513871) Hence the Village Industries Association.
('65', 275, 4, 22, 513913) Hindu Muslim tension also enables the system to live, and so does untouchability, so does the drink evil.
('65', 275, 4, 23, 514019) People had sufficient experience now in this kind of training.
('65', 275, 4, 24, 514082) I am, therefore, resisting every temptation to invite civil disobedience by the people.
('65', 275, 4, 25, 514170) There is temptation enough.
('65', 275, 4, 26, 514198) Even the prisoners in Bombay who were thought to be discharged are still in the various jails of the Presidency of Bombay.
('65', 275, 4, 27, 514321) Buildings which have been seized by the Government are not being returned.
('65', 275, 4, 28, 514396) I can multiply such instances drawn from various provinces.
('65', 275, 4, 29, 514456) Nevertheless I know that I have to live down these irritations and so have fellow workers.
('65', 276, 0, 1, 514547) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 277
('65', 276, 1, 2, 514597) appears to me just now the best form of resistance, if it may be so called.
('65', 276, 1, 3, 514673) But if I may not go [to] the Frontier, and if there is no just cause for preventing me from going there, it may prove the last straw and I will again find myself utterly incapable of doing constructive work.
('65', 276, 1, 4, 514881) I must receive this elementary satisfaction of the soul.
('65', 276, 1, 5, 514938) Let me not anticipate.
('65', 276, 1, 6, 514961) All I can say is that I shall not rush to the jail.
('65', 276, 1, 7, 515013) You will have ample notice.
('65', 276, 1, 8, 515041) I hope Mira had a successful tour in America.
('65', 276, 1, 9, 515087) You will share this letter with C. F. Andrews and whomsoever you like.
('65', 276, 1, 10, 515158) Did you get the balance paid to you of the expenses incurred here?
('65', 276, 2, 11, 515225) BAPU [PS.] I have not yet drafted the letter about the Frontier.
('65', 276, 4, 12, 515290) MISS AGATHA HARRISON LONDON
('65', 276, 5, 13, 515318) From a photostat: G.N. 1480

('65', 283, 6, 9, 526510) Note 3: In both (a) and (b), the word “member” 2 is used to denote a primary member, whereas whenever the word “membership” occurs the reference is to an elected member.
('65', 283, 6, 10, 526680) At both places, therefore, you should use either “member” or “person”.
('65', 283, 6, 11, 526751) “Member” at one place and “person” at another will not be correct.
('65', 283, 6, 12, 526818) The word “member” is not likely to be interpreted to mean a member holding an elective post.
('65', 283, 6, 13, 526911) All the same, you should use the same word at both places, whichever you prefer.
('65', 283, 7, 14, 526992) Note 5: Bapu feels that the words “every district” throughout will serve the purposefully, or that, alternatively, the amendment suggested by him should be retained.
('65', 283, 7, 15, 527158) Using the word “town” only will not permit the additional members in one town to be “amalgamated” with the additional members in another town in the same district, and will also create difficulties in forming constituencies with a minimum of five members.
('65', 283, 8, 16, 527414) Note 6: In clause (h) Bapu suggests the following amendment in place of the one suggested by you: “When the number of duly qualified primary members exceeds the minimum required for electing 2,000 delegates, the Working Committee shall readjust the minimum of 500 duly qualified primary members required per delegate so as to maintain the maximum for all India and the balance between urban and rural areas as per clause f(1) hereof.”

('65', 292, 6, 14, 541111) 329. LETTER TO K. M. MUNSHI
('65', 292, 7, 15, 541139) November 6, 1934
('65', 292, 8, 16, 541156) MY DEAR MUNSHI,
('65', 292, 9, 17, 541172) My mind is off the constitution now.
('65', 292, 9, 18, 541209) Therefore, it is difficult for me to give you a definite opinion on your letter just received.
('65', 292, 9, 19, 541304) On all the points raised by you, therefore, you should give full effect to that which was clearly understood at the sub committee’s deliberations.
('65', 292, 9, 20, 541451) I sent you my phraseology 1 to meet what I thought was the prevalent view of the sub committee.
('65', 292, 9, 21, 541547) As you know, I was in it the whole of the time, but so was also Kishorelal.
('65', 292, 9, 22, 541623) I would gladly prefer his memory to mine.
('65', 292, 9, 23, 541665) Now for the details: 1. What was understood at the sub committee was that, wherever, whether in rural area or urban area, contiguous places could be combined to form plural member constituencies they should be so combined.
('65', 292, 9, 24, 541888) There was no distinction between the urban area and the rural area except that in the urban area the maximum was fixed at ten members and the minimum at five, wherever such a thing [was] possible; for rural area no maximum or minimum was fixed, but wherever possible, by the process of amalgamation suggested above, plural member constituencies were to be created.
('65', 292, 9, 25, 542253) The question of
('65', 292, 10, 26, 542269) 1 Vide “Letter to K.M.Munshi”, 3 11 1934.
('65', 293, 0, 1, 542311) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 293, 1, 2, 542353) amalgamating Ahmedabad, Dhanduka and Prantij does not arise at all in my conception.
('65', 293, 1, 3, 542438) My difficulty arose in your drawing the distinction between the two areas.
('65', 293, 1, 4, 542513) According to our definition of a town, it must have a population of more than l0,000. Any place having 10,000 or less is not a town and belongs to the rural area.
('65', 293, 1, 5, 542676) I do not know if I have made my own meaning clear.
('65', 293, 1, 6, 542727) If it is not clear, and if there is nobody whom you can consult as to the understanding, please enforce your own view.
('65', 293, 1, 7, 542846) After all if there is any difficulty or difference of opinion among the members of A. I. C. C. it can be removed at the next session of the Congress.
('65', 293, 1, 8, 542996) 2. The difficulty for Bombay in the matter of readjusting the proportion of 500 to one delegate was not before me, because it has 21 members allotted to it as the maximum.
('65', 293, 1, 9, 543168) For the other provinces, I understand this to be the position.
('65', 293, 1, 10, 543231) We have the maximum fixed for them and we have also the maximum fixed for urban and rural areas.
('65', 293, 1, 11, 543328) Therefore, the distribution or readjustment will be according to provinces and further readjustment according to the areas in the respective provinces.
('65', 293, 1, 12, 543480) My own interpretation of my draft is that both these are provided for.
('65', 293, 1, 13, 543551) But if you think otherwise, then your draft should stand or any other you may frame to carry out this meaning.
('65', 293, 1, 14, 543662) That the meaning is what I have given here I have no doubt whatsoever.
('65', 293, 1, 15, 543733) 3. As to the special session I have no difficulty.
('65', 293, 1, 16, 543784) The A. I. C. C., the Working Committee and the President will be at the disposal of the delegates.
('65', 293, 1, 17, 543883) They will do whatever they like with them and I thought that our draft had so provided.
('65', 293, 1, 18, 543971) You may send me that final proof if you like, but I waive that privilege, because the publication of the constitution is overdue.
('65', 293, 1, 19, 544101) If we have honestly tried to give effect to the views of the sub committee as adopted by the Subjects Committee, our duty is done and we should stand the fire of criticism.

('65', 296, 15, 24, 548535) You have to concentrate your attention on becoming perfectly well and exclude every activity that may interfere with your progress in that direction.
('65', 296, 15, 25, 548685) God won’t be just if He was not merciful.
('65', 296, 15, 26, 548727) Justice and mercy are different terms with us imperfect human beings, not so with God who
('65', 297, 0, 1, 548817) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 297, 1, 2, 548859) is perfection and who knows our hearts and who will rule them if you will let him.
('65', 297, 1, 3, 548942) His justice is, therefore, never vindictive, never faulty and therefore descends upon us in the form of mercy.
('65', 297, 1, 4, 549053) Untouchability is not a divine institution, it is a man made institution.
('65', 297, 1, 5, 549127) That God permits evil to exist side by side with good is a mystery which we need not attempt to solve, but which we dare not ignore.
('65', 297, 1, 6, 549260) Those who believe in God naturally believe also that He presides over our destinies.
('65', 297, 1, 7, 549345) Even our sorrows turn into joy if we surrender ourselves completely to God.

('65', 303, 1, 2, 557978) 347. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('65', 303, 2, 3, 558006) November 8, 1934
('65', 303, 3, 4, 558023) I have seen newspaper paragraphs saying that a Delhi millionaire has placed at my disposal 20 lakhs of rupees for the All India Village Industries Association which is in the process of formation.
('65', 303, 3, 5, 558220) A later Press report makes me select Ahmedabad as the headquarters of the All India Village Industries Association.
('65', 303, 3, 6, 558336) Both these rumours are absolutely without foundation.
('65', 303, 3, 7, 558390) I would like the public to discount news about my movement or intention unless they are authorized by me.
('65', 303, 3, 8, 558496) What is true is that I have promises of Rs. 2,500 per month, and have already received over Rs. 500 in cash.
('65', 303, 3, 9, 558605) Whilst the Association will undoubtedly need funds, it needs workers more than funds.
('65', 303, 3, 10, 558691) The latter will come if the former is assured.
('65', 303, 3, 11, 558738) I, therefore, invite those who would work for the Association to send in their names.
('65', 303, 3, 12, 558824) only those will help who will give some time to the village or who are interested in what may at first sight appear to be uninteresting or unattractive village work.
('65', 303, 3, 13, 558990) The work will be of four kinds: (l) to encourage and improve the known industries that are likely to perish for want of support; (2) to take charge of and sell the products of those industries; (3) to carry on the survey of such village industries as need to be revived and supported; and (4) to attend to village sanitation and hygiene.
('65', 303, 3, 14, 559328) Whist the Association is in the process of formation and the scheme of work is being framed, I would ask fellow workers to set about encouraging hand pounding of rice, grinding of wholewheat meal by village chakkis 1 and popularizing gur 2 and study the processes with a view to ensuring the purity of the products.
('65', 303, 3, 15, 559644) The workers will collect accurate information about these three things and other village industries that may come under their observation and pass on to me such statistics as they may be able to collect.
('65', 303, 4, 16, 559848) 1 Manually operated grinding stone 2 Jaggery
('65', 304, 0, 1, 559893) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 305
('65', 304, 1, 2, 559943) I would also like to emphasize the fact that the Association is to be entirely non political.
('65', 304, 1, 3, 560037) Its sole object will be the economic, moral and hygienic uplift of the villages of India and it will be open to workers drawn from all parties.
('65', 304, 1, 4, 560181) The test will be full sympathy with the programme and readiness to help it with money and action wherever possible.
('65', 304, 2, 5, 560297) The Bombay Chronicle, 10 11 1934

('65', 306, 6, 11, 562745) 352. HARIJAN BOARDS
('65', 306, 7, 12, 562765) What should be the qualifications of members of Harijan Boards and what should be the number constituting them, are the questions often asked.
('65', 306, 7, 13, 562908) I endeavoured to answer 1 them fairly exhaustively at the meeting of the U. P. Provincial Board in Benares the other day.
('65', 306, 7, 14, 563030) It is necessary, however, to revert to the questions from time to time or till such time as one definite policy has been evolved.
('65', 306, 7, 15, 563160) If we remember that members of these Boards are servants and not patrons, much less ornaments, most of the difficulties will be automatically solved.
('65', 306, 7, 16, 563310) There will then be no question of pleasing or displeasing anybody.
('65', 306, 7, 17, 563377) Only those will be included who are eager to serve the cause and whose presence will promote the usefulness of the Board to which they belong and whose capacity for service will be increased by their being members of a Board.
('65', 306, 7, 18, 563603) No one should allow himself or herself to be a member of a Board, unless he or she (1) believes in the uttermost removal of untouchability, (2) pays something to the Board according to his or her capacity, (3) does some definite Harijan service, e.g., having a Harijan in his or her home as a member of the family, or at least as a domestic servant, or is teaching a Harijan or Harijans, or paying a regular visit to Harijan quarters and cleaning them, or, if he or she is a doctor,
('65', 306, 8, 19, 564086) 1 On July 29; vide “Speech at central board meeting of Harjan sevak sangh, Benares”, 29 7 1934.
('65', 307, 0, 1, 564182) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 307, 1, 2, 564224) treating Harijan patients free of charge, etc., (4) sends to the Board a diary containing a record of his or her service from month to month.
('65', 307, 1, 3, 564366) If some such conditions are observed, there need be no restriction on the number of members.
('65', 307, 1, 4, 564459) The more, the merrier.
('65', 307, 1, 5, 564482) Such Boards will meet to take notes; exchange experiences and solve mutual difficulties.
('65', 307, 1, 6, 564571) They will never waste time in fruitless discussions.
('65', 307, 1, 7, 564624) There may be Advisory Committees attached to the Boards.
('65', 307, 1, 8, 564681) These will lay down for themselves some minimum qualifications.
('65', 307, 1, 9, 564745) Naturally the qualifications of advisers will be less stringent than those of members of regular Boards.
('65', 307, 1, 10, 564850) What if members with the qualifications I have described cannot be found is the natural question arising from the bare mention of them.
('65', 307, 1, 11, 564986) I must repeat the answer I have given often enough before now.
('65', 307, 1, 12, 565049) The persons invited by the Central Board to form Sanghs in their own provinces will, in the absence of members having the necessary qualifications, perform the service through agents.
('65', 307, 1, 13, 565233) ‘Act True’ must be the motto of every Harijan Board, and there should never be any departure from the wholesome maxim.
('65', 307, 2, 14, 565352) Harijan, 9 11 1 934
('65', 307, 3, 15, 565372) 353. MR. SUPPOSED INCONSISTENCY
('65', 307, 4, 16, 565404) The Editor has sent the following 1 received by him for answer:
('65', 307, 5, 17, 565468) In the Harijan of the 9th March Gandhiji is reported to have said that ‘there was no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability’ 2 .
('65', 307, 5, 18, 565601) [This] does not seem to accord with his previous statement, which was that there is such sanction but he did not accept the authority of such passages because they were immoral.
('65', 307, 5, 19, 565779) Will you kindly explain the apparent inconsistency, through the columns of the Harijan?
('65', 307, 5, 20, 565867) I make no hobgoblin of consistency.
('65', 307, 5, 21, 565903) If I am true to myself from moment to moment, I do not mind all the inconsistencies that may be flung in my face.
('65', 307, 5, 22, 566017) But in the letter quoted, there is no inconsistency.
('65', 307, 5, 23, 566070) If I reject certain texts in the Shastras as interpolations or inconsistent with the fundamental principles they lay down or with universal morality, surely, I am entitled to say that there is no warrant in the Shastras for the practice or belief that the objectionable texts
('65', 307, 6, 24, 566346) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('65', 307, 6, 25, 566383) 2 Vide “Speech at women’s meeting, Mangalore”, 24 2 1934.
('65', 308, 0, 1, 566441) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 309
('65', 308, 1, 2, 566491) prescribe.
('65', 308, 1, 3, 566502) I have quoted the opinion of not one but several learned men in support of the contention that the Shastras do not enjoin untouchabilily as it is practised today.
('65', 308, 1, 4, 566665) Of course, there is untouchability in the Shastras, but it is all curable in accordance with the simple methods prescribed by them.
('65', 308, 1, 5, 566797) We all become untouchables every day when we attend to natural functions, and our untouchability is cured by simple ablutions.
('65', 308, 1, 6, 566924) Indeed, even wicked thoughts make us untouchable, but we are cured by resisting them and purifying ourselves by taking the name of God as Rama or Vasudev or Narayan or Shiva and invoking His never failing protection.
('65', 308, 1, 7, 567141) Even so is a Harijan, whose occupation may render him untouchable, cured by prescribed purification.
('65', 308, 1, 8, 567242) And certain sanatanists claim that there is an incurable untouchability which is handed down from father to son for generations and which will live to the end of Time.
('65', 308, 1, 9, 567410) And what is the saddest of all is that the sanatanists claim that such untouchables are to be counted by the million.
('65', 308, 1, 10, 567528) Their warrant for the belief in the existence of several million untouchables is not a Shastra, but census reports, which change from time to time and which are prepared by a host of enumerators who have no knowledge of the Hindu Shastras and, in numerous cases.
('65', 308, 1, 11, 567791) are not themselves Hindus.
('65', 308, 1, 12, 567818) It is thus a superstitious belief against which every lover of Hinduism should rise in rebellion.
('65', 308, 2, 13, 567916) Harijan, 9 11 1934
('65', 308, 3, 14, 567935) 354. RIGHT OF MINORITY
('65', 308, 4, 15, 567958) A sanatanist asks:
('65', 308, 5, 16, 567977) As a sanatanist I have a difficulty about temple entry by Harijans.
('65', 308, 5, 17, 568045) Supposing among temple goers of a particular temple there is a majority of 99 to I in favour of Harijans entering the temple and the temple is opened.
('65', 308, 5, 18, 568196) What about the minority of one who has objection to worshipping in a temple visited by Harijans?
('65', 308, 5, 19, 568293) If reformers have their way, will it not be an undue interference with the right of worship which belongs to the sanatanists from time immemorial?
('65', 308, 5, 20, 568440) There may be a public church of the Roman Catholics as well as a public church of Protestants in an English town.
('65', 308, 5, 21, 568554) Even if the Protestants be in a majority, they would not interfere with the conduct of affairs in the Roman Catholic church.
('65', 308, 5, 22, 568679) Why, then, should the reformers (even though in the majority) interfere with the conduct of affairs in a public temple belonging to the sanatanists?
('65', 308, 5, 23, 568828) I should answer the questions by putting another.
('65', 308, 5, 24, 568878) If the one solitary sanatanist has the right, as he undoubtedly has, what about the
('65', 309, 0, 1, 568962) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 309, 1, 2, 569004) majority?
('65', 309, 1, 3, 569014) Have they no rights?
('65', 309, 1, 4, 569035) The parallel quoted does not apply.
('65', 309, 1, 5, 569071) The questioner has imagined the existence side by side of two churches belonging to different denominations.
('65', 309, 1, 6, 569180) It would be a monstrous impertinence on the part of Protestants to interfere with the rights of Roman Catholics or vice versa.
('65', 309, 1, 7, 569307) But suppose all the Protestants but one decided to admit to their temple persons whom they had excommunicated for ages.
('65', 309, 1, 8, 569427) Surely, they would have every right to lift the ban.
('65', 309, 1, 9, 569480) Here there would be no question of changing one’s religion, as there is in the case imagined by the questioner.
('65', 309, 1, 10, 569592) In the temple entry movement, reformers do not seek to alter their faith.
('65', 309, 1, 11, 569666) If they did, in theory at least, not even a unanimous decision of temple goers of a temple should entitle them to use a temple for purposes never intended by the founders.
('65', 309, 1, 12, 569838) Here the reformers claim that the faith they profess in common with the sanatanists permits the use of their temples by fellow Hindus, the Harijans.
('65', 309, 1, 13, 569987) It is, therefore, a question of interpretation, and in such matters, the opinion of a majority must prevail.
('65', 309, 1, 14, 570096) If it did not, it would amount to the coercion of a majority by a minority, and there would be an end to all progress.
('65', 309, 1, 15, 570215) Indeed, the doctrine the questioner propounds would mean decay and death to a society that subscribes to it.
('65', 309, 1, 16, 570324) It should be remembered that the minority is free to build a temple for itself.
('65', 309, 1, 17, 570404) And so far as I am concerned, I have given my opinion that even a minority of one should have its prejudices so far respected that a special hour may be set apart so as to enable it to offer worship free from the intrusion, whether of reformers or of Harijans.
('65', 309, 2, 18, 570665) Harijan, 9 11 1934

('65', 313, 1, 8, 576087) What he feels is that you overrate your ability to do things and that you are generous at the expense of your trust.
('65', 313, 1, 9, 576204) As for instance, he related to me the story of outdoor boys whom you are training and for whom you are providing afternoon refreshments although it is no part of your job to do so and although the boys who come are not so poor as not to afford one or two pice for refreshments.

('65', 313, 1, 14, 576874) A trustee has to take the role of a miser in regard to his trust.

('65', 315, 0, 1, 578947) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 315, 1, 2, 578989) 364. INTERVIEW TO NIRMAL KUMAR BOSE1
('65', 315, 2, 3, 579026) November 9/10, 1934 2
('65', 315, 3, 4, 579048) QUESTION: .
('65', 315, 3, 5, 579060) Should khadi be merely a sort of humanitarian work or should we use it chiefly as an instrument of political education?
('65', 315, 3, 6, 579180) Our experience has been that unless the ultimate objective is kept clearly in mind, it degenerates easily into a work of no significance.
('65', 315, 3, 7, 579318) ANSWER: The two issues of khadi and political organization should be kept absolutely separate.
('65', 315, 3, 8, 579413) There must be no confusion.
('65', 315, 3, 9, 579441) The aim of khadi is humanitarian; but so far as India is concerned, its effect is bound to be immensely political.
('65', 315, 3, 10, 579556) The Salvation Army wants to teach people about God.
('65', 315, 3, 11, 579608) But they come with bread.
('65', 315, 3, 12, 579634) For the poor bread is their God.
('65', 315, 3, 13, 579667) Similarly we should bring food into the mouths of the people through khadi.
('65', 315, 3, 14, 579743) If we succeed in breaking the idleness of the people through khadi, they will begin to listen to us.
('65', 315, 3, 15, 579844) Whatever else the Government might do, it does leave some food for the villagers.
('65', 315, 3, 16, 579926) Unless we can bring food to them, why should the people listen to us?
('65', 315, 3, 17, 579996) When we have taught them what they can do through their own efforts, then they will want to listen to us.
('65', 315, 3, 18, 580102) That trust can best be generated through khadi.
('65', 315, 3, 19, 580150) While working out the khadi programme our aim should be purely humanitarian, that is, economic.
('65', 315, 3, 20, 580246) We should leave out all political considerations whatsoever.
('65', 315, 3, 21, 580307) But it is bound to produce important political consequences which nobody can prevent and nobody need deplore.
('65', 315, 4, 22, 580417) Q. Could we not start small battles on local and specific issues against capitalism in the villages and use them as a means of strengthening the people or bringing about a sense of co operation among them, in preference to the khadi method?
('65', 315, 4, 23, 580658) When we have a choice between the two, which should we prefer?
('65', 315, 4, 24, 580721) If we have to sacrifice all the work that we have built up in the villages in connection with khadi while fighting against the moneylender or the landed proprietor, for, say, a reduction in the rate of interest or increase in the share of agricultural produce, then what shall we do—provided the latter is more liable to evoke self confidence among the villagers than the khadi method of organization?
('65', 315, 4, 25, 581123) A. It is a big proviso you have added at the end of the question.
('65', 315, 4, 26, 581189) I cannot say if fights on local and specific issues against capitalists are more likely to generate the kind of determination and courage needed in a non violent campaign.
('65', 315, 4, 27, 581361) But if I concede you that point, then khadi
('65', 315, 5, 28, 581405) 1 According to the source, Nirmal Kumar Bose met Gandhiji on November 9 and 10. The report was published after correction by Gandhiji.
('65', 315, 5, 29, 581540) 2 ibid.
('65', 316, 0, 1, 581548) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 317
('65', 316, 1, 2, 581598) would have to be sacrificed under the circumstances you quote.
('65', 316, 1, 3, 581661) As a practical man, claiming to be an expert in non violent methods, I should advise you not to go in for that type of work in order to train the masses in self consciousness and attainment of power.
('65', 316, 1, 4, 581861) We are fighting for swaraj in the non violent way.
('65', 316, 1, 5, 581912) If many workers in different parts of India engage in local battles of the sort you describe, then, in times of necessity, people all over India will not be able to make a common cause in a fight for swaraj.
('65', 316, 1, 6, 582120) Before civil disobedience can be practised on a vast scale, people must learn the art of civil or voluntary obedience.
('65', 316, 1, 7, 582239) Our obedience to the Government is through fear; and the reaction against it is either violence itself or that species of it, which is cowardice.
('65', 316, 1, 8, 582385) But through khadi we teach people the art of civil obedience to an institution which they have built up for themselves.
('65', 316, 1, 9, 582505) Only when they have learnt that art can they successfully disobey something which they want to destroy in the non violent way.
('65', 316, 1, 10, 582632) This is why I should advise all workers not to fritter their fighting strength in many sided battles, but to concentrate on peaceful khadi work in order to educate the masses into a condition necessary for a successful practice of non violent non co operation.
('65', 316, 1, 11, 582893) With their own exploitation, boycott of foreign cloth through picketing may easily be violent; through the use of khadi it is most natural and absolutely non violent.
('65', 316, 2, 12, 583060) Q. Is love or non violence compatible.
('65', 316, 2, 13, 583099) with possession or exploitation in any shape or form?
('65', 316, 2, 14, 583153) If possession and non violence cannot go together, then do you advocate the maintenance of private ownership of land or factories at an unavoidable evil which will continue so long as individuals are not ripe or educated enough to do without it?
('65', 316, 2, 15, 583399) If it be such a step, would it not be better to own all the land through the State and place the State under the control of the masses?
('65', 316, 3, 16, 583535) A. Love and exclusive possession can never go together.
('65', 316, 3, 17, 583591) Theoretically when there is perfect love, there must be perfect non possession.
('65', 316, 3, 18, 583671) The body is our last possession.
('65', 316, 3, 19, 583704) So a man can only exercise perfect love and be completely dispossessed, if he is prepared to embrace death and renounce his body for the sake of human service.
('65', 316, 3, 20, 583864) But that is true in theory only.
('65', 316, 3, 21, 583897) In actual life, we can hardly exercise perfect love, for the body as a possession will always remain with us.
('65', 316, 3, 22, 584007) Man will ever remain imperfect, and it will always be his part to try to be perfect.
('65', 316, 3, 23, 584092) So that perfection in love or non possession will remain an unattainable ideal, as long as we are alive, but towards which we must ceaselessly strive.
('65', 317, 0, 1, 584243) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 317, 1, 2, 584285) Those who own money now are asked to behave like trustees holding their riches on behalf of the poor.
('65', 317, 1, 3, 584387) You may say that trusteeship is a legal fiction.
('65', 317, 1, 4, 584436) But if people meditate over it constantly and try to act up to it, then life on earth would be governed far more by love than it is at present.
('65', 317, 1, 5, 584580) Absolute trusteeship is an abstraction like Euclid’s definition of a point, and is equally unattainable.
('65', 317, 1, 6, 584685) But if we strive for it, we shall be able to go further in realizing a state of equality on earth than by any other method.
('65', 317, 2, 7, 584809) Q. If you say that private possession is incompatible with non violence, why do you put up with it?
('65', 317, 3, 8, 584909) A. That is a concession one has to make to those who earn money but who would not voluntarily use their earnings for the benefit of mankind.
('65', 317, 4, 9, 585050) Q. Why then not have State ownership in place of private property and thus minimize violence?
('65', 317, 4, 10, 585144) A. It is better than private ownership.
('65', 317, 4, 11, 585184) But that too is objectionable on the ground of violence.
('65', 317, 4, 12, 585241) It is my firm conviction that if the State suppressed capitalism by violence, it will be caught in the coils of violence itself, and will fail to develop nonviolence at any time.
('65', 317, 4, 13, 585420) The State represents violence in a concentrated and organized form.
('65', 317, 4, 14, 585488) The individual has a soul, but as the State is a soulless machine, it can never be weaned from violence to which it owes its very existence.
('65', 317, 4, 15, 585629) Hence I prefer the doctrine of trusteeship.
('65', 317, 5, 16, 585673) Q. Let us come to a specific instance.
('65', 317, 5, 17, 585712) Supposing an artist leaves certain pictures to a son who does not appreciate their value for the nation and sells them or wastes them, so that the nation stands to lose something precious through one person’s folly.
('65', 317, 5, 18, 585928) If you are assured that the son would never be a trustee in the sense in which you would like him to be, do you not think the State would be justified in taking away those things from him with the minimum use of violence?
('65', 317, 5, 19, 586150) A. Yes, the State will, as a matter of fact, take away those things, and I believe it will be justified if it uses the minimum of violence.
('65', 317, 5, 20, 586290) But the fear is always there that the State may use too much violence against those who differ from it.
('65', 317, 5, 21, 586394) I would be very happy indeed if the people concerned behaved as trustees; but if they fail, I believe we shall have to deprive them of their possessions through the State with the minimum exercise of violence.
('65', 317, 5, 22, 586604) That is why I said 1 at the Round Table Conference that every vested interest must be subjected to scrutiny, and confiscation ordered where necessary with or without compensation as the case demanded.
('65', 317, 6, 23, 586805) 1 Vide “Extract from proceedings of the federal structure committee meeting”, 19 11 1931.
('65', 318, 0, 1, 586895) VOL.65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 319
('65', 318, 1, 2, 586945) What I would personally prefer would be not a centralization of power in the hands of the State, but.
('65', 318, 1, 3, 587047) an extension of the sense of trusteeship; as in my opinion the violence of private ownership is less injurious than the violence of the State.
('65', 318, 1, 4, 587190) However, if it is unavoidable, I would support a minimum of State ownership.
('65', 318, 2, 5, 587267) Q. Then, sir, shall we take it that the fundamental difference between you and the Socialists is that you believe that men live more by self direction or will than by habit, and they believe that men live more by habit than by will; that being the reason why do you strive for self correction while they try to build up a system under which men will find it impossible to exercise their desire for exploiting others?
('65', 318, 3, 6, 587684) A. While admitting that man actually lives by habit, I hold that it is better for him to live by the exercise of will.
('65', 318, 3, 7, 587803) I also believe that men are capable of developing their will to an extent that will reduce exploitation to a minimum.
('65', 318, 3, 8, 587921) I look upon an increase of the power of the State with the greatest fear, because although while apparently doing good by minimizing exploitation, it does the greatest harm to mankind by destroying individuality, which lies at the root of all progress.
('65', 318, 3, 9, 588174) We know of so many cases where men have adopted trusteeship, but none where the State has really lived for the poor.
('65', 318, 4, 10, 588291) Q. But have not those cases of trusteeship which you sometimes cite been due to your personal influence rather than to anything else?
('65', 318, 4, 11, 588425) Teachers like you come infrequently.
('65', 318, 4, 12, 588462) Would it not be better, therefore, to trust to some organization to effect the necessary changes in man, rather than depend upon the casual advent of men like yourself?
('65', 318, 5, 13, 588631) A. Leaving me aside, you must remember that the influence of all great teachers of mankind has outlived their lives.
('65', 318, 5, 14, 588748) In the teachings of each prophet like Mohammed, Buddha or Jesus, there was a permanent portion and there was another which was suited to the needs and requirements of the times.
('65', 318, 5, 15, 588926) It is only because we try to keep up the permanent with the impermanent aspects of their teachings that there is so much distortion in religious practice today.
('65', 318, 5, 16, 589087) But that apart, you can see that the influence of these men has sustained us after they have passed away.
('65', 318, 5, 17, 589193) Moreover, what I disapprove of is an organization based on force which a State is.
('65', 318, 5, 18, 589276) Voluntary organization there must be.
('65', 318, 6, 19, 589314) Q. What then, sir, is your ideal social order?
('65', 318, 6, 20, 589361) A. I believe that every man is born in the world with certain natural tendencies.
('65', 318, 6, 21, 589443) Every person is born with certain definite limitations which he cannot overcome.
('65', 318, 6, 22, 589524) From a careful observation of those limitations the law of varna was deduced.
('65', 318, 6, 23, 589602) It establishes certain
('65', 319, 0, 1, 589625) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 319, 1, 2, 589667) spheres of action of certain people with certain tendencies.
('65', 319, 1, 3, 589728) This avoided all unworthy competition.
('65', 319, 1, 4, 589767) Whilst, recognizing limitations, the law of ‘varna’ admitted of no distinctions of high and low, on the one hand it guaranteed to each the fruits of his labours and on the other it prevented him from pressing upon his neighbour.
('65', 319, 1, 5, 589996) This great law has been degraded and [has] fallen into disrepute.
('65', 319, 1, 6, 590062) But my conviction is that an ideal social order will only be evolved when the implications of this law are fully understood and given effect to.
('65', 319, 2, 7, 590207) Q. Do you not think that in ancient India there was much difference in economic status and social privileges between the four varnas?
('65', 319, 2, 8, 590341) A. That may be historically true.
('65', 319, 2, 9, 590375) But misapplication or an imperfect understanding of the law must not lead to the ignoring of the law itself.
('65', 319, 2, 10, 590484) By constant striving we have to enrich the inheritance left to us.
('65', 319, 2, 11, 590551) This law determines the duties of man.
('65', 319, 2, 12, 590590) Rights follow from a due performance of duties.
('65', 319, 2, 13, 590638) It is the fashion nowadays to ignore duties and assert or rather usurp rights.
('65', 319, 3, 14, 590717) Q. If you are so keen upon reviving varnashrama, why do you not favour violence as the quickest means?
('65', 319, 3, 15, 590820) A. Surely the question does not arise.
('65', 319, 3, 16, 590859) Definition and performance of duties rule out violence altogether.
('65', 319, 3, 17, 590926) Violence becomes imperative when an attempt is made to assert rights without reference to duties.
('65', 319, 4, 18, 591024) Q. Should we not confine our pursuit of Truth to ourselves and not press it upon the world because we know that it is ultimately limited in character?
('65', 319, 4, 19, 591175) A. You cannot so circumscribe truth even if you try.
('65', 319, 4, 20, 591228) Every expression of truth has in it the seeds of propagation, even as the sun cannot hide its light.
('65', 319, 5, 21, 591329) The Hindustan Times, 17 10 1935

('65', 320, 3, 10, 592592) 366. LETTER TO SURESH CHANDRA BANERJI November 10, 1934
('65', 320, 4, 11, 592648) MY DEAR SURESH, I have your letter.
('65', 320, 4, 12, 592684) I do wish you to get on well.
('65', 320, 4, 13, 592714) I have sent you messages through Prafulla.
('65', 320, 4, 14, 592757) One thing I want to emphasize.
('65', 320, 4, 15, 592788) Just as a prisoner has no right to think of the world outside the prison walls, much less to form any opinion about what he may hear of events taking place outside his little universe of the jail, so also should a sick person lying on his bed cease to apply his mind to problems of the world outside the sick room.
('65', 320, 4, 16, 593103) He is no longer taking an active part in those events; he honestly becomes unfit to give a correct judgment.
('65', 320, 4, 17, 593212) This is also the ideal put before the sannyasi.
('65', 320, 4, 18, 593260) Immediately a man takes sannyasa he is supposed to cut himself off from the day to day activities of the world.
('65', 320, 4, 19, 593372) If these very simple obvious facts of life were borne in mind we should be spared so much misery, misunderstanding and so many errors; and prisoners, sick people and sannyasis would lead peaceful lives and do justice to their respective stations.
('65', 320, 4, 20, 593619) If you are not in pain, I would like you to do one thing: that is, to write out the medical chapters for Satisbabu’s book.
('65', 320, 4, 21, 593742) I want a good guide for village workers.
('65', 320, 4, 22, 593783) The conception is to produce a book after Moore’s Family Medicine or Everybody His Own Doctor.
