('65', 323, 3, 8, 597298) 372. LETTER TO SAM HIGGINBOTTOM November 11, 1934
('65', 323, 4, 9, 597348) DEAR FRIEND, I do appreciate your letter of the 8th instant just received.
('65', 323, 4, 10, 597423) Do please send me all your suggestions.
('65', 323, 4, 11, 597463) You would have seen the brief statement I had issued.
('65', 323, 4, 12, 597517) Nevertheless I send you a copy for ready reference.
('65', 323, 4, 13, 597569) It represents an outline of my mind’s working.
('65', 323, 4, 14, 597616) I do not propose to tour in connection with the work, at least not at the present moment.
('65', 323, 4, 15, 597706) I am holding informal discussions with friends interested in the project, and I have Prof.
('65', 323, 4, 16, 597797) Kumarappa with me just now.
('65', 323, 4, 17, 597825) I would love to meet you in the course of the month after a preliminary exchange of views by correspondence.
('65', 323, 4, 18, 597934) That will enable us to save our time at the time of discussion.
('65', 323, 4, 19, 597998) I am sure you realize one fundamental fact.
('65', 323, 4, 20, 598042) What applies to America and England does not necessarily apply to India.
('65', 323, 4, 21, 598115) India has in her teeming millions so many superfluous days that she does not need to free the energy of her sons for superior or more remunerative work through highly developed machinery.
('65', 323, 4, 22, 598303) In her 350 million children she has so many living ready made machines, and if she can utilize their labour, half of which is running to waste, the double starvation of the body and the mind will cease.
('65', 323, 4, 23, 598506) That is the problem that faced me when I returned to India in 1915, and has haunted me ever since.
('65', 323, 5, 24, 598605) Yours sincerely, PROF.
('65', 323, 5, 25, 598628) SAM HIGGINBOTTOM ALLAHABAD CHRISTIAN COLLEGE AGRICULTURAL INSTITUTE, ALLAHABAD

('65', 329, 4, 6, 606420) 381. LETTER TO H. L. SHARMA
('65', 329, 5, 7, 606448) November 12, 1934 2
('65', 329, 6, 8, 606468) SHARMA,
('65', 329, 7, 9, 606476) I could understand what you say in your letter.
('65', 329, 7, 10, 606524) It is written in a plain straightforward manner but it is full of your ignorance.
('65', 329, 7, 11, 606606) If you go to England you must acquire a degree and it takes a minimum of seven years to attain a genuine degree and in no case less than five years.
('65', 329, 7, 12, 606755) And all that you will get will be what you could have achieved here itself.
('65', 329, 7, 13, 606831) You have made a grave allegation against British educated as well as Indian educated doctors.
('65', 329, 7, 14, 606925) At present there are doctors of both the types who perform the work of a Bhangi and feel no shame in that.
('65', 329, 7, 15, 607032) Rupees 3, 000 is not enough these days for seven years.
('65', 329, 7, 16, 607088) You should have at least Rs. 30,000. And Rs. 60,000 if you take Draupadi along with you.
('65', 329, 7, 17, 607177) This is the minimum sum needed for seven years.
('65', 329, 7, 18, 607225) In spite of my simple living it cost me Rs. 13,000 for three years.
('65', 329, 7, 19, 607293) And the cost of living has now doubled.
('65', 329, 7, 20, 607333) But the consideration of money may be looked upon as secondary.
('65', 329, 7, 21, 607397) I am strongly opposed to the very idea of going to England.
('65', 329, 7, 22, 607457) Going to England might be proper only after one has acquired a basic knowledge of one’s subject.
('65', 329, 7, 23, 607554) I have no doubt that the basic knowledge can be easily acquired in India itself.
('65', 329, 7, 24, 607635) The notion of going to England is simply mistaken and must be put an end to.
('65', 329, 7, 25, 607712) If you think that you are not in error you may rebel against me and go in dependently without my blessings.

('65', 338, 5, 21, 620157) 398. LETTER TO SHANKERLAL BANKER
('65', 338, 6, 22, 620190) November 14, 1934
('65', 338, 7, 23, 620208) MY DEAR SHANKERLAL,
('65', 338, 8, 24, 620228) I have gone through the papers in connection with the prize competition.
('65', 338, 8, 25, 620301) Without prejudice to his right to get the prize on fulfilling the conditions laid down, it strikes me that the machine seems to be otherwise useful.
('65', 338, 8, 26, 620450) We might ask Kirloskar Brothers to let us buy some machines so as to enable us to experiment on them and find out by experience their workability, also defects if any, and determine finally whether we can declare the machine as the prize winner or whether we can, without giving the prize, provide a market for the machine.
('65', 338, 8, 27, 620774) From all the descriptions I have received of the machine it appears to me to be complicated and too unworkable to win the prize.
('65', 338, 8, 28, 620903) But we might be able to make use of the machine in
('65', 338, 9, 29, 620954) 1 This is not available.
('65', 339, 0, 1, 620979) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 339, 1, 2, 621021) order to supply the hand spun yarn to our depots and to those who may desire to take in hand spun yarn.
('65', 339, 1, 3, 621125) We might also by making extensive experiments find out whether the yarn is equal to the mill yarn from the point of view of weavers.
('65', 339, 1, 4, 621258) If you think that this may be done, I would send for a representative of Kirloskar Brothers and talk to him unless you think that the time is not ripe for such conversation or that if the conversations are carried on they should be carried on by you.
('65', 339, 1, 5, 621509) Kirloskar Brothers did write to me offering to send a machine and Sjt.
('65', 339, 1, 6, 621580) Kale so as to enable me to watch its working.
('65', 339, 1, 7, 621626) I send you a copy of my reply 1 to them.

('65', 346, 2, 3, 629729) November 15, 1934
('65', 346, 3, 4, 629747) DEAR FRIEND,
('65', 346, 4, 5, 629760) His Excellency has probably seen the public statement 1 I have made of my intention to visit the Frontier Province as soon as possible consistently with my preoccupations.
('65', 346, 4, 6, 629932) I am likely to be free after the middle of December.
('65', 346, 4, 7, 629985) My object in wishing to visit the Frontier Province is to be with its people, to know them at first hand and to understand how far the teaching of non violence by Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan has permeated his followers.
('65', 346, 4, 8, 630207) It is also my intention to help them in the development of their village industries.
('65', 346, 4, 9, 630292) I need hardly say that I have no desire whatsoever to inculcate among the Frontier people the spirit of disobedience (civil or otherwise) of authority.
('65', 346, 4, 10, 630444) Though I know that there is no legal bar against my entering the Frontier Province, I have no desire to do anything that may bring me in conflict with the Government.
('65', 346, 4, 11, 630611) It is my earnest effort to avoid such conflict in so far as it is humanly possible.
('65', 346, 4, 12, 630695) Will you kindly ascertain His Excellency’s wishes in the matter and let me know them?
('65', 346, 5, 13, 630781) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('65', 349, 0, 1, 634664) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 349, 1, 2, 634706) 418. INTERVIEW TO “THE MANCHESTER GUARDIAN”
('65', 349, 2, 3, 634750) [November 15, 1934] 1
('65', 349, 3, 4, 634772) [GANDHIJI:] I am ready for your questions.
('65', 349, 4, 5, 634815) [CORRESPONDENT:] Does your retirement from the Congress mean that you take no more interest in politics?
('65', 349, 4, 6, 634920) [G.] No.
('65', 349, 5, 7, 634929) He had no intention of immediately returning to active politics, but it certainly did not mean retirement for the present, he explained, in guiding the new Village Industries Organization, in solving the Hindu Moslem problem, and continuing the campaign against untouchability.
('65', 349, 5, 8, 635207) He said: All these movements will be non political in the narrow sense of the term.
('65', 349, 6, 9, 635291) [C.] Supposing that the Joint Committee’s report gives even less than the White Paper, what will be your reaction to it?
('65', 349, 7, 10, 635412) He was quite prepared to believe that the forecast was correct, but did not seem willing to commit himself.
('65', 349, 7, 11, 635520) He contrasted the procedure actually followed by the British Government in regard to the reforms with that outlined by Mr. MacDonald in the House of Commons soon after the termination of the second session of the Round Table Conference.
('65', 349, 7, 12, 635757) 2 The Prime Minister had spoken of a settlement with India’s representatives (though, Mr. Gandhi pointed out with emphasis, the Round Table delegates were only nominees of the British Government) to be initialled by both parties, and that settlement would then be the basis of Parliamentary legislation.
('65', 349, 8, 13, 636061) [C.] The same thing had happened in Ireland.
('65', 349, 8, 14, 636106) [G.] Yes, the Irish parallel does hold good—but not just yet.
('65', 349, 9, 15, 636168) At this point, I drew his attention to a recent statement by General Smuts in Britain.
('65', 349, 9, 16, 636255) General Smuts had said that it was an act of faith on the part of the British to have conferred self government on South Africa, and a similar act of faith in regard to India would, in his view, be justified by subsequent results.
('65', 349, 10, 17, 636486) 1 In the introductory paragraph the correspondent states that the interview began after Gandhiji signed the letters seeking assistance from “experts” to become advisers of the All India Village Industries Association.
('65', 349, 10, 18, 636704) Vide “Letter to Rabindranath Tagore”, 15 11 1934. 2 Held in 1931.
('65', 350, 0, 1, 636770) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 351
('65', 350, 1, 2, 636821) [G.] I was in South Africa at the time and can see no similarity between the two cases.
('65', 350, 1, 3, 636909) In the case of the Boers, it was not an act of faith, but making a virtue of necessity.
('65', 350, 2, 4, 636997) [C.] How ?
('65', 350, 2, 5, 637008) [G.] The Boer War was a virtual defeat for the British.
('65', 350, 2, 6, 637064) They were sick and weary of the fight, and their resources were getting exhausted.
('65', 350, 2, 7, 637147) of course, as an Imperial Power, they could have carried it on; but the tide was rising fast in favour of Campbell Bannerman.
('65', 350, 2, 8, 637273) King Edward’s instructions to Lord Milner were to conciliate the Boers.
('65', 350, 2, 9, 637345) I will grant that whatever was done was done not grudging]y but handsomely.
('65', 350, 3, 10, 637421) [C.] And so ?
('65', 350, 3, 11, 637435) [G.] And so, I go back to the statement 1 I made some weeks ago to the Con,ress in Bombay—that is, no constitutional agitation will ever achieve freedom for a country.
('65', 350, 4, 12, 637603) Nothing was ever gained that way, according to his reading of French or British history, and he had put that point to Lord Lothian and a few others with whom he had discussed the Indian problem at oxford three years ago.
('65', 350, 5, 13, 637824) Mr. Gandhi made it clear beyond doubt that his conviction was that Britain would never grant to India self government of the kind South Africa enjoys today so long as she has “nothing to act upon”.
('65', 350, 5, 14, 638022) She does not feel that civil resistance has been successful; there is a sense of exultation that the movement has been paralysed.
('65', 350, 6, 15, 638152) Pursuing the point further, I asked him whether apart from the circumstances under which self government was granted to South Africa (and which do not, according to him, exist in India), the contents of that measure would satisfy him—in other words, what is the independence he aims at?
('65', 350, 6, 16, 638439) He did not seem disposed to discuss the question in detail.
('65', 350, 6, 17, 638499) But he said the goal, for him, was defined in the concluding portion of his statement 2 at the second Round Table Conference; if membership of the British Common.
('65', 350, 6, 18, 638662) wealth was forced upon India, he would resist it; but if it was voluntary partnership, terminable at will, he would have no objection to such an association.
('65', 350, 6, 19, 638820) So far as he was concerned, it was the statement of an “eternal position”.
('65', 350, 7, 20, 638895) But at present he is “ immersed” in the building up of the Village Industries Organization.
('65', 350, 7, 21, 638987) His recent walking tour through the villages in connection with the
('65', 350, 8, 22, 639055) 1 Vide “Speech at subjects committee meeting A.I.C.C.”, 23 10 1934. 2 Vide “Speech at plenary session of round table conference”, 1 12 1931.

('65', 351, 1, 2, 639238) anti untouchability campaign was a revelation to him.
('65', 351, 1, 3, 639292) The village people seemed to him “inert and despondent’,.
('65', 351, 1, 4, 639350) Their poverty stricken conditions have been making “a more and more forcible appeal”.
('65', 351, 1, 5, 639436) The revival of village industries would infuse life into occupations that are now dying out.

('65', 351, 2, 7, 639614) He is visualizing to himself the 700,000 villages of India, and his ambition is to spread out his workers in as many as possible.
('65', 351, 3, 8, 639744) Spinning, on which he has set his heart for many years, he confessed, is the lowest paid of rural occupations.

('65', 352, 1, 10, 641776) The permanent part of him triumphs over the ashes and appears clearer to us for their removal.
('65', 352, 1, 11, 641871) Let us cherish Lalaji’s memory in that light and let Harijan Hindus and caste Hindus make a fresh resolve in Lalaji’s memory to cleanse society of the curse of untouchability—the former by ridding themselves of the defects arising out of their suppression, and the latter by shedding the sin of the feeling of superiority, which belief in natal untouchability implies.

('65', 352, 3, 13, 642260) 421. VILLAGE INDUSTRIES
('65', 352, 4, 14, 642284) As the author of the Congress resolutions 1 on village industries and as the sole guide of the Association that is being formed for their promotion, it is but meet that I should, as far as possible, share with the public the ideas that are uppermost in my mind regarding these industries and the moral and hygienic uplift that is intimately associated with them.
('65', 352, 4, 15, 642647) The idea of forming the Association took definite shape during the Harijan tour as early as when I entered Malabar.
('65', 352, 4, 16, 642763) A casual talk with a khadi worker showed to me how necessary it was to have a body that would make an honest attempt to return to the villagers what has been cruelly and thoughtlessly snatched away from them by the city dwellers.
('65', 352, 4, 17, 642993) The hardest hit among the villagers are the Harijans.
('65', 352, 4, 18, 643047) They have but a limited choice of the industries that are open to the villagers in general.
('65', 352, 4, 19, 643139) Therefore, when their industries slip away from their hands, they become like the beasts of burden with whom their lot
('65', 352, 5, 20, 643258) 1 Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee Meeting, A. I. C. C”, 24 10 1934.
('65', 353, 0, 1, 643329) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 353, 1, 2, 643371) is cast.
('65', 353, 1, 3, 643380) Let the doubting reader peruse Prof.
('65', 353, 1, 4, 643417) Malkani’s article reproduced elsewhere 1 and he will realize the truth of my statement.
('65', 353, 1, 5, 643505) But the villagers in general are not much better off today.
('65', 353, 1, 6, 643565) Bit by bit they are being confined only to the hand to mouth business of scratching the earth.
('65', 353, 1, 7, 643660) Few know today that agriculture in the small and irregular holdings of India is not a paying proposition.
('65', 353, 1, 8, 643766) The villagers live a lifeless life.
('65', 353, 1, 9, 643802) Their life is a process of slow starvation.
('65', 353, 1, 10, 643846) They are burdened with debts.
('65', 353, 1, 11, 643876) The moneylender lends, because he can do no otherwise.
('65', 353, 1, 12, 643931) He will lose all if he does not.
('65', 353, 1, 13, 643964) This system of village lending baffles investigation.
('65', 353, 1, 14, 644018) our knowledge of it is superficial, in spite of elaborate inquiries.
('65', 353, 1, 15, 644087) Extinction of village industries would complete the ruin of the 7,00,000 villages of India.
('65', 353, 1, 16, 644179) I have seen in the daily Press criticism of the proposals I have adumbrated.
('65', 353, 1, 17, 644256) Advice has been given to me that I must look for salvation in the direction of using the powers of nature that the inventive brain of man has brought under subjection.
('65', 353, 1, 18, 644424) The critics say that water, air, oil and electricity should be fully uti lized as they are being utilized in the go ahead West.
('65', 353, 1, 19, 644552) They say that control over these hidden powers of nature enables every American to have 33 slaves.
('65', 353, 1, 20, 644651) Repeat the process in India and I dare say that it will thirty three times enslave every inhabitant of this land, instead of giving everyone thirty three slaves.
('65', 353, 1, 21, 644813) Mechanization is good when the hands are too few for the work intended to be accomplished.
('65', 353, 1, 22, 644904) It is an evil when there are more hands than required for the work, as is the case in India.
('65', 353, 1, 23, 644997) I may not use a plough for digging a few square yards of a plot of land.
('65', 353, 1, 24, 645070) The problem with us is not how to find leisure for the teeming millions inhabiting our villages.
('65', 353, 1, 25, 645167) The problem is how to utilize their idle hours, which are equal to the working days of six months in the year.
('65', 353, 1, 26, 645278) Strange as it may appear, every mill generally is a menace to the villagers.
('65', 353, 1, 27, 645355) I have not worked out the figures, but I am quite safe in saying that every mill hand does the work of at least ten labourers doing the same work in their villages.
('65', 353, 1, 28, 645520) In other words he earns more than he did in his village at the expense of ten fellow villagers.
('65', 353, 1, 29, 645616) Thus spinning and weaving
('65', 353, 2, 30, 645642) 1 It appeared in Harijan, 23 11 1934, under the title “The Story of the Desert of Sind”.
('65', 354, 0, 1, 645731) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 355
('65', 354, 1, 2, 645782) mills have deprived the villagers of a substantial means of livelihood.
('65', 354, 1, 3, 645854) It is no answer in reply to say that they turn out cheaper, better cloth, if they do so at all.
('65', 354, 1, 4, 645950) For, if they have displaced thousands of workers, the cheapest mill cloth is dearer than the dearest khadi woven in the villages.
('65', 354, 1, 5, 646080) Coal is not dear for the coal miner who can use it there and then, nor is khadi dear for the villager who manufactures his own khadi.
('65', 354, 1, 6, 646214) But if the cloth manufactured in mills displaces village hands, rice mills and flour mills not only displace thousands of poor women workers, but damage the health of the whole population in the bargain.
('65', 354, 1, 7, 646418) Where people have no objection to taking flesh diet and can afford it, white flour and polished rice may do no harm, but in India, where millions can get no flesh diet even where they have no objection to eating it, it they can get it, it is sinful to deprive them of nutritious and vital elements contained in whole wheat meal and unpolished rice.
('65', 354, 1, 8, 646767) It is time medical men and others combined to instruct the people on the danger attendant upon the use of white flour and polished rice.
('65', 354, 1, 9, 646904) I have drawn attention to some broad glaring facts to show that the way to take work to the villagers is not through mechanization but that it lies through revival of the industries they have hitherto followed.
('65', 354, 1, 10, 647115) Hence the function of the All India Village Industries Associ ation must, in my opinion, be to encourage the existing industries and to revive, where it is possible and desirable, the dying or dead industries of villages according to the village methods, i.e., the villagers working in their own cottages as they have done from times immemorial.
('65', 354, 1, 11, 647461) These simple methods can be considerably improved as they have been in hand ginning, hand carding, hand spinning and hand weaving.
('65', 354, 1, 12, 647592) A critic objects that the ancient plan is purely individualistic and can never bring about corporate effort.
('65', 354, 1, 13, 647701) This view appears to me to be very superficial.
('65', 354, 1, 14, 647749) Though articles may be manufactured by villagers in their cottages, they can be pooled together and profits divided.
('65', 354, 1, 15, 647866) The villagers may work under supervision and according to plan.
('65', 354, 1, 16, 647930) The raw material may be supplied from common stock.
('65', 354, 1, 17, 647982) If the will to co operative effort is created, there is surely ample opportunity for co operation, division of labour, saving of time and efficiency of work.
('65', 354, 1, 18, 648140) All these things are today being done by the All India Spinners’ Association in over 5,000 villages.
('65', 355, 0, 1, 648241) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 355, 1, 2, 648283) But khadi is the sun of the village solar system.
('65', 355, 1, 3, 648333) The planets are the various industries which can support khadi in return for the heat and the sustenance they derive from it.
('65', 355, 1, 4, 648459) Without it, the other industries cannot grow.
('65', 355, 1, 5, 648505) But during my last tour I discovered that, without the revival of the other industries, khadi could not make further progress.
('65', 355, 1, 6, 648632) For villagers to be able to occupy their spare time profitably, the village life must be touched at all points.
('65', 355, 1, 7, 648744) That is what the two Associations are expected to do.
('65', 355, 1, 8, 648798) Naturally they can have nothing to do with politics or political parties.
('65', 355, 1, 9, 648872) The Congress, in my opinion, did well in making both the Associations autonomous and wholly non political.
('65', 355, 1, 10, 648979) All parties and all communities can combine to uplift the villages economically, morally and hygienically.
('65', 355, 1, 11, 649086) I know that there is a school of thought that does not regard khadi as an economic proposition at all.
('65', 355, 1, 12, 649189) I hope that they will not be scared by my having mentioned khadi as the centre of village activities.
('65', 355, 1, 13, 649291) I could not complete the picture of my mind without showing the inter relation between khadi and the other village industries.
('65', 355, 1, 14, 649418) Those who do not see it are welcome only to concentrate their effort on the other industries.
('65', 355, 1, 15, 649512) But this, too, they will be able to do through the new Association, if they appreciate the background I have endeavoured to give in this article.

('65', 370, 1, 2, 667579) 446. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL November 18, 1939
('65', 370, 2, 3, 667630) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I see from your three letters that you have not got a clear picture of the Village Industries Association in your mind.
('65', 370, 2, 4, 667768) The idea behind it is that we should exclusively buy from villages whatever articles they can produce.
('65', 370, 2, 5, 667871) We can thereby repay a little of the debt that we owe to them.
('65', 370, 2, 6, 667934) Whether or not we shall be able to do this is another matter.
('65', 370, 2, 7, 667996) We need not proceed on the supposition that we shall not.
('65', 370, 2, 8, 668054) What was started by only six or seven of us has now spread all over the country.
('65', 370, 2, 9, 668135) If it is our duty to do what I am suggesting, then all of us should use pens, ink, knives, soap, jaggery and sugar manufactured in villages and flour and rice ground or milled in villages.
('65', 370, 2, 10, 668324) I have mentioned these things only as examples.
('65', 370, 2, 11, 668372) Maybe we shall not carry out this idea in respect of many of the things enumerated; if, however, we believe that it is our moral duty to use such articles, we shall be putting crores of rupees into the pockets of villagers and the importance of villages will increase.
('65', 370, 2, 12, 668641) only then shall we be able to establish the swaraj of our dreams, devoted to the welfare of villages, and only then will it be non violent swaraj.
('65', 370, 2, 13, 668788) All other things can be deduced from this.
('65', 370, 2, 14, 668831) The Association can function only if it gets five or six full time workers.
('65', 370, 2, 15, 668907) We are trying to attract for it some Congress minded persons who are not regular Congressmen.
('65', 370, 2, 16, 669001) of course some of the workers will have to be Congressmen.
('65', 370, 2, 17, 669060) I am trying to persuade Jairamdas, hoping that Rajendrababu and you will be able to spare him and that he will agree to be released.
('65', 370, 2, 18, 669193) If he cannot do this work, he will be of no service.
('65', 370, 2, 19, 669246) I am discussing the same problem with Khan Saheb.
('65', 370, 2, 20, 669296) I don’t know what Jalbhai’s attitude will be.
('65', 370, 2, 21, 669342) If he refuses, I intend to invite Khurshed.
('65', 370, 2, 22, 669386) Such at any rate are my dreams.
('65', 370, 2, 23, 669418) I am indifferent whether or not they are realized.
('65', 370, 2, 24, 669469) They help to preserve my peace of mind.
('65', 370, 2, 25, 669509) If you are now free please come over.
('65', 370, 2, 26, 669547) The treatment of your nose must get priority, of course.
('65', 370, 2, 27, 669604) How many workers from Gujarat may I engage in this work?
('65', 370, 2, 28, 669661) Raojibhai has written to me and expressed his willingness.
('65', 370, 2, 29, 669720) I have replied to him saying that, even if he can be free, he can come only if permitted by you.
('65', 370, 2, 30, 669817) We shall also have to think about the headquarters.
('65', 370, 2, 31, 669869) The election results were really wonderful.
('65', 370, 2, 32, 669913) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]
('65', 370, 3, 33, 669949) Bapuna Patro 2: Sardar Vallabhbhaine, pp.

('65', 374, 2, 3, 673301) November 19, 1934
('65', 374, 3, 4, 673319) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS,
('65', 374, 4, 5, 673338) I have your letter.
('65', 374, 4, 6, 673358) How can I say what I need?
('65', 374, 4, 7, 673385) Whenever there is a question of a hundred or two or a thousand I ask you for it.
('65', 374, 4, 8, 673466) But by taking up the huge work of village industries I have increased my own commitments.
('65', 374, 4, 9, 673556) Thus I can only say that you may give me whatever is left after making other essential donations.
('65', 374, 4, 10, 673654) The formation of a board for village industries is presenting some difficulties.
('65', 374, 4, 11, 673735) I want the board to be very small, to consist of a minimum of three members and a maximum of ten.
('65', 374, 4, 12, 673833) I want men who have full faith in its aims and can devote more or less their full time to it.
('65', 374, 4, 13, 673927) And this precisely is giving me some trouble.
('65', 374, 4, 14, 673973) Have you any ideas in this respect ?
('65', 374, 4, 15, 674010) Do you know Rajkumari Amrit Kaur?
('65', 374, 4, 16, 674044) I have for a long time desired to go and live in Utmanzai, the village of Khan Saheb.
('65', 374, 4, 17, 674130) I have sent a letter to Delhi on Thursday.
('65', 374, 4, 18, 674173) 1 I have given the reason for a visit to the Frontier Province and have asked if there is any objection to my going there.
('65', 374, 4, 19, 674296) Let us see what reply I get.
('65', 374, 4, 20, 674325) When is the operation to take place?

('65', 375, 5, 11, 675266) 455. LETTER TO G. V. MAVALANKAR
('65', 375, 6, 12, 675298) November 20, 1934
('65', 375, 7, 13, 675316) BHAI MAVALANKAR,
('65', 375, 8, 14, 675333) You cannot be permitted to engage yourself exclusively in minting money.
('65', 375, 8, 15, 675406) I hope you will agree to shoulder the burden of the Harijan Ashram and the dairy.
('65', 375, 8, 16, 675488) We must find the expenses of the Harijan Ashram and of Harijan work in Gujarat from Gujarat itself.
('65', 375, 8, 17, 675588) I am sure in my mind that the burden of begging this sum should not have to be borne by Sardar.
('65', 375, 8, 18, 675684) He will contribute something voluntarily, but refuses to put himself to trouble on that account.
('65', 375, 8, 19, 675781) My purpose in inviting you, Ranchhodlal and Shankerlal is that either all of you should pay the expenses or beg for them.
('65', 375, 8, 20, 675903) I hope you will not want me to beg from outside Gujarat.
('65', 375, 8, 21, 675960) And, besides, how far can I be depended upon?
('65', 375, 8, 22, 676006) Before long you and I will know where I am.
('65', 375, 8, 23, 676050) Please, therefore, spare some time from the business of money making and give a little of it to Harijan work and a little to the service of the cow.
('65', 375, 8, 24, 676199) If, however, my guess is wrong and if at present you cannot spare a single moment for philanthropic work from the task of earning money to pay off your debt, in case you are in debt, tell me frankly and I will not then pester you.
('65', 375, 8, 25, 676430) I have now reached my 66th year making people work beyond their capacity.
('65', 375, 8, 26, 676504) How can the old hardened habit leave completely, although I have now grown somewhat indifferent ?
('65', 375, 8, 27, 676602) I am leaving the Congress, yielding to the feeling that no one should work
('65', 375, 9, 28, 676677) 1 2 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee
('65', 376, 0, 1, 676718) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 377
('65', 376, 1, 2, 676769) beyond his capacity but I have not yet parted company from my personal co workers.
('65', 376, 1, 3, 676852) To achieve this I must stop wielding my pen and resort to silence or I must work only through our journals.
('65', 376, 1, 4, 676960) But I am not yet powerful enough to work in this manner.
('65', 376, 1, 5, 677017) I have not yet completely got over my infatuation, and so I am driven to write letters such as this.
('65', 376, 1, 6, 677118) But I warn you not to have any false sense of shame on my account.
('65', 376, 1, 7, 677185) I shall be content if you do whatever you can as a matter of dharma.
('65', 376, 1, 8, 677254) I have written, much to the same effect, to Ranchhodlal and Shankerlal.

('65', 380, 4, 19, 683503) I didn’t like her ways at all.

('65', 382, 4, 7, 685750) I think you know the scope of the Association and the v method of achieving its object.
('65', 382, 4, 8, 685838) Would you care to serve on the Central Board?
('65', 382, 4, 9, 685884) If you will, have you got a living belief in the formula underlying the object, namely, that we must go to the villages in search of all the articles of daily use, and not make villages look to the cities for the supply of such articles?
('65', 382, 4, 10, 686122) That is to say, do you recognize the necessity, so far as it is possible, of eliminating the city factories and mills which are fast displacing the village industries, and supplying the daily wants of the villagers thereby confining 90 per cent of the population of India to bare agriculture?
('65', 382, 4, 11, 686415) Do you consider the realization of this object worthy of your making it the main business of your life, and will you give the Board most of your time?
('65', 382, 4, 12, 686566) If you will, I would like you to serve on the Board.
('65', 382, 4, 13, 686619) The idea that we are evolving is to make the Board as small as possible, consistent with its efficient working, and to make it consist of practically whole timers.
('65', 382, 4, 14, 686783) Will you please wire your reply to this letter?
('65', 382, 5, 15, 686831) SHRI B. SHIVA RAO

('65', 384, 10, 19, 689817) 472. IN THE THROES OF BIRTH
('65', 384, 11, 20, 689845) The All India Village Industries Association takes a long time to be born.
('65', 384, 11, 21, 689920) All the consolation I can give the public is that all the available time at the disposal of J. C. Kumarappa and myself is being devoted to the task.
('65', 384, 11, 22, 690069) Three questions confront us: location of the Central Office, composition of the Central Board and agencies.
('65', 384, 12, 23, 690177) 1 The Joint Parliamentary Committee Report was released to the Press on November 22, 1934.
('65', 385, 0, 1, 690268) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 385, 1, 2, 690310) Though all these questions worry us, that of the composition of the Board causes the greatest trouble.
('65', 385, 1, 3, 690413) The task is tremendous.
('65', 385, 1, 4, 690437) The goal is great.
('65', 385, 1, 5, 690456) Rejuvenation of villages in the face of the current fashion of highly developed mechanization and centralization is no easy job.
('65', 385, 1, 6, 690585) We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the Board must be composed of only a few earnest persons who have a living faith in the programme of the Association, who have an aptitude for the task and who will give the Board much, if not the whole, of their time.
('65', 385, 1, 7, 690852) We are trying to find persons, irrespective of parties, who will shoulder the burden.
('65', 385, 1, 8, 690938) So far as branches are concerned, we have tentatively come to the conclusion that the districts should be the units directly responsible for the Central Board.
('65', 385, 1, 9, 691098) Since the British official districts are not all equal in area or population, we will not hesitate to subdivide them where necessary.
('65', 385, 1, 10, 691232) The predominant consideration will be decentralization and creation of a living touch with the villagers.
('65', 385, 1, 11, 691338) There will be direct connection with the States wherever they will permit it.
('65', 385, 1, 12, 691416) We want to serve all the villages of geographical India.
('65', 385, 1, 13, 691473) There is difficulty, too, regarding choice of the Central office.
('65', 385, 1, 14, 691539) We would gladly establish it in a village, if that is possible.
('65', 385, 1, 15, 691603) But our choice is limited by two considerations.
('65', 385, 1, 16, 691652) We do not want to invest the meagre funds, that have been promised or have already come, in land and brick and mortar.
('65', 385, 1, 17, 691771) We have, therefore; to confine our selection to such places where we can get the required accommodation for the asking.
('65', 385, 1, 18, 691891) The second limitation is that the Central office should be near the main line of the railways and should be easily accessible from all the parts of India.
('65', 385, 1, 19, 692046) But let me not anticipate events.
('65', 385, 1, 20, 692080) I have shared enough with the public to enable those who will to guide us with advice.
('65', 385, 1, 21, 692167) We invite the prayers of all who are in sympathy with our difficult mission.
('65', 385, 2, 22, 692244) Harijan, 23 11 l934
('65', 385, 3, 23, 692264) 473. VILLAGE INDUSTRIES IN GUNTUR
('65', 385, 4, 24, 692298) Sitarama Sastry of Vinaya Ashram, Repalle, Guntur District, Andhradesha, in offering the services unreservedly of the whole of his Ashram to the All India Village Industries Association, says:
('65', 385, 5, 25, 692491) The following items of work suggest themselves to me and I commend them to you.
('65', 385, 5, 26, 692571) (I) Shoe making, (2) hand ginning of seed cotton, (3)
('65', 386, 0, 1, 692625) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 387
('65', 386, 1, 2, 692676) preparation of jaggery from the juice of palmyra tree, (4) improved pottery, (5) hand made paper, (6) stone dressing, (7) hand made groundnut kernels, (8) extracting oil and other products from the outer rinds of oranges, (9).
('65', 386, 1, 3, 692903) preservation of palmyra fruits.
('65', 386, 1, 4, 692935) The second item will also help in the khadi industry; the third will help in the solution of the drink problem.
('65', 386, 1, 5, 693047) Palmyras are grown in large numbers in this district, and the ripe fruit of these trees has been analysed and found to contain valuable elements of food.
('65', 386, 1, 6, 693201) oranges are also grown on a large scale in this district and are cheap.
('65', 386, 1, 7, 693273) The outer rind is thrown away as useless,.
('65', 386, 1, 8, 693316) but it is really useful from the commercial point of view.
('65', 386, 1, 9, 693375) It contains an inflammable oil and is also sold in the market as orange peel.
('65', 386, 1, 10, 693453) Kondaveedu is a village in this district which has long been famous for hand paper.
('65', 386, 1, 11, 693537) The District Congress Committee tried to revive this industry in 1921 , but the attempt was given up, owing to the indifference of the workmen.
('65', 386, 1, 12, 693681) A special stone is available in Palnad which is locally dressed and is used for paper weights, for flooring and walls and table slabs.
('65', 386, 1, 13, 693816) It is ordinarily called Palnad marble.
('65', 386, 1, 14, 693855) Hand made groundnut kernels are sold in the South and are cheaper than machine made kernels.
('65', 386, 1, 15, 693948) Groundnut crop is raised in several parts of the district.
('65', 386, 1, 16, 694007) Mr. T. Ramaswamy Gupta of Bezwada, a vakil who gave up his profession for spiritual sadhana, is responsible for improved pottery, and the earthenware prepared under his directions are far superior to the articles made by the country potter!
('65', 386, 1, 17, 694248) This is not the only or the first offer.
('65', 386, 1, 18, 694289) It is a matter of great joy to me that many such offers have been received from almost all the parts of India.
('65', 386, 1, 19, 694400) This happens to be the latest and contains the information which other workers would value.
('65', 386, 1, 20, 694492) I would recommend all the workers who are offering services to commence work without waiting for directions.
('65', 386, 1, 21, 694601) The idea behind the village industries scheme is that we should look to the villages for the supply of our daily needs and that, when we find that some needs are not so supplied, we should see whether with a little trouble and organization they cannot be profitably supplied by the villagers.
('65', 386, 1, 22, 694894) In estimating the profit, we should think of the villager, not of ourselves.
('65', 386, 1, 23, 694971) It may be that in the initial stages, we might have to pay a little more than the ordinary price and get an inferior article in the bargain.
('65', 386, 1, 24, 695112) Things will improve, if we will interest ourselves in the supplier of our needs and insist on his doing better and take the trouble of helping to do better.
('65', 386, 2, 25, 695269) Harijan, 23 11 1934
('65', 387, 0, 1, 695289) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 387, 1, 2, 695331) 474. LETTER TO M. VISVESVARAYYA 1
('65', 387, 2, 3, 695365) November 23, 1934
('65', 387, 3, 4, 695383) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your prompt reply.
('65', 387, 3, 5, 695431) I see that we hold perhaps diametrically opposite views.
('65', 387, 3, 6, 695488) My conviction based upon extensive experience of village life is that in India at any rate for generations to come, we shall not be able to make much use of mechanical power for salving the problem of ever growing poverty of the masses.
('65', 387, 3, 7, 695725) We are too many and we have so many idle hours at our disposal that it would be suicidal to make use of mechanical power and allow human power to run to waste.
('65', 387, 3, 8, 695885) The question of leisure after toil comes into being when people learn the art of making effective use of their waste hours.
('65', 387, 3, 9, 696009) Such being my view the extract that you have sent me from Stalin has no appeal for me at all.
('65', 387, 3, 10, 696103) The more expressive extract from Lenin makes matters worse for me.
('65', 387, 3, 11, 696170) It is like much cry and little wool.
('65', 387, 3, 12, 696207) I could be no party to engaging the villagers in producing army machinery and army stores.
('65', 387, 3, 13, 696298) If India has no desire to take part in the gory exploitation of unmechanized regions of the earth, she has no need to fear aggression from foreign countries.
('65', 387, 3, 14, 696456) My dream may remain wholly unrealized and India may become a willing or unwilling partner in the sin of exploitation.
('65', 387, 3, 15, 696574) Nevertheless I would use the whole of the power that God may vouchsafe to me in stemming the onrush of the violent current.
('65', 387, 3, 16, 696698) I should take delight in perishing in the attempt.
('65', 387, 3, 17, 696749) In spite of the strength of my conviction, I entertain great regard for your fine abilities and love of the country, and that shall be unabated whether I have the good fortune to secure your co operation or face your honest opposition.
('65', 387, 4, 18, 696985) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SIR M. VISVESVARAYYA, K. C. I. E.

('65', 388, 1, 2, 697284) 475. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('65', 388, 2, 3, 697310) November 23, 1934
('65', 388, 3, 4, 697328) DEAR SISTER, I have your letter.
('65', 388, 3, 5, 697361) I have gone through your draft proposal for the training of social service workers.
('65', 388, 3, 6, 697445) I am inclined to think that the District Boards cannot open the centres you contemplate without the permission of the Government.
('65', 388, 3, 7, 697575) But that is a legal point on which I cannot write with any confidence.
('65', 388, 3, 8, 697646) I have, however, a deeper objection to your scheme.
('65', 388, 3, 9, 697698) District Boards as they are constituted in India have no interest in things of permanent value such as you have proposed.
('65', 388, 3, 10, 697820) Their very constitution perhaps disables them for taking such interest.
('65', 388, 3, 11, 697892) What you contemplate is pioneer work.
('65', 388, 3, 12, 697930) It is essentially meant for reformers.
('65', 388, 3, 13, 697969) Therefore it has got to be taken up by private agencies, and when they make of such training centres a success?
('65', 388, 3, 14, 698081) the thing becomes easy for District Boards and the like to take up.
('65', 388, 3, 15, 698149) If I have understood your object correctly, you want to rejuvenate the villages.
('65', 388, 3, 16, 698230) The trend is in the opposite direction.
('65', 388, 3, 17, 698270) Hence neither District Boards nor the Government as such will handle the thing in the manner you and I would have them do.
('65', 388, 3, 18, 698393) I wish we could meet early.
('65', 388, 4, 19, 698421) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('65', 388, 9, 25, 698582) I thank you for your letter.
('65', 388, 9, 26, 698611) The Village Industries Association will not be concerned exclusively with the industries of the depressed classes, but will be concerned with the industries of the villages as a whole.
('65', 388, 9, 27, 698796) Naturally [the] depressed classes will figure prominently in its scheme; but that will figure among the villagers who have been exploited by the city people.
('65', 388, 9, 28, 698954) The scheme is still in process of formation.
('65', 388, 9, 29, 698999) If you have any advice to give, I shall appreciate it.

('65', 388, 9, 31, 699121) People belonging to different political schools will be welcome as helpers or
('65', 389, 0, 1, 699199) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('65', 394, 9, 14, 705789) You have misunderstood my retirement from the Congress.
('65', 394, 9, 15, 705845) I have not left it in disgust.
('65', 394, 9, 16, 705876) Congressmen as individuals are both good and bad.
('65', 394, 9, 17, 705926) But Congress is uniformly good.

('65', 394, 9, 19, 705997) Is God therefore less good?

('65', 394, 9, 21, 706069) I had become a dead weight.

('65', 395, 4, 5, 706611) I have a letter from you after a long time.

('65', 395, 4, 13, 707199) She has suffered much.

('65', 395, 4, 17, 707400) Do you have any proposal in view for Manu 3?

('65', 398, 8, 28, 712222) 495. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('65', 398, 9, 29, 712252) November 26, 1934 During the Harijan tour I discovered that the salt concession, which was part of the Irwin Gandhi Pact, was not being availed of by the: people.
('65', 398, 9, 30, 712415) I observed also how much poor people suffered because of want of salt, although it was lying in front of them in areas adjoining the sea.
('65', 398, 9, 31, 712553) In Mangalore, the fishermen brought the thing prominently to my notice.
('65', 398, 9, 32, 712625) I thereupon entered into correspondence with Government as early as last March.
('65', 398, 9, 33, 712705) The then Finance Member, Sir George Schuster, promptly replied to my query, and I discovered
('65', 398, 10, 34, 712798) 1 The letter is incomplete.
('65', 398, 10, 35, 712826) 2 This appeared under the title “Free Salt for the Salt of the Earth”.
('65', 399, 0, 1, 712897) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 399, 1, 2, 712939) to my joy that the clause had not suffered wreck.
('65', 399, 1, 3, 712989) I ought to have published the correspondence between Sir George Schuster and myself much earlier than I am now doing.
('65', 399, 1, 4, 713107) I need not go into the causes for this delay.
('65', 399, 1, 5, 713153) I now publish the correspondence, together with the clause and the communique 1 based upon it and setting forth the conditions of operating the clause.
('65', 399, 1, 6, 713305) When the Pact was published, in commenting upon it, I had described this as the humanitarian part of the document.
('65', 399, 1, 7, 713420) It was the humanitarian appeal that had found ready response from Lord Irwin.
('65', 399, 1, 8, 713498) Those who now avail themselves of the concession will bear this fact in mind and will, therefore, refrain from making any commercial use of the concession, either directly or indirectly, and work it strictly within the four corners of the communique.
('65', 399, 1, 9, 713749) All those Congressmen and others who are interested in villagers concerned making full use of the concession will bear in mind the list of areas from which concession for free manufacture and collection of salt has been withdrawn.
('65', 399, 1, 10, 713980) The workers will also bear in mind that it is open to all concerned to make application to the local officers for the restoration of the concession.
('65', 399, 1, 11, 714129) In no case should the concession be worked without sanction being previously obtained.
('65', 399, 2, 12, 714216) Harijan, 30 11 1934

('65', 401, 4, 14, 717156) Your 26 page letter has made me utter this prayer.
('65', 401, 4, 15, 717207) I was under the impression that after our meeting in England, your pride would have gone down; but my calculation has gone wrong.

('65', 406, 4, 9, 724593) He owned and conducted a sun treatment hospital in Delhi.

('65', 406, 4, 14, 724883) He wants at my instance to put his knowledge on a more solid foundation and therefore wants to know things about the [human] body which should be common to all whether they are allopaths or naturopaths or any other.

('65', 407, 0, 1, 725951) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 407, 1, 2, 725993) 506. SPEECH AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH 1
('65', 407, 2, 3, 726028) [On or before November 30, 1934] 2
('65', 407, 3, 4, 726063) Some of you here perhaps know how the Village Industries Association came into being.
('65', 407, 3, 5, 726149) During my extensive Harijan tour last year it was clearly borne in upon me that the way in which we were carrying on our khadi work was hardly enough either to universalize khadi or to rejuvenate the villages.
('65', 407, 3, 6, 726359) I saw that it was confined to a very few and that even those who used khadi exclusively were under the impression that they need do nothing else and that they might use other things irrespective of how and where they were made.
('65', 407, 3, 7, 726587) Khadi was thus becoming a lifeless symbol, and I saw that, if the state of things was allowed to go on, khadi might even die of sheer inanition.
('65', 407, 3, 8, 726732) It is not that a concentrated, intensive effort devoted exclusively to khadi would not be conducive to success, but there was neither that concentration nor intensity.
('65', 407, 3, 9, 726900) All did not give all their spare time to the charkha or the takli, and all had not taken to the exclusive use of khadi—though their number was larger than that of the spinners.
('65', 407, 3, 10, 727077) But the rest were all idle.
('65', 407, 3, 11, 727105) There were multitudes of men with quantities of enforced leisure on their hands.
('65', 407, 3, 12, 727186) That I saw was a state which could lead only to our undoing.
('65', 407, 3, 13, 727247) ‘These people” I said to myself, ‘could never win swaraj.
('65', 407, 3, 14, 727305) For, their involuntary and voluntary idleness made them a perpetual prey of exploiters, foreign and indigenous.
('65', 407, 3, 15, 727417) Whether the exploiter was from outside or from the Indian cities, their state would be the same, they would have no swaraj., So I said to myself, ‘Let these people be asked to do something else; if they will not interest themselves in khadi, let them take up some work which used to be done by their ancestors but which has of late died out.
('65', 407, 3, 16, 727759) There were numerous things of daily use which they used to produce themselves not many years ago, but for which they now depend on the outer world.
('65', 407, 3, 17, 727907) There were numerous things of daily use to the town dweller for which he depended on the villagers but which he now imports from cities.
('65', 407, 3, 18, 728044) The moment the villagers decided to devote all their spare
('65', 407, 4, 19, 728103) 1 Published in Harijan under the title “A. I. V. I. A. —Its Meaning and Scope”.
('65', 407, 4, 20, 728183) This is a “brief resume” of Gandhiji’s “third talk”.
('65', 407, 4, 21, 728236) Reports of the first two speeches are not available.
('65', 407, 4, 22, 728289) 2 According to a report in The Bombay Chronicle 6 12 1934, the annual session of Gandhi Seva Sangh was held in the last week of November 1934.
('65', 408, 0, 1, 728432) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 409
('65', 408, 1, 2, 728483) time to doing something useful and the town dwellers to use those village products, the snapped link between the villagers and the towndwellers would be restored.
('65', 408, 1, 3, 728646) As to which of the extinct or moribund village industries and crafts could be revived, we could not be sure until we sat down in the midst of the villages to investigate, to tabulate and classify.
('65', 408, 1, 4, 728843) But I picked up two things of the most vital importance: articles of diet and articles of dress.
('65', 408, 1, 5, 728940) Khadi was there.
('65', 408, 1, 6, 728957) In the matter of articles of diet, we were fast losing our self sufficiency.
('65', 408, 1, 7, 729034) only a few years ago, we pounded our own paddy and ground our own flour.
('65', 408, 1, 8, 729107) Put aside for the time being the question of health.
('65', 408, 1, 9, 729160) It is an indisputable fact that the flour mill and the rice mill have driven millions of women out of employment and deprived them of the means of eking out their income.
('65', 408, 1, 10, 729331) Sugar is fast taking the place of jaggery, and ready made articles of diet like biscuits and sweetmeats are freely being imported into our villages.
('65', 408, 1, 11, 729480) This means that all the village industries are gradually slipping out of the hands of the villager, who has become producer of raw materials for the exploiter.
('65', 408, 1, 12, 729640) He continually gives, and gets little in return.
('65', 408, 1, 13, 729689) Even the little he gets for the raw material he produces he gives back to the sugar merchant and the cloth merchant.
('65', 408, 1, 14, 729806) His mind and body have become very much like those of the animals, his constant companions.
('65', 408, 1, 15, 729898) When we come to think of it, we find that the villager of today is not even half so intelligent or resourceful as the villager of fifty years ago.
('65', 408, 1, 16, 730045) For, whereas the former is reduced to a state of miserable dependence and idleness, the latter used his mind and body for all he needed and produced them at home.
('65', 408, 1, 17, 730208) Even the village artisan today partakes of the resourcelessness that has overtaken the rest of the village.
('65', 408, 1, 18, 730316) Go to the village carpenter and ask him to make a spinning wheel for you go to the village smith and ask him to make a spindle for you, you will be disappointed.
('65', 408, 1, 19, 730478) This is a deplorable state of things.
('65', 408, 1, 20, 730516) It is as a remedy for it that the Village Industries Association has been conceived.
('65', 408, 1, 21, 730601) This cry of ‘back to the village” some critics say, is putting back the hands of the clock of progress.
('65', 408, 1, 22, 730705) But is it really so?
('65', 408, 1, 23, 730726) Is it going back to the village, or rendering back to it what belongs to it?
('65', 408, 1, 24, 730803) I am not asking the city dwellers to go to and live in the villages.
('65', 408, 1, 25, 730872) But I am asking them to render unto the villagers what is due to them.
('65', 408, 1, 26, 730943) Is there any single raw material that the city dwellers can obtain except from the villager?
('65', 408, 1, 27, 731036) If they cannot, why not teach him to work on it himself, as he used to before and as he would do now but for our exploiting inroads?
('65', 409, 0, 1, 731169) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 409, 1, 2, 731211) But this reinstating the villager in what was once his natural position is no easy task.
('65', 409, 1, 3, 731300) I had thought that I should be able to frame a constitution and set the Association going with the help of Sjt.
('65', 409, 1, 4, 731412) Kumarappa within a short time.
('65', 409, 1, 5, 731443) But the more I dive into it, the more I find myself out of my depth.
('65', 409, 1, 6, 731512) In a sense, the work is much more difficult than khadi, which does not in any way offer a complicated problem.
('65', 409, 1, 7, 731623) You have simply to exclude all foreign and machine made cloth, and you have established khadi on a secure foundation.
('65', 409, 1, 8, 731741) But here the field is so vast, there is such an infinite variety of industries to handle and organize, that it will tax all our business talent, expert knowledge and scientific training.
('65', 409, 1, 9, 731928) It cannot be achieved without hard toil, incessant endeavour and application of all our business and scientific abilities to this supreme purpose.
('65', 409, 1, 10, 732075) Thus, I sent a questionnaire 1 to several of our well known doctors and chemists, asking them to enlighten me on the chemical analysis and different food values of polished and unpolished rice, jaggery and sugar, and so on.
('65', 409, 1, 11, 732299) Many friends, I am thankful to say, have immediately responded, but only to confess that there has been no research in some of the directions I had inquired about.
('65', 409, 1, 12, 732463) Is it not a tragedy that no scientist should be able to give me the chemical analysis of such a simple article as gur?
('65', 409, 1, 13, 732582) The reason is that we have not thought of the villager.
('65', 409, 1, 14, 732638) Take the case of honey.
('65', 409, 1, 15, 732662) I am told that in foreign countries such a careful analysis of honey is made that no sample which fails to satisfy a particular test is bottled for the market.
('65', 409, 1, 16, 732822) In India we have got vast resources for the production of the finest honey, but we have not much expert knowledge in the matter.
('65', 409, 1, 17, 732951) An esteemed doctor friend writes to say that in his hospital, at any rate, polished rice is taboo and that it has been proved after experiments on rats and other animals that polished rice is harmful.
('65', 409, 1, 18, 733152) But why have not all the medical men published the results of their investigation and experiment and joined in declaring the use of such rice as positively harmful?
('65', 409, 1, 19, 733317) I have just by one or two instances indicated my difficulty.
('65', 409, 1, 20, 733378) What sort of an organization should I have?
('65', 409, 1, 21, 733422) What kinds of laboratory research shall we have to go in for?
('65', 409, 1, 22, 733484) We shall need a number of scientists and chemists prepared to lay not only their expert knowledge at our disposal, but to sit down in our laboratories and to devote hours of time, free of charge, to experiments in the direction I have indicated.
('65', 409, 1, 23, 733730) We shall have not only to publish the results from time
('65', 409, 2, 24, 733786) 1 Vide “Letter to Dr. B. C. Roy”, 8 11 1934.
('65', 410, 0, 1, 733831) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 411
('65', 410, 1, 2, 733882) to time, but we shall have to inspect and certify various products.
('65', 410, 1, 3, 733950) Also we shall have to find out whether the villager who produces an article or foodstuff rests content with exporting it and with using a cheap substitute imported from outside.
('65', 410, 1, 4, 734128) We shall have to see that the villagers become first of all self contained and then cater for the needs of the city dwellers.
('65', 410, 1, 5, 734254) For this purpose we shall have to form district organizations, and, where districts are too big to handle, we may have to divide the districts into sub districts.
('65', 410, 1, 6, 734417) Each of these—some 250—should have an agent who will carry out a survey and submit a report in the terms of the instructions issued to him from the head office.
('65', 410, 1, 7, 734578) These agents shall have to be full timers and whole hoggers, with a live faith in the programme and prepared immediately to make the necessary adjustment in their daily life.
('65', 410, 1, 8, 734753) This work will certainly need money, but, more than money, it will need men of strong faith and willing hands.
('65', 410, 2, 9, 734864) Q. Will not this programme swamp the khadi programme which has yet to be fulfilled?
('65', 410, 3, 10, 734948) Khadi cannot be moved from its central place.
('65', 410, 3, 11, 734994) Khadi will be the sun of the whole industrial solar system.
('65', 410, 3, 12, 735054) All the other industries will receive warmth and sustenance from the khadi industry.
('65', 410, 4, 13, 735139) Q. What exactly are the industries we must revive or promote?
('65', 410, 5, 14, 735201) A. I have indicated the lines.
('65', 410, 5, 15, 735232) We must promote every useful industry that was existent a short while ago and the extinction of which has now resulted in unemployment.
('65', 410, 6, 16, 735368) Q. Have we to declare a boycott of the rice and the flour mills?
('65', 410, 7, 17, 735433) A. We have to declare no boycott, but we shall ask the people to husk their own rice and to grind their own flour, and we shall carry on persistent propaganda in favour of hand pounded rice and hand ground flour as better articles of diet from the point of view of health.
('65', 410, 7, 18, 735706) Let us declare a boycott of idleness.
('65', 410, 8, 19, 735744) Q. Shall we use the Congress Committees for this purpose?
('65', 410, 9, 20, 735802) A. of course.
('65', 410, 9, 21, 735816) We shall use and take help from any source.
('65', 410, 9, 22, 735860) We have no politics as such and no party.
('65', 410, 10, 23, 735902) Q. The formation of the Central Board means centralization?
('65', 410, 11, 24, 735962) A. Not quite.
('65', 410, 11, 25, 735976) The districts will be the working centres.
('65', 410, 11, 26, 736019) The Central office will be only a watch tower for the whole of India issuing
('65', 411, 0, 1, 736096) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 411, 1, 2, 736138) instructions, but not a board of administration.
('65', 411, 1, 3, 736187) It will be a sort of correspondence school through which the various agents will carry on mutual exchange of thought and compare notes.
('65', 411, 1, 4, 736323) We want to avoid centralization of administration, we want centralization of thought, ideas and scientific knowledge.
('65', 411, 2, 5, 736441) Harijan, 7 12 1934
('65', 411, 3, 6, 736460) 507. ‘WHY NOT LABOUR SAVING DEVICES’
('65', 411, 4, 7, 736497) A fair friend who was enthused over the contemplated formation of the All India Village Industries Association, on reading my Press message 1 on the preliminary programme, writes: The very idea of the revival or encouragement of the hand husking of rice and chakki grinding even for villages has scared me from, and abated my enthusiasm for village work.
('65', 411, 4, 8, 736852) It seems lo me an enormous waste of one’s time and energy not to take advantage of labour saving devices in the uplift scheme.
('65', 411, 4, 9, 736979) If the villagers, and along with them the uplift workers, have to husk and grind, there will hardly be leisure left for them to attend to anything else for their improvement.
('65', 411, 4, 10, 737154) Besides, if the primitive methods were revived, the men will take up the work in the first flush of enthusiasm; but ultimately the brunt of the whole work, I mean husking and grinding, will fall on us, women, and there will be a setback to the little progress we have already made.
('65', 411, 4, 11, 737436) Underlying this argument is a fallacy.
('65', 411, 4, 12, 737475) There is no question of refusing to take advantage of labour saving devices.
('65', 411, 4, 13, 737552) If the vilIagers had enough to eat and to clothe themselves with, there would be no cause for home grinding or home husking, assuming that the question of health was not of any importance or, if it was, there was no difference between home ground flour and millground, or home husked rice and mill husked.
('65', 411, 4, 14, 737858) But the problem is that the villagers became idle when they left off husking and grinding even for their own use, and made no good use of their idle hours whether for uplift or otherwise.
('65', 411, 4, 15, 738046) A starving man or woman who has time on his or her hand will surely be glad to earn an honest anna during that time, for, he or she will resent being advised to save his or her labour when either can turn it into a few pice to alleviate starvation.
('65', 411, 5, 16, 738295) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, pp.
('65', 412, 0, 1, 738332) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 413
('65', 412, 1, 2, 738383) correspondent is wrong in thinking that the uplift worker has either to grind or husk.
('65', 412, 1, 3, 738470) He has certainly to learn the art and know the tools, so that he can suggest improvements and understand the limitations of the tools.
('65', 412, 1, 4, 738605) She is wrong, again, in thinking that in the first flush of enthusiasm men will be called upon to grind or husk or will perform these tasks of their own accord and ultimately let the brunt fall on the shoulders of women.
('65', 412, 1, 5, 738826) The fact is that husking and grinding was the prerogative of women, and tens of thousands made a living out of this task, which was both dignified and invigorative.
('65', 412, 1, 6, 738991) Now they are perforce idle, because the vast majority of them have not been able to find another employment in the place of these two, which we have snatched away from them.
('65', 412, 1, 7, 739165) When the fair friend writes about the “little progress” that the women have already made, she has undoubtedly the icitydwellers in mind, for the village life is entirely untouched by uplift workers.
('65', 412, 1, 8, 739364) The majority of them do not even know how the women or men live in the 7,00,000 villages of this vast land.
('65', 412, 1, 9, 739472) We little know how they have deteriorated for want of nourishing food and protective clothing.
('65', 412, 1, 10, 739567) And we little know how, being fed on innutritious rice or flour,which are their staple, they and their children lose stamina and what little vitality they have.
('65', 412, 1, 11, 739728) I have no partiality for return to the primitive method of grinding and husking for the sake of them.
('65', 412, 1, 12, 739830) I suggest the return, because there is no other way of giving employment to the millions of villagers who are living in idleness.
('65', 412, 1, 13, 739960) In my opinion, village uplift is impossible, unless we solve the pressing economic distress.
('65', 412, 1, 14, 740053) Therefore, to induce the villagers to utilize their idle hours is in itself solid uplift work.
('65', 412, 1, 15, 740148) I invite the fair correspondent and those who feel like her to go to some villages, live there for some time in the midst of the villagers and try to live like them, and they will soon perceive the soundness of my argument.

('65', 413, 0, 1, 740392) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 413, 1, 2, 740434) 508. WHAT IS IT?
('65', 413, 2, 3, 740451) An esteemed friend wrote the orher day saying, among other things, that he had not before his mind’s eye a full picture of what I meant by village industries work.
('65', 413, 2, 4, 740615) It was a good question.
('65', 413, 2, 5, 740639) It must have occurred to many people.
('65', 413, 2, 6, 740677) This is the purport of what I wrote to him: In a nutshell, of the things we use, we should restrict our purchases to the articles which villages manufacture.
('65', 413, 2, 7, 740835) Their manufactures may be crude.
('65', 413, 2, 8, 740868) We must try to induce them to improve their workmanship, and not dismiss them because foreign articles or even articles produced in cities, that is, big factories, are superior.
('65', 413, 2, 9, 741046) In other words, we should evoke the artistic talent of ~the villager.
('65', 413, 2, 10, 741116) In this manner shall we repay somewhat the debt we owe to them.
('65', 413, 2, 11, 741180) We need not be frightened by the thought whether we shall ever succeed in such an effort.
('65', 413, 2, 12, 741270) Within our own times we can recall instances where we have not been baffled by the difficulty of our tasks when we have known that they were essential for the nation’s progress.
('65', 413, 2, 13, 741448) If, therefore, we as individuals believe that revivification of India’s villages is a necessity of our existence, if we believe that thereby only can we root out untouchability and feel one with all, no matter to what community or religion they may belong, we must mentally go back to the villages and treat them as our pattern, instead of putting the city life before them for imitation.
('65', 413, 2, 14, 741837) If this is the correct attitude, then, naturally, we begin with ourselves and thus use, say, handmade paper instead of mill made, use village reed, wherever possible, instead of the fountain pen or the penholder, ink made in the villages instead of the big factories, etc.
('65', 413, 2, 15, 742110) I can multiply instances of this nature.
('65', 413, 2, 16, 742151) There is hardly anything of daily use in the home which the villagers have not made before and cannot make even now.
('65', 413, 2, 17, 742268) If we perform the mental trick and fix our gaze upon them, we immediately put millions of rupees into the pockets of the villagers, whereas at the present moment we are exploiting the villagers without making any return worth the name.
('65', 413, 2, 18, 742504) It is time we arrested the progress of the tragedy.
('65', 413, 2, 19, 742556) To me, the campaign against untouchability has begun to imply ever so much more than the eradication of the ceremonial untouchability of those who are labelled untouchables.
('65', 413, 2, 20, 742730) For the city dweller, the villages have become untouchable.
('65', 413, 2, 21, 742790) He does not know them, he will not live in them.
('65', 414, 0, 1, 742839) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 415
('65', 414, 1, 2, 742890) he finds himself in a village, he will want to reproduce the city life there.
('65', 414, 1, 3, 742968) This would be tolerable, if we could bring into being cities which would accommodate 30 crores of human beings.
('65', 414, 1, 4, 743080) This is much more impossible than the one of reviving the village industries and stopping the progressive poverty, which is due as much to enforced unemployment as to any other cause.

('65', 430, 7, 10, 768236) 532. DISCUSSION WITH ABDUL GHAFFAR KHAN 1
('65', 430, 8, 11, 768278) December 7, 1934
('65', 430, 9, 12, 768295) [GANDHIJI:] Khan Saheb, this is not an occasion when we may not offer defence.
('65', 430, 9, 13, 768374) We must engage our own lawyer and offer defence.
('65', 430, 10, 14, 768423) The Khan Saheb said, “That may be, but I am averse to defending myself in a law court.
('65', 430, 10, 15, 768510) Ever since 1919 you have taught us not to recognize the law courts and I should hate this time to do otherwise.” I quite see, but we do not want to go to jail now if we can help it and hence I would urge you to engage a lawyer.
('65', 430, 10, 16, 768738) “Just as you please”, said the Khan Saheb, and got ready to accompany the officials.
('65', 430, 11, 17, 768823) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 12 1934
('65', 430, 12, 18, 768855) 1 This brief discussion took place just as Abdul Ghaffar Khan was leaving after his arrest.
('65', 430, 12, 19, 768947) The Bombay Chronicle reports.
('65', 430, 12, 20, 768977) today at about 5.15 p.m.
('65', 430, 12, 21, 769002) when the D. S. P. of Wardha accompanied by a police officer from Bombay visited the Satyagraha Ashram asking for Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, he was sitting upstairs with Mahatma Gandhi and the arrival of visitors was announced by Mirabehn.
('65', 430, 12, 22, 769239) Gandhiji asked her to bring them upstairs.
('65', 430, 12, 23, 769282) “The D. S. P. came up and told Gandhiji that he had a warrant of arrest for Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan from the Presidency Magistrate of Bombay.
('65', 430, 12, 24, 769424) Gandhiji asked for the warrant and read it out to Khan Saheb.
('65', 430, 12, 25, 769486) It was on a charge under Section 124 A, there being no mention of any speech or writing in question.
('65', 430, 12, 26, 769587) on the D. S. P. asking Khan saheb as to when he would be ready he said he was quite ready.
('65', 430, 12, 27, 769678) But Gandhiji said that if the D. S. P. did not mind Khan Saheb would see his brother and children at Seth Jamnalal’s place.

('65', 434, 8, 13, 774508) I have taken the deepest interest in your invention.
('65', 434, 8, 14, 774561) I have great regard for Mr. Kale both as a mechanic and a man.
('65', 434, 8, 15, 774624) I felt drawn to him when he was at the Ashram.
('65', 434, 8, 16, 774671) Being a fairly busy man, I had not much time to give to the examination of the machine, but I have kept myself in touch with the progress of the examination by the Judges 2. When you offered to send it to me I told you of my own difficulty.
('65', 434, 8, 17, 774912) But I was pressed by a friend to give the machine a trial myself.
('65', 434, 8, 18, 774978) I, therefore, wrote to you again 3 asking you to send the machine with Mr. Kale and another who might know all about tools in general.
('65', 434, 8, 19, 775113) I had intended to keep the machine here for some time so that the Director of the Ashram Shri Vinoba might also try it.
('65', 434, 8, 20, 775233) The prize of Rs. 1,00,000 is at the disposal of him who would earn it.
('65', 434, 8, 21, 775304) I am personally anxious to give it, if the machine of my dream can be had.
('65', 434, 8, 22, 775379) The highest speed attained on the ordinary wheel is over 700 yards per hour.
('65', 434, 8, 23, 775456) Besides yours, there are two machines of promise.
('65', 434, 8, 24, 775506) They are also undergoing improvements.

('65', 436, 1, 2, 777278) 541. LETTER TO M. VISVESVARAYYA 1
('65', 436, 2, 3, 777312) December 10, 1934
('65', 436, 3, 4, 777330) DEAR FRIEND,
('65', 436, 4, 5, 777343) I thank you for your letter.
('65', 436, 4, 6, 777372) Fortunately I have your book also sent to me for which too, kindly accept my thanks.
('65', 436, 4, 7, 777457) Your letter gave me great joy in that there was in it promise of your support to my humble effort on behalf of the villagers.
('65', 436, 4, 8, 777583) I have no difficulty whatsoever in endorsing your remarks about heavy industries.
('65', 436, 4, 9, 777665) I know that the heavy industries cannot be organized without power driven machinery.
('65', 436, 4, 10, 777750) I can have no quarrel with such use of machinery.
('65', 436, 4, 11, 777800) My objection comes in when such machinery displaces human labour without providing displaced hands with a substitute at least as good as displaced labour.
('65', 436, 5, 12, 777955) Yours sincerely M. K. GANDHI
('65', 436, 6, 13, 777984) From a photostat: C.W. 9727. Courtesy: Government of Mysore
('65', 436, 7, 14, 778044) 542. LETTER TO CARL HEATH
('65', 436, 8, 15, 778070) December 10, 1934
('65', 436, 9, 16, 778088) DEAR FRIEND,
('65', 436, 10, 17, 778101) I have your letter of 19th November.
('65', 436, 10, 18, 778138) I have not been able to understand it, in spite of the help I sought from Charlie Andrews.
('65', 436, 10, 19, 778229) I have no hesitation in agreeing with you that any solution of the present deadlock should be just and creative, and that it should be neither imposed nor extorted; in other words, it should be an agreed solution honourable to both the countries.
('65', 436, 10, 20, 778476) I know too the suffering of India and the suffering of Lancashire.
('65', 436, 10, 21, 778543) But if the juxtaposition of the two is meant to imply that the cause of the suffering of either is identical I would dissent from any such view.
('65', 436, 10, 22, 778688) The suffering of India is imposed upon her; the suffering of Lancashire is due partly to world causes and partly to its own shortsightedness and selfishness.
('65', 436, 10, 23, 778846) So far as it was possible for me to suggest an alleviation of the
('65', 436, 11, 24, 778912) 1 This letter was displayed at the Mysore Pavilion of the Gandhi Darshan Exhibition held in New Delhi in 1969 70.
('65', 437, 0, 1, 779026) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 437, 1, 2, 779068) suffering of Lancashire through India’s help I had made a definite offer 1 when I was in England in 1931. But my offer proved to be of no avail.
('65', 437, 1, 3, 779213) The offer was this: If there was a free settlement between England and India, a favoured nation clause was quite possible, in so far as India might need any foreign cloth in order to supplement her output of cloth, whether through the village spinning wheel or through her mills.
('65', 437, 1, 4, 779493) I do not know how far such treatment is possible today for, even during the short period that has elapsed since the meeting of the Round Table Conference, India has become better organized for the manufacture of all her clothing requirements, in spite of the fact that she is importing fine count calico both from England and Japan.
('65', 437, 1, 5, 779826) The chief point, however, is not how Lancashire can send its calico to India, but how the whole of England can benefit in every way by the benefit that India must derive from attainment of complete freedom, political and economic.
('65', 437, 1, 6, 780057) The more I study the villages of India the more intensely do I realize that India has no need to be a pauper country if she can get the chance to grow without the fetters that today prevent hernatural natural growth.
('65', 437, 1, 7, 780274) Your last paragraph seems to imply that there is no longer any repression in India.
('65', 437, 1, 8, 780358) I can only tell you that repression is there to be seen by anyone with the naked eye.
('65', 437, 1, 9, 780444) I do not know of any single repressive law that has been repealed.
('65', 437, 1, 10, 780511) The Press is effectively gagged, there is no such thing as freedom of movement in Bengal as also in the Frontier Province.
('65', 437, 1, 11, 780634) If you hear nothing of imprisonments and lathi charges it is because civil disobedience is suspended and the Congress has resolved, in furtherance of the spirit of non violence, to submit to repressive laws in so far as it is humanly possible to do so.
('65', 437, 1, 12, 780887) on the top of all this comes the Parliamentary Committee’s proposals for a new constitution.
('65', 437, 1, 13, 780980) It is, as I read it, a barefaced denial of freedom.
('65', 437, 1, 14, 781032) I see in it no scope for expansion.
('65', 437, 1, 15, 781068) I would any day prefer the existing state to the crushing burden that threatens to overwhelm India and tighten the British hold upon her.
('65', 437, 1, 16, 781206) My own power of endurance is being tested beyond my capacity.
('65', 437, 1, 17, 781268) My way to the Frontier Province is blocked.
('65', 437, 1, 18, 781312) But, in spite of the blackness of the horizon, I have no sense of despair in me.
('65', 437, 1, 19, 781393) I believe in the existence of a beneficent Power that
('65', 437, 2, 20, 781447) 1 Vide “Interview to unemployed workers’ deputation” and “Statement to the Press”, 27 9 1931.
('65', 438, 0, 1, 781541) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 439
('65', 438, 1, 2, 781592) overrides and upsets all human plans.
('65', 438, 1, 3, 781630) It ever produces order out of chaos, and redresses wrongs in spite of the tyranny of tyrants.
('65', 438, 1, 4, 781724) India must come to her own one day.
('65', 438, 1, 5, 781760) But she will do so chiefly if her own sons and daughters behave themselves and prove worthy of her freedom.
('65', 438, 1, 6, 781868) We must exert our utmost to prove our worth, and you, friends of the Conciliation Group, will, I know, do your level best according to your lights to help a just solution.
('65', 438, 2, 7, 782040) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI CARL HEATH, ESQ.
