('65', 443, 5, 8, 789386) 552. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('65', 443, 6, 9, 789414) December 11, 1934
('65', 443, 7, 10, 789432) It is unfortunate that Press correspondents have thought fit without reference to the parties thereto to publish garbled reports of the correspondence that has been going on between His Excellency the Viceroy and myself with reference to my contemplated visit to the Frontier Province.
('65', 443, 7, 11, 789718) I was pressed by several editors to contradict or confirm the reports.
('65', 443, 7, 12, 789789) The best thing I could do was to seek His Excellency’s permission to publish the correspondence in so far as it has gone.
('65', 443, 7, 13, 789911) Having just received this permission, 3 I release the correspondence to the Press.
('65', 443, 7, 14, 789994) But I would warn the public against thinking that the correspondence is closed and that I am waiting for the first opportunity to court arrest by proceeding to the Frontier in the teeth of His Excellency’s advice to the contrary.
('65', 443, 7, 15, 790224) I have no desire to offer civil disobedience at the present moment.
('65', 443, 7, 16, 790292) My object is as a humble servant of God to meet those in the Frontier who call themselves Servants of God and to know them.
('65', 443, 7, 17, 790416) The urge has become all the greater now that their brave leader is under
('65', 443, 8, 18, 790489) 1 The report has the date line “Bangalore, December 11, 1934”.
('65', 443, 8, 19, 790552) 2 M. L. C. and Secretary, Mysore State Harijan Sevak Sangh 3 Vide “Letter to Upton Sinclair”, 6 12 1934.
('65', 444, 0, 1, 790657) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 445
('65', 444, 1, 2, 790708) arrest.
('65', 444, 1, 3, 790716) But my immediate object cannot be served by defiance of authority.
('65', 444, 1, 4, 790783) Therefore, I propose to try all possible constitutional means to obtain the necessary permission.
('65', 444, 1, 5, 790881) If suspicion of my motive is the cause of refusal, I shall try to disarm the suspicion.
('65', 444, 1, 6, 790969) My endeavour is to avoid every occasion for civil disobedience of authority, in so far as it is humanly possible to do so.
('65', 444, 1, 7, 791092) I would therefore ask the public in general, and the friends of the Frontier in particular, to hold themselves in patience.
('65', 444, 1, 8, 791216) They will know in proper time what is to happen finally.
('65', 444, 1, 9, 791273) And I would urge the editors of newspapers to respect my wish that they publish nothing concerning my contemplated visit to the Frontier without authority.
('65', 444, 1, 10, 791429) Here is the correspondence 1:

('65', 449, 0, 1, 798326) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 449, 1, 2, 798368) 561. HARIJAN WORK IN ASSAM
('65', 449, 2, 3, 798395) The Secretary, Harijan Sevak Sangh, Assam, has sent me a copy of the report of the Sangh’s work during the year.
('65', 449, 2, 4, 798508) From the report I abstract the following interesting particulars:
('65', 449, 3, 5, 798574) The Sangh runs 72 schools for boys and girls with 2,365 pupils on the rolls.
('65', 449, 3, 6, 798651) of these, 21 are mixed schools and 4 for girls only.
('65', 449, 4, 7, 798704) The total amount spent on the schools during the year was Rs. 4,495 1 4 O.
('65', 449, 5, 8, 798779) The Sangh recruited 328 boys and girls for the ordinary schools.
('65', 449, 6, 9, 798844) Scholarships totalling Rs. 864 9 0 for Middle English and High English schools were given to Harijan students.
('65', 449, 7, 10, 798955) The total value of books, slates, soaps, clothes given came to Rs. 206 2 6.
('65', 449, 8, 11, 799031) 23 Namghars (prayer houses) were thrown open to Harijans.
('65', 449, 9, 12, 799089) The Jorhat Committee built a common prayer house for Rs. 1,196 9 3.
('65', 449, 10, 13, 799157) The Sangh employed 11 Harijan teachers, including two mistresses.
('65', 449, 11, 14, 799223) A co operative society was organized at Dibrugarh for Bhangis.
('65', 449, 11, 15, 799286) 81 Bhangis have taken up shares.
('65', 449, 11, 16, 799319) Rs. 920 have already been realized.
('65', 449, 12, 17, 799355) The Sangh has organized 9 District Committees.
('65', 449, 12, 18, 799402) These have organized 22 sub committees of Harijans.
('65', 449, 13, 19, 799454) Free medical relief was given, costing Rs. 16 7 O. 40 spinningwheels and ten maunds of cotton for spinning were distributed among poor Harijans.
('65', 449, 14, 20, 799599) 132 villages were toured for anti opium and anti drink propaganda.
('65', 449, 14, 21, 799666) As a result, 154 took pledges, giving up drink, and 15 hemp smoking.
('65', 449, 15, 22, 799735) Municipal Boards of the Province were requested to make better arrangements of housing, drainage and water supply for their employees, especially the sweepers.
('65', 449, 15, 23, 799895) But it is sad to note that none of them took up the work.
('65', 449, 15, 24, 799953) Gauhati and Dibrugarh were the worst offenders.
('65', 449, 16, 25, 800001) By way of contrast, it is pleasurable to note that, at the instance of the itinerant workers, some villages constructed their own roads and cleaned their own tanks.
('65', 449, 17, 26, 800166) 246 villages were surveyed during the year, and statistics of Harijan families as to their condition, professions, disabilities, drinking and opium habits, etc., were collected.
('65', 450, 0, 1, 800344) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 451
('65', 450, 1, 2, 800395) The President, His Holiness the Satradhikar Goswami of Garmur, toured through most of the important places including the ex tea garden coolie centres.
('65', 450, 1, 3, 800546) In Assam, opium is a very serious problem.
('65', 450, 1, 4, 800589) It ruins the addict physically, morally and materially.
('65', 450, 1, 5, 800645) It has been found that, in 8 districts, the average consumption among 64,459 addicts is nearly 1Ω tolas per head per month.
('65', 450, 1, 6, 800769) In Nowgong, excepting the Mikir Hills, the consumption is about 18 Srs.
('65', 450, 1, 7, 800841) per 10,000, in Lakhimpur it is 62 Srs.
('65', 450, 1, 8, 800880) per 10,000 In Mikir Hills it is even over 62 Srs.
('65', 450, 1, 9, 800930) per 10,000. Harijans are the worst sufferers in Lakhimpur, Sibsagar and Nowgong.
('65', 450, 1, 10, 801011) The main professions of indigenous Harijans are fishing, pottery and goldsmithy.
('65', 450, 1, 11, 801092) The revival movement should result in helping these artisans.
('65', 450, 1, 12, 801154) This encouraging record is marred by the knowledge that over one fourth of the expenses were incurred for administrative and propaganda purposes.
('65', 450, 1, 13, 801300) The total expenditure was Rs. 11,966. of this, Rs. 3,664 represents administration and propaganda, and Rs. 8,302 welfare.
('65', 450, 1, 14, 801422) Administrative staff absorbs Rs. 1,149 and propagandists Rs. 1,020. I have omitted annas and pies.
('65', 450, 1, 15, 801521) Now this expense for welfare work of Rs. 8,302 is much too much in my estimation.
('65', 450, 1, 16, 801603) As I have repeatedly said, constructive work is its own and the best propaganda.
('65', 450, 1, 17, 801684) Administrative staff should also be reduced to a minimum.
('65', 450, 1, 18, 801742) I know that Assam is a difficult province to work [in].
('65', 450, 1, 19, 801798) Nevertheless, the fact that Harijan Sevak Sanghs are an organization of penitents or debtors should ever be borne in mind.
('65', 450, 2, 20, 801921) Harijan, 14 12 1934
('65', 450, 3, 21, 801941) 562. NOTES
('65', 450, 4, 22, 801952) AN ASPIRING NATUROPATH
('65', 450, 5, 23, 801975) Being myself a half baked naturopath, I draw to myself similar cranks, of whom Shri Sharma of Khurja is one.
('65', 450, 5, 24, 802084) He had to his credit a Sun and Light Hospital and some well advertised books.
('65', 450, 5, 25, 802162) I had a hand in the disappearance of the Hospital.
('65', 450, 5, 26, 802213) The sequel is told as follows in his own words: 1
('65', 450, 6, 27, 802263) I would like .
('65', 450, 6, 28, 802278) to inform .
('65', 450, 6, 29, 802290) those who may be interested in nature cure methods that, having become, of late, more acquainted with the
('65', 450, 7, 30, 802396) 1 Only extracts are reptoduced here.
('65', 451, 0, 1, 802433) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 451, 1, 2, 802475) ways of Nature, that is of Truth, I have discovered that all my books on sunlight and colour cannot be held to be reliable beyond doubt.
('65', 451, 1, 3, 802612) I would, therefore, like all those who possess my books, or who might have heard of them, for the time being to dismiss them from their consideration and not to rely upon what I have written therein or upon the invention which I have advertised therein.
('65', 451, 1, 4, 802866) I hope some day .
('65', 451, 1, 5, 802884) to re write the books and place them before the public with confidence based upon verifiable experiments.
('65', 451, 1, 6, 802990) I wish the other naturopaths will take a lesson from Shri Sharma’s example.
('65', 451, 1, 7, 803066) I have written and spoken much against the modern treatment of diseases.
('65', 451, 1, 8, 803139) But I have a sneaking regard for the comparative sanity of allopaths.
('65', 451, 1, 9, 803209) They do not make pretensions.
('65', 451, 1, 10, 803239) The best among them do not refuse to learn from others, and they are humble enough to own their mistakes among themselves, though not to their patients.
('65', 451, 1, 11, 803392) They try to know all about the human body and as much as is possible of the drugs they use.
('65', 451, 1, 12, 803484) Naturopaths use few drugs.
('65', 451, 1, 13, 803511) But an accurate knowledge of the body is surely essential for all who would tamper with it under the pretence of curing it of the many ailments to which it is a prey.
('65', 451, 1, 14, 803678) Shri Sharma has a burning passion for becoming a true naturopath.
('65', 451, 1, 15, 803744) He is, therefore, determined to acquire a working knowledge of anatomy, physiology and whatever is necessary for all who will deal with diseases, whether in the name of allopathy, homoeopathy or naturopathy.
('65', 451, 1, 16, 803952) His notice is a confession and a warning.
('65', 451, 1, 17, 803994) Let all concerned take note.
('65', 451, 2, 18, 804023) Harijan, 14 12 1934

('65', 452, 1, 2, 804585) 564. MOTHER OF INVENTION
('65', 452, 2, 3, 804610) Shri J. K. Mehta, Secretary, Indian Merchants, Chamber, Bombay, writes: 1
('65', 452, 3, 4, 804684) In 1917 my services were borrowed from the Chamber by the Government of India for purposes of the War.
('65', 452, 3, 5, 804787) .I was at Simla for about a year and a half with the Munitions Board.
('65', 452, 3, 6, 804857) It was found that horseshoes could not be made available from the United Kingdom.
('65', 452, 3, 7, 804939) It proved to be a great and complicated problem, as there was no factory in India making horseshoes.
('65', 452, 3, 8, 805040) Ultimately the solution was found in getting supplies from hundreds of villages.
('65', 452, 3, 9, 805121) The village smith came to the rescue of the Government of India, .
('65', 452, 3, 10, 805188) who got horseshoes from different villages and sent them up for the Army requirements.
('65', 452, 3, 11, 805275) Truly, necessity is the mother of invention.
('65', 452, 3, 12, 805320) Why should not we be able to accomplish in our war against enforced idleness and unemployment what had become possible in the time of the great War?
('65', 452, 3, 13, 805469) Instances such as .Shri J. K. Mehta has given can be endlessly multiplied.
('65', 452, 3, 14, 805544) The whole face of the great continent of Europe was changed during those days of mutual slaughter, and men and women, boys and girls had to work with their hands, in order that they might be able to keep body and soul together.
('65', 452, 4, 15, 805772) Harijan, 14 12 1934
('65', 452, 5, 16, 805792) 565. A. I. F. I. A.—OBJECT AND CONSTITUTION 2
('65', 452, 6, 17, 805838) [WARDHA, December 14, 1934] 3
('65', 452, 7, 18, 805868) As the idea was to form a Board of Administration of the policy and programme of the All India Village Industries Association of persons who thoroughly believe in its policy and the practicability of its programme and who will, in effect, be wholetimers, both Mr. Kumarappa and I have given considerable time and thought to the formation of the Board.
('65', 452, 8, 19, 806220) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('65', 452, 8, 20, 806257) 2 The Association was formed on this date; vide Vol. LX, “The New Baby”, 21 12 1934. The constitution was released to the Press along with a statement on December 15.
('65', 452, 9, 21, 806424) 3 ibid.
('65', 453, 0, 1, 806432) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 453, 1, 2, 806474) The Congress resolution 1 in the matter contemplates the question of a self acting, independent and non political organization consisting of men and women whose primary aim in life would be identification with the villagers and promotion of their welfare.
('65', 453, 2, 3, 806730) The following friends, having understood the implications of their obligation, have consented to form the Association of which they become both the foundation members and the first Board of Management:
('65', 453, 3, 4, 806932) Shri Shrikrishnadas Jajooji, President and Treasurer [Shri] J. C. Kumarappa, organizer and Secretary Shrimati Gosibehn Captain Dr. Khan Saheb Shri Shoorji Vallabhdas Dr. Prafulla Ghosh Shri Lakshmidas Purushottam Asar Shri Shankerlal Banker They will have power to add to their number.
('65', 453, 4, 5, 807218) The function of the Board will be to define the programme of village reconstruction work from time to time, to co ordinate the policy followed in different centres, to collect, collate and circulate information gathered from workers or agents as to the actual condition of the existing village industries, both those that may be flourishing and those that may be perishing, also as to the economic, moral and physical condition of villagers, to carry on research work with the help of specialists and experts and to discover and create a market for surplus village manufactures.
('65', 453, 5, 6, 807797) The Board will collect such funds as may be required for the due discharge of its functions.
('65', 453, 5, 7, 807890) As the secret of the success of the policy of this Association will be in making the villagers selfreliant and self supporting, its programme must not be costly.
('65', 453, 5, 8, 808052) The idea is, therefore, to work with as little outlay as possible.
('65', 453, 6, 9, 808119) It follows, therefore, that decentralization must be the keynote of the Board’s policy, and India will be divided into as many areas as there may be workers or agents, who will work, organize and be
('65', 453, 7, 10, 808318) 1 Vide “Speech at subjects committee meeting, A.I.C.C.”, 24 10 1934.
('65', 454, 0, 1, 808387) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 455
('65', 454, 1, 2, 808438) responsible to the Board for the carrying out of its programme in their respective areas.
('65', 454, 1, 3, 808528) The workers or agents will be selected from those who, consistently with their preoccupation of earning their livelihood, will give their whole time to the work of the.
('65', 454, 1, 4, 808697) Association.
('65', 454, 1, 5, 808710) So tar as possible, the agents will be honorary.
('65', 454, 1, 6, 808759) They will collect what funds may be necessary for the organization of their areas.It may be that the Board will not get many unpaid agents.
('65', 454, 1, 7, 808899) It will be satisfied, for a start, even with a few districts which are thoroughly organized and demonstrated to be economically and otherwise successful.
('65', 454, 1, 8, 809053) A list of agents will be published from time to time.
('65', 454, 1, 9, 809107) The Board cannot carry on research work without the help of experts.
('65', 454, 1, 10, 809176) And since experts cannot be expected to give their whole time and thought to the work of the Association, I have sent requests to several friends if they would allow their names to appear on the Board of Advisers.
('65', 454, 1, 11, 809390) So far the following friends have kindly consented to be on it: Dr. Rabindranath Tagore Sir J. C. Bose Sir P. C. Ray Sir C. V. Raman Shri Ramdas Pantulu Jamal Mohamed Sahib Shri G. D. Birla Sir Purushottamdas Thakurdas Sir S. Pochkhanawalla Prof.

('65', 454, 2, 13, 809800) Wardha has been chosen as the Headquarters because of being
('65', 455, 0, 1, 809860) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 455, 1, 2, 809902) centrally situated, being a junction station and being rather a glorified village than a city.
('65', 455, 1, 3, 809997) Though I have several names before me of friends who have undertaken to act as agents to the Association, I would request these correspondents as well as others to offer their names to the Organizer and Secretary, Mr. J. C. Kumarappa, Wardha.
('65', 455, 1, 4, 810240) I have transferred to him all the names and papers received by me.
('65', 455, 2, 5, 810307) THE CONSTITUTION OF THE ASSOCIATION
('65', 455, 3, 6, 810343) The Association contemplated: by the resolution regarding village industries passed by the Indian National Congress at its session held on the 27th October, 1934, at Bombay, and known as the All India Village Industries Association, i.e., the Akhil Bharat Gram Udyog Sangh, is hereby formed.
('65', 455, 5, 7, 810635) The object of the Association shall be village reorganization and reconstruction, including the revival, encouragement and improvement of village industries, and the moral and physical advancement of the villages of India.
('65', 455, 6, 8, 810858) ACTIVITIES
('65', 455, 7, 9, 810869) For the due fufilment of its object, the Association shall raise funds to carry on research work, publish literature, organize organic establish agencies, devise measures for the improvement.
('65', 455, 7, 10, 811061) of village tools, and do everything that may be necessary for the furtherance of its object.
('65', 455, 7, 11, 811154) The Association shall work under the guidance and advice of Gandhiji.
('65', 455, 7, 12, 811224) The Association shall consist of: (i) A Board of Management, (ii) Members, (iii) Agents, (iv) Honorary workers, (v) Paid, wholetime workers and (vi) Associates, and shall also have a board of advisers.
('65', 455, 8, 13, 811426) MEMBERSHIP
('65', 455, 9, 14, 811437) Any person who subscribes to the pledge hereto annexed and is recommended by a member, or any one of the duly authorized agents of the Association, and whose admission is approved by the Board of Management shall be a Member.
('65', 456, 0, 1, 811663) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 457
('65', 456, 1, 2, 811714) Any person who sympathizes with the object of the Association and pays an annual subscription of not less than Rs. 100 shall be an Associate, and any person who pays a lump sum of Rs. 1,000 may be enrolled as a Life Associate.
('65', 456, 1, 3, 811941) Advisers shall be those who, consistently with their preoccupations, agree to give the free benefit of their special knowledge to the Association whenever they are consulted.
('65', 456, 2, 4, 812116) BOARD OF MANAGEMENT
('65', 456, 3, 5, 812136) The following foundation members shall be the first Board of Management to hold office for three years: Shri Shrikrishandas Jajoo [Shri] J. C. Kumarappa Shri[mati] Gosibehn Captain Dr. Khan Saheb Shoorji Vallabhdas Dr. Prafulla Chandra Ghosh Shri Lakshmidas Purushottam Asar [Shri] Shankerlal Banker Thereafter the members shall elect the Board of Management to hold office for a period of three years.
('65', 456, 3, 6, 812539) The Board of Management shall be in full charge of the affairs of the Association, hold funds and properties for it, and shall have power to add to their number from among the duly enrolled members, provided that the total strength does not exceed twenty.
('65', 456, 3, 7, 812795) The Board of Management shall maintain proper books of accounts which shall be duly audited and which shall be open to public inspection.
('65', 456, 3, 8, 812933) The Board of Management shall have the power to frame bye laws for the carrying out of the object clause.
('65', 456, 3, 9, 813039) It will be open to the Board of Management to alter or amend or add to this constitution by the consent of three fourths of the then existing members of the Board of Management.
('65', 456, 3, 10, 813217) The Board of Management shall have power to appoint trustees to hold funds and properties on behalf of the Association.
('65', 456, 3, 11, 813337) Pledge for Members
('65', 457, 0, 1, 813356) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 457, 1, 2, 813398) Having read the constitution and rules of the All India Village Industries Association, I offer to be a member thereof and, God helping, promise to devote the best part of my energy and talents to the furtherance of its object, which is the all round welfare of the villagers of India.
('65', 457, 1, 3, 813684) So long as I remain a member of the Association, I shall not take part in any campaign of Civil Disobedience.
('65', 457, 1, 4, 813794) In the discharge of my duties, I shall seek the assistance and co operation of all those who may be willing to give them, irrespective of differences in politics.
('65', 457, 1, 5, 813957) To the best of my ability, I shall strive to live up to the ideals of the Association and prefer the use of village manufactures to any other.
('65', 457, 1, 6, 814100) In the prosecution of my obligations to the villagers, I shall recognize no distinction between man and man.
('65', 457, 2, 7, 814209) Harijan, 21 12 1934
('65', 457, 3, 8, 814229) 566. LETTER TO J. N. SAHNI
('65', 457, 4, 9, 814256) December 14, 1934
('65', 457, 5, 10, 814274) MY DEAR SAHNI,
('65', 457, 6, 11, 814289) Your letter.
('65', 457, 6, 12, 814302) I do not read Hindustan Times.
('65', 457, 6, 13, 814333) The cutting you send me I see for the first time.
('65', 457, 6, 14, 814383) It is just now 3 a.m.
('65', 457, 6, 15, 814405) Devdas is here but I see him rarely.
('65', 457, 6, 16, 814442) I am sending the cutting to him with a note of disapprobation.
('65', 457, 6, 17, 814505) Although it was a Press agency report, he had no right to publish it without reference to me.
('65', 457, 6, 18, 814599) You or he or anybody would be justified in publishing exclusive news provided it was authorized by the party affected.
('65', 457, 6, 19, 814718) There are today in India English journalists who, though not well disposed towards me, observe the rule with reference to me, not for my sake but for their own journalistic reputation.
('65', 457, 6, 20, 814903) I know that you did not err wittingly, but you have erred, now I can say, both as a soldier and [as a] journalist.
('65', 457, 6, 21, 815018) 1 The injury started with the U. P. wire from Patna.
('65', 457, 6, 22, 815071) But I have done.
('65', 457, 6, 23, 815088) I draw the attention of those who, I believe, are amenable to influence from me.
('65', 457, 6, 24, 815169) You must forget all about it, but learn the lesson that it is better not to print anything about me in which public interest is involved, without reference to me.
('65', 457, 7, 25, 815332) 1 Vide also “Letter to J.N. Sahni”, 10 12 1934.
('65', 458, 0, 1, 815380) VOL. 65 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 459
('65', 458, 1, 2, 815431) You shall certainly see me when I come to Delhi and you will incidentally know what injury has been caused by the premature publication of news that was only half true, not by you only but others also.
('65', 458, 1, 3, 815633) But others, lapse does not excuse yours.
('65', 458, 2, 4, 815674) Yours sincerely, BAPU

('65', 458, 4, 7, 815745) 567. LETTER TO SAHEBJI MAHARAJ

('65', 458, 6, 9, 815794) DEAR SAHEBJI MAHARAJ 1, I have kept your previous letter of 6th September by me.
('65', 458, 6, 10, 815875) I read your “Cows Help Cows” only last week.
('65', 458, 6, 11, 815920) It is beautifully written.
('65', 458, 6, 12, 815947) But I want to complain as a humble representative of the cow.
('65', 458, 6, 13, 816009) Some experts tell me that mixtures such as you contemplate are not wholly successful.
('65', 458, 6, 14, 816095) What, I find, is needed are experiments that would serve the villagers in their own villages.
('65', 458, 6, 15, 816189) If we do not find anything in that direction the majority of cows have to die so that the minority in off places like Dayalbagh may live !
('65', 458, 6, 16, 816328) I shall want your help in the village industries work.
('65', 458, 7, 17, 816383) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('65', 460, 1, 2, 818146) APPENDIX I
('65', 460, 2, 3, 818157) TALK WITH MARS CHESLEY
('65', 460, 3, 4, 818180) [On or before December 15, 1934] 1
('65', 460, 4, 5, 818215) MARY CHESLEY: Do you believe your guidance comes from subconscious reasoning or from God ?
('65', 460, 5, 6, 818306) GANDHI: From God—but subconscious reasoning may be the voice of God.
('65', 460, 5, 7, 818375) often, after seeing the way I consciously reason out why that is the best way.
('65', 460, 5, 8, 818454) Mahomet was like this, very sure his voices were of God and he was no impostor.
('65', 460, 6, 9, 818534) M. C. Then does following conscience lead to mystical experiences?
('65', 460, 7, 10, 818601) G. It may or it may not.
('65', 460, 7, 11, 818626) But one thing is sure that the humility which feels itself nothing before God is necessary for mystical experiences, such as those of Saint Francis and Saint Augustine.
('65', 460, 7, 12, 818795) on the other hand, a Bradlaw or a Marcus Aurelius, though following conscience, felt themselves to be self made men and not dependent on God, and so they could get no mystical experiences or joy.
('65', 460, 7, 13, 818991) To me, following conscience is following a living force, not an ethical code.
('65', 460, 8, 14, 819069) M. C. How do you understand what is God’s guidance for you when it is a question of choosing between two good things?
('65', 460, 9, 15, 819187) G. I use my intellect on the subject and if I don’t get any strong feeling as to which of the two I should choose, I just leave the matter, and before long I wake up one morning with the perfect assurance that it should be A rather than B. Always, of course, it is necessary to be utterly humble and go wherever the decision should take you, even though it should be to difficulties and suffering.
('65', 460, 10, 16, 819585) M. C. Is it not necessary to lead a disciplined life in order to receive these assurances as to what to do and not to do?
('65', 460, 11, 17, 819707) G. Yes, of course, one’s mind must be attuned to the five necessary rules of love, truth, purity, non possession and fearlessness.
('65', 460, 12, 18, 819838) M. C. Do you include bodily discipline such as fasting?
('65', 460, 13, 19, 819894) G. It you follow the five rules already mentioned.
('65', 460, 13, 20, 819945) you will find that bodily discipline follows automatically.
('65', 460, 13, 21, 820005) You should read Rajayokga by Swami Vivekananda on this point.
('65', 460, 14, 22, 820067) 1 According to the source the talk took place at the close of one of the sessions of the All India Village Industries Association held at Wardha on December 14 and 15, 1934.
('65', 461, 0, 1, 820241) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 461, 1, 2, 820283) Just then word was brought to Gandhi that a certain rich man had donated a large sum of money to the All India Village Industries Association fund, and joy was expressed by the little group, Gandhi remarking quietly .
('65', 461, 1, 3, 820501) that loving service was receiving its reward.
('65', 461, 1, 4, 820547) He had been saying previously that we who believed in non violence should win the rich to serve the poor by our own devoted service and by showing our contentment and happiness in a position of less wealth and prestige than we might demand.
('65', 461, 1, 5, 820788) He spoke about this again now.
('65', 461, 2, 6, 820819) G. If rich people could see us poorer ones really content instead of hankering after wealth, it would become the fashion to dispense with wealth.
('65', 461, 2, 7, 820965) The fashion for brown bread grew because a few enthusiasts showed that they really believed in it and liked it.
('65', 461, 2, 8, 821077) Unfortunately the higher castes have failed to identify themselves with their humbler fellows.
('65', 461, 2, 9, 821172) This is the darkest hour of Hinduism.
('65', 461, 2, 10, 821210) I have no excuse to offer for it.
('65', 461, 3, 11, 821244) M. C. What is your remedy ?
('65', 461, 4, 12, 821272) G. Everything I am doing, village industries, khaddar, Harijan work, etc.
('65', 461, 5, 13, 821346) M. C. From what sources do you get your conception of God ?
('65', 461, 6, 14, 821406) G. From my childhood, remembering my mother’s constant visits to the temple.
('65', 461, 6, 15, 821483) Sometimes these were as many as four or five a day, and never less than two.
('65', 461, 6, 16, 821560) Also my nurse used to tell me I must repeat the name of God if I felt afraid.
('65', 461, 7, 17, 821638) M. C. Are not your own experiences sources of your conception too?
('65', 461, 8, 18, 821705) G. Yes, but they did not begin until later, in South Africa.
('65', 461, 8, 19, 821766) Before that I had a period of doubt and it was during that time that I began to study Islam and Christianity.
('65', 461, 9, 20, 821876) M. C. How far have these two religions coloured your conception of God ?
('65', 461, 10, 21, 821949) G. I began with a prejudice against Christianity because in my youth it had meant to me drink, eating meat and Western clothes.
('65', 461, 10, 22, 822077) I had no such prejudice to overcome against Islam.
('65', 461, 10, 23, 822128) Later when I met some fine Christian people my prejudice went, and for a year I studied Christian books voraciously, attended the Keswick Convention, met famous divines and generally absorbed Christianity, honestly seeking to know if I should do as some of my friends were always begging me to do— become a Christian.
('65', 461, 10, 24, 822446) But in the end I honestly felt I could not do so.
('65', 461, 10, 25, 822496) I believe in the historic Jesus, for the four gospels bear the stamp of the real experience of devotees.
('65', 461, 11, 26, 822601) M. C. Is the conception of God as Father only to be found in Chris tianity ?
('65', 461, 12, 27, 822678) 1 At this point Kasturba and others came with Gandhiji's food.
('65', 461, 12, 28, 822741) Mary Chesley left and joined him again during his evening walk.
('65', 462, 0, 1, 822805) VOL. 64 : 16 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15 DECEMBER, 1934 463
('65', 462, 1, 2, 822856) G. No, it is also to be found in Hinduism.
('65', 462, 1, 3, 822899) Read the second chapter of the Gita in which the conception of God, not only as Father, but also as Mother is to be found.
('65', 462, 1, 4, 823022) This is not the case with Islam, for among all its ninetynine names for God, .’Father” is not one.
('65', 462, 1, 5, 823121) Mahomet, like Christ, had the authoritative note of God consciousness.
('65', 462, 1, 6, 823192) If you judge a religion by the changed lives of its adherents, Islam seems to me to have as much to show as Christianity.
('65', 462, 1, 7, 823314) Anyway, two thousand years is a very brief time in which to judge the merits of a religion.
('65', 462, 2, 8, 823406) M. C. I know some people who are praying that you may become a Christian .
('65', 462, 3, 9, 823481) G. (Laughing) .
('65', 462, 3, 10, 823497) Many are—
('65', 462, 4, 11, 823507) M. C. But wait until you hear the reason—it is because they feel that you can give a truer interpretation of Christianity than any yet given to the world.
('65', 462, 5, 12, 823662) G. There are others who feel that too.
('65', 462, 5, 13, 823701) But if they wish me to say that Christianity is the only true religion, I cannot do so.
('65', 462, 5, 14, 823789) I can truly say, however, that Christianity is a true religion.
('65', 462, 6, 15, 823853) M. C. What do you think is the special contribution of Christianity, Islam and Hinduism to the world?
('65', 462, 7, 16, 823955) G. I think Christianity’s particular contribution is that of active love.
('65', 462, 7, 17, 824029) No other religion says so firmly that God is love, and the New Testament is full of the word.
('65', 462, 7, 18, 824123) Christians, however, as a whole have denied this principle with their wars.
('65', 462, 7, 19, 824199) The ahimsa of Hinduism is a more passive thing than the active Christian love.
('65', 462, 7, 20, 824278) The great contribution of Hinduism is its recognition of the unity of all life.
('65', 462, 7, 21, 824358) Like Christianity, Hinduism has not lived up to its teaching.
('65', 462, 7, 22, 824420) If either had done so, there would have been no need for Islam, for whatever is fundamentally good in a religion for the part of the world in which it has arisen is certainly good for the whole world.
('65', 462, 7, 23, 824621) Islam’s contribution has been the brotherhood of all men.
('65', 462, 7, 24, 824679) Later this idea was limited to the Islamic brotherhood, so Muslims too have failed to live up to the teaching of their religion.
('65', 462, 7, 25, 824808) Khan Saheb, with his teaching of the service of all humanity, is bringing them back to the original idea.
('65', 462, 8, 26, 824914) M. C. You once said that the idea of Jesus as the Son of God was a mystical conception.
('65', 462, 8, 27, 825002) Would you enlarge upon that, please?
('65', 462, 9, 28, 825039) C. I believe that Jesus was a man born in the natural way, and that people, seeing the wonderful things he did, ascribed divinity to him, and then described it mystically by saying that he was the Son of God.
('65', 462, 10, 29, 825248) M. C. Do you think such writers were impostors?
('65', 462, 11, 30, 825296) I hey were just expressing their conception mystically.
('65', 462, 11, 31, 825352) The whole Book of Revelation is a description of mystical experiences.
('65', 462, 11, 32, 825423) For example, it does not mean literally that streets were to be paved with gold.
('65', 462, 11, 33, 825504) Many mystical expressions would be gross if they meant literally what they said.
('65', 463, 0, 1, 825585) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('65', 463, 1, 2, 825627) M. C. Have you had any mystical experiences?
('65', 463, 2, 3, 825672) G. If, by mystical experiences, you mean visions, no.
('65', 463, 2, 4, 825726) I should be a fraud if I claimed to have had such.
('65', 463, 2, 5, 825777) But I am very sure of the voice which guides me.
('65', 463, 2, 6, 825826) Of course, some unbalanced people have claimed to hear voices too—but I do not think anyone has suggested that I am unbalanced.
('65', 463, 3, 7, 825954) M. C. You have spoken of your sense of uneasiness which preceded your twenty one days’ fast 2 last year, and also said that generally when obeying your inner voice, you find a reason for your action afterwards.
('65', 463, 3, 8, 826165) Did you find a reason for the twenty one days’ fast?
('65', 463, 4, 9, 826218) G. It is true that a sense of uneasiness drove me to that fast.
('65', 463, 4, 10, 826282) Usually, even under the greatest strain I can remain quite buoyant but when I lost that buoyancy and could not even sleep, I decided to fast and immediately found peace.
('65', 463, 4, 11, 826452) Yes, I did discover a reason for it, one which the fast itself brought to light; for several people, both at the time and afterwards, wrote to tell me of sins which they had committed and which they had now put right to the best of their ability.
('65', 463, 4, 12, 826699) They said that the fast had brought them to a knowledge of the truth about themselves and that they would not allow such faults to occur again.
('65', 463, 5, 13, 826843) M. C. You have said sometimes that consciousness of sin brings a feeling of separation from God.
('65', 463, 5, 14, 826940) Did you feel any such separation before your fast?
('65', 463, 6, 15, 826991) I felt only great uneasiness and restlessness.
('65', 463, 6, 16, 827038) I could not joke even in my usual way.
('65', 463, 6, 17, 827077) During the discussion on the organization of Village Industries’ Association Gandhi made it clear that ‘rural mindedness’ was to him not a mere detail, but the prime necessity.
('65', 463, 6, 18, 827254) When the name of a certain woman was suggested as a member of the Board, he remembered that she had, in all seriousness, thought it impossible to use tooth sticks in a town, because there was nowhere to throw them.
('65', 463, 6, 19, 827469) We could not have anyone of such mentality on the Board.
('65', 463, 6, 20, 827526) To begin with, we do not want in our Village Industries to try to compete with the West in making tooth powders, etc.
('65', 463, 7, 21, 827644) Bapu, pp.
('65', 463, 8, 22, 827654) 1 This remark was said in such a droll way that all burst into laughter.
('65', 463, 8, 23, 827727) 2 From May 8 to 28, 1933.
